i didn't play all that much when the sniper bots were around but now that they are gone Team Fortress 2 is better then ever

If you're looking for a shooter game with great depth to invest into from 2007 from THE Valve themselves, look no further than this. Great and timeless class dynamics, peak community content, although this game is old, and that it's pretty much no major developments in a while, along with issues such has random crits and a mid matchmaking system, your experience will always have some funny, godlike, or bizarre moments. It's style of  may not be for you, but in a community making this game alive, it's hard not to be curious at least.

If you're a mentally stunted late 20s-early 30s male that doesn't like how difficult modern day hero shooters are, this is for you. If you're not that, do yourself a favor and play Marvel Rivals, because I'm sure whoever is reading this hates Overwatch for... uh. Reasons? I'm sure they have their reasons. 

Team Fortress 2 is a very rare instance of being a game that has what I'd like to call a 'flashbulb' version of it because it hasn't gotten a single substantial update since 2017. What you play today is what you'd be playing in 2017, with the only difference being a dwindling player base and a massive influx in cheaters. Unfortunately, the bot crisis was never fixed and if you dare to step foot outside of the cheater-infested Valve servers, you'd be submitting yourself to some of the most heinous online experiences that you'll ever have through community servers. 

Trade servers are dead, Valve servers are infested with bots, community servers are overrun with people that don't play the game. Team Fortress 2 is truly a game that you had to play during the golden age because you didn't know how much the genre could be improved until Overwatch came out and set a new bar. 

MvM is still fun af tho. No doubt about that.

[Shot opens on ringing alarm bell; sirens and klaxons play in the background]

The Administrator: "Intruder Alert! A RED Spy is in the base!"

[Signs illuminate on a large security panel: "Intruder Alert', 'RED Spy' and 'In Base'; pull out to reveal the BLU Soldier watching the board]

Soldier: "A RED Spy is in the base!?"

[Intruder Alert begins to play. The Soldier reaches from off-screen and pulls a Shotgun off a rack of weapons. Cut to the Soldier dashing down the stairs and through the 2Fort sublevel while saying "Hut, Hut, Hut!" with every step he takes]

The Administrator: "Protect the briefcase!"

Soldier: "We need to protect the briefcase!"

[Camera pans to reveal the BLU Scout trying to open the code-locked 'Briefcase Room' door]

Scout: "Yo, a lil' help here!?"

[The Soldier pushes the Scout aside and begins to 'decode' the combination]

Soldier: "All right, all right, I got it. Stand back son. 1, 1, 1, umm... 1!"

Scout: Let's go, let's go-

[BLU Heavy comes around the corner, Sasha in hand, charging towards the Scout and Soldier]

Heavy: "INCOMING!"

[Heavy shoulder-barges the door, destroying it. The three of them are sent tumbling and screaming into the Intelligence Room. The Scout reaches the desk to discover the briefcase is perfectly safe]

Scout: [while screaming, he notices the briefcase] "AAAAAHHHH- Hey, it's still here!"

Heavy: "-AAAAalright then."

Spy: "Ahem."

[Camera zooms in to reveal the BLU Spy, with the BLU Sniper's corpse over one shoulder]

Spy: "Gentlemen."

[Meet the Spy' Title Card]

[Cut back to the Spy, carrying the dead Sniper towards the desk]

Spy: "I see the briefcase is safe."

Soldier: "Safe and sound, mm-hmm."

Scout: "Yeah, it is!"

Spy: "Tell me... did anyone happen to kill a RED Spy on the way here?"

[The other three BLUs shake their heads and shrug]

Spy: "No? Then we still have a problem."

[He deposits the Sniper's body on the desk, revealing a bloody Knife in his back]

Soldier: "...and a knife."

[The Scout approaches and removes the knife]

Scout: "Oooh, big problem. I've killed plenty of Spies; they're dime-a-dozen back-stabbing scumbags - like you!"

[The Scout attempts to manipulate the knife like the Spy, only to cut himself on the finger and drop it]

Scout: "Ow! No offense."

Spy: "If you managed to kill them, I assure you, they were not like me." [The Spy deftly retrieves the knife and flicks it shut, handing it back to the Scout] "And nothing... nothing like the man loose inside this building."

Scout: "What're you? President of his fan club?"

[The Soldier and Heavy chuckle]

[The Spy turns to face the Scout]

Spy: "No... that would be your mother!"

[The Spy reveals a folder and slaps it down on the table, revealing several compromising photographs of the RED Spy and the Scout's mother]

Scout: [stammers out of shock and disbelief]

Spy: "Indeed, and now he's here to f**k us! So listen up boy, or pornography starring your mother will be the second worst thing that happens to you today."

[[[Right Behind You]] plays]

[The Soldier and Heavy examine the photographs. The Heavy leans over and shows the Soldier one photo in particular]

Soldier: "Oh!"

[The Scout frantically retrieves the photos as the Spy lights and smokes a cigarillo in the foreground]

Scout: "Gimme that!"

Spy: "This Spy has already breached our defenses..."

[Fade to the RED Spy, creeping through the Hydro tunnels. He pauses at a corner, as the camera pulls back to reveal a BLU Level 3 Sentry Gun with its Engineer. He slides an Sapper across the floor, disarming and destroying the Sentry Gun immediately]

Engineer: "Sentry Down!"

[The BLU Engineer throws his Wrench down and frantically reaches for his Pistol, only to have the Spy shoot him in the head with the Revolver. The dead Engineer crashes through a door and the Spy steps over him and fires at a target off-screen]

[Cut back to the BLU Intelligence Room. The BLU Spy leans over the dead Sniper, gesturing frantically.]

Spy: "You've seen what he's done to our colleagues!"

[Flashback to the BLU Sniper, now alive and sniping from a dusty attic. The RED Spy creeps up on him and steps on a creaking floorboard, alerting the Sniper, who engages the Spy with the Kukri. A struggle ensues, and the Sniper is ultimately backstabbed]

[Cut back to BLU Intelligence Room]

Spy: "And worst of all, he could be any one of us..."

[Fade to the RED Spy fighting a BLU Medic, armed with a Bonesaw]

Medic: "Raus, raus!"

[The Spy breaks the Medic's arm, disarming him. Close-up on the Spy's face as he disguises as the Medic, sans spectacles]

Medic: [gasps] "Nein..."

[The Spy kills the Medic with a well-placed chop to the throat, knocking off his spectacles, which he catches and wears, completing his disguise]

[Cut back to BLU Intel Room. The BLU Spy looks frantic]

Spy: "He could be in this very room! He could be you! He could be me! He could even be-"

[The Spy is cut off as his head explodes violently. The camera switches to the Soldier, Shotgun in hand, with a confused Heavy and a panicked Scout]

Scout: "Whoa, whoa, whoa!"

Heavy: "Oh!"

Soldier: "What? It was obvious!" [The Soldier pumps his Shotgun, discarding the spent shell.] "He's the RED Spy! Watch, he'll turn red any second now..."

[The Soldier and Heavy approach the dead Spy, with The Soldier prodding the Spy's foot with his Shotgun]

Soldier: "Any second now... See? Red! Oh, wait... that's blood."

[The Scout lingers behind, his expression sinister. He approaches the Soldier and Heavy, retrieving the knife he pocketed earlier, and flicking it open easily. As he approaches, he flickers and melts, revealing himself to be the RED Spy]

Heavy: "So, we still got problem..."

Soldier: "Big problem... all right, who's ready to go find this Spy?"

Spy: "Right behind you."

[Team Fortress 2 ending flourish music plays, with the stabbing of the Soldier and Heavy punctuating the beat of the tune.]

[Petite Chou-Fleur plays]

[Fade to the scattered photos of the Scout's mother. The RED Spy retrieves one of them and smiles wistfully]

Spy: "Ahh... ma petite chou-fleur."

[The RED Spy walks off with the BLU team's intel in tow]

Liked: No weird matchmaking. No one telling me what to do. An older style game community where the best and worst of humanity gather, unfettered by morality, only the urge to have fun. The class mechanics are still solid after all these years, and it's a great "pick up and play" sort of game that doesn't need huge time commitments. The bot crisis has finally be solved, so casual is fixed (for now). 

Dislike: Updates are anomalies (there's one coming out of the blue in a few months for MvM, but it's 100% community made). There is no real direction for the game going forward outside of maintenance. Only really two seasons now (winter and Summer) which are both 6 months long. Would be nice if we got at least three (Winter, Summer, and Spring). At this stage of the game, crate keys should be a dollar cheaper. Or at least more chances to get a hat/cosmetic as a regular weekly drop.  New class weapons are also never coming now that the game is so old. Old updates were canned (like invasion, or Heavy update). If Valve made TF3, would we even want to move over to it and lose all our stuff? 

All my pros are the game itself. All my cons are the situation regarding the status of the games age, so weigh that yourself. It's a free game now, after all. Why not play it?

TF2 is a surprisingly social game. You make not expect much from from a shooter, but this is pretty much the only shooter i ever play because of this aspect, along with how amazing of an artstyle this game has. 

It is a massive shame Valve no longer seems to game what makes it into the game due to lack of quality control, because this was once a consistently beautiful looking game. So much love has been put into creating a world for these characters, the lore, cinematics, map visual cues.. real shame all that is now burried under this rug made of bright nonsensical cosmetics and terrible update decisions bloated with maps, taunts and cosmetics that frankly just don't fit the game..

But despite all the issues current TF2 has, i think the game offers you more than i had hoped so when i started playing. The random social interactions with strangers only using voice commands, chat or just even taunts is something you will truly not get in any other game. Genuinely

Timeless masterpiece, unfortunately, it's only updated enough for it to be playable and in no fault of the now small development team. 

This game keeps me coming back after so long due to two things:
-It's endlessly customisable and satisfying game play. Dominating the entire server through nothing but skill and manipulating the game's engine to perform wild stunts, outsmarting opponents, has provided me with one of the most addicting game play loops a multiplayer game has ever had.
-The community surrounding it; still alive after almost 2 decades. It may seem toxic at first (as with any multiplayer FPS game), but I have enjoyed so many heartwarming and hilarious moments with random players thousands of miles away that I will probably never see again. 

The humour and inside gags within the player-base stretch beyond the game and into social media. I started watching Team Fortress 2 videos long before I even bought the game. Compilations and fan animations still appear in my YouTube recommended after several-month-long breaks between gaming sessions, as I laugh along with people from 18 years ago to the same stupid jokes.
I hope to remember this as more than a game, but a major part of my younger life. It meant, means and will mean so much to so many people.

Suppose I should do a review...
Okay, so this is one of those games where you don't need any level of experience beyond just standard PvP FPS stuff to get into it. However,
-paid content includes having fun, in-game chat*, storing more than a handful of items
-lots and lotsa toxic players, they don't normally interact with people beyond dominating lobbies though
-source(TM)  jank©
Jank includes anything from the unintended demoknight, battle medic and Pootis sub-classes all the way to backstab flings, that one window on pl_frontier, and a lot of weird reasons for getting stuck on things. The game traces its roots back to a HL2 mod and as such has matured over a long time. There's a grand old well of user generated content you can get into for free on a lot of community servers, which is a great way to have fun or play warioware if you don't want to pay for it. Seriously, check out the custom maps people make, it's incredible. 

Game culture you might want to know about: 
-Friendlies: usually seen dancing in groups, crouching with melee weapons or doing other funny shit. Killing them is normally rude, unless the whole server is dancing. At that point, I'd consider it okay to re-queue for something else or start using your tauntkills.
-Pootis: a quasi-friendly species, the Pootis is found in ctf_2Fort and many other gardens of slow gameplay. Though some are un-adorned heavy players, one can easily tell a pootis by their behaviour and colourful, often whimsical plumage. They most typically sport a beanie with tassels and a sandvich in hand, with other colourful garments seen often. They are typically friendlies. If you attack them, they may stop at nothing to kill you in a demeaning way. They may attack first, in which case the winner is whoever tauntkills the other first.
-If someone dies suddenly, with no attacks made, they have used a 'killbind'. It is a common joke. To make your own:
     1- open settings from within the game. From the popup for changing controls, select [Advanced...] -> [enable developer console]
     2- with the console enabled, hit `~ key (top left of keyboard)
     3- don't worry about the code, you're not going to hack anything (probably)
     4- enter this phrase without the quotes: 'bind k kill' and press enter
                         (you can select another key to bind but k is easy to remember and not used by default)
     5- disable the developer console, it's really annoying mid-game. 

*this is a counter-measure to some serious bot issues that have, thankfully, been resolved at the time of writing. Thank you, valve

This will always be the best "hero" shooter, casual fun environment + comedic in voice acting and game design that are alien to modern games.
No stoic military heros; no heros that couldn't bear ill will against a mosquito; no evil heros of tragic backstory that might be just misunderstood, but instead a bunch of human psycopaths bearing a cartoony levels of hate and love towards each other.
No ultimates to cause a "Q" kitchen sink standoff; only cooldown is running out of loaded ammo; no hero sharing a role with each other; no role-locking yourself; 9 heros with sidegrades will always be more insteresting and balanced than 40+ hero rosters even when there is no real update in a decade.
Not to mention how mechanically deep some tricks can be.
It is a very old game, and still the best in the genre.

So i have playing this game for around 3 and 1/2 years on and off This game i think is the in the discussion for top 3 games of all time It has fun exciting gameplay , Characters , visuals , and for a game that came out in 2007 it still is a fun experience to play.  BUT it has been neglected by valve to a extent that for a good time casual was unplayable because of the aimbots and when the community was tired of valves neglect the got of their butt and actually did something with TF2 and fixed the bot crisis for now. But the reason i love this game so much so much in fact i played during the bot crisis everyday (Because i didn't know Uncletopia severs existed). Was the characters, all 9 classes have funny and memorable lines My favorite voice line from the game is when you dominate a Demoman as Soldier he says "Scotland is not a real country You are a Englishman with a dress!" But what really got me to even pick up this game was content creators on Youtube, Im going to list off all the TF2 Youtubers that made me want to play this game , LazyPurple, UncleDane, Big Joey, TheWhatShow , Elmaxo, Great Blue, Jontohil2 , Shork, OrisTv, Itsfeckin raw, Rtgame, Solarlight, soundsmith, WeezyTF2, and last but not least Zenith, (also everyone on the chucklenuts podcast) This game has impacted my life in many ways like most of the Valve titles but Tf2 holds a special place in my Heart. Thank You for Reading My Review! :)

I told myself I would write a review for this game when the time was right. This game has allowed me to meet some pretty incredible—and awful—people. A lot of the game involves mic spam, unfair matchmaking, and crits. But every now and then, you meet some truly amazing people.

As someone who struggled with making friends and social skills, this game has been my home. Over my 10 years of playing, I’ve learned that Team Fortress 2 constantly challenges the phrase, “Now I’ve seen everything.” You’ll always find new experiences, many laughs, and a community that—despite its rot and age—still loves the game.

(Minus the horrid people on the TF2 Emporium. Valve, you really need to address that and do a better job curating.)

I joined this game near the end of its heyday and the beginning of its sunset era. I’ve met friends in real life through this game. I’ve also seen a lot of people move on from it. Real life is important, and the people in it matter. Every once in a while, I check in on people I used to play with years ago. Some are doing just fine; others, not so much. Some are in college, others are getting married, and some have kids now.

That’s why this review, albeit small, really hits home for me. It doesn’t end with updates. The mods, maps, hats, people, weapons, characters, and more all add to the game. TF2 isn’t just a game—it’s an icon.

Thank you to everyone who played this game with me over the years. To the friends who read this that I met in TF2, you’ve given me a timeless memory, and I won’t soon forget you. I look forward to playing with everyone again soon.

Oh, Team Fortress 2, you glorious, aging dumpster fire of a game still chugging along like a 2007 jalopy with a “Honk if You Love Hats” bumper sticker. Once a shining beacon of class-based shooters, TF2 has devolved into a bizarre social experiment where toxic players and brain-dead strategies collide in a cacophony of voice chat slurs and rocket-jumping regrets.

Let’s start with the community, because nothing says “welcome” like a 12-year-old moron named "Piller Croc" screaming the N-word through a $2 Walmart mic, threatening to kick you to let his friend in, while his teammate "xX_SniperGod420_Xx" types “EZ” after missing 17 consecutive headshots. The player base is a toxic stew of tryhards, trolls, and weirdly aggressive newbies who’d rather flame you for picking Engineer on offense or for running a back burner Pyro than, say, actually play the objective.  Oh you wanted to play as a sniper?  You're going to have to run that past "冰雪Ice snow" who is playing his preferred class, but takes issue with you doing the same, k thx.

Then there’s the gameplay, where the meta hasn’t evolved since the Bush administration. You’ve got players clinging to strategies so outdated they might as well be written on parchment. “Just stack five Heavies on the payload,” says MedicMain69, with the unshakable confidence of a flat-earther at a NASA convention. Meanwhile, the Spy mains are still trying to pull off the same knife trick they saw in a YouTube montage from 2012, oblivious to the fact that everyone’s got a PhD in paranoid back-checking by now. It’s not just that these players lack imagination it’s that they’re so smug about it. They’ll lecture you on why their 0-12 Scout run was “tactical” while you’re busy capturing the point solo.

Most of the tactics around the weapons were learned from a YouTube video from 10 years ago but the game has since changed, just these morons keep insisting to "crouch in front of the tank and shoot up with the phlog!" Without realizing that you can do more damage over time with literally any other flamethrower from the side.  "bUt mY fAvOrItE tWiTcH StReAmEr sAiD sO!!" is their only retort.  If they'd only play the game instead of watching someone else play the game...

And don’t get me started on the “geniuses” who think spamming “Need a dispenser here!” while standing in spawn is a personality trait. The confidence-to-competence ratio in TF2 is off the charts. You’ll see a Demoman sticky-trap his own team’s spawn door, wipe the squad, and then have the gall to call you a noob for not “predicting” his galaxy-brain play. It’s like watching a toddler proudly present you with a crayon drawing of a war crime.

Have I told you about the players who are so good they require an entire team of "expert players" to win?  Yep.  Sure fire way to tell you're on a quality server is the guy named "Gregarious" crying about how his entire team is worthless (except him, of course).  He's the best phlog pyro that ever lived to helplessly watch the bomb be delivered.  You can sense this occurs on every server this "Greg" joins.

The game itself? Still fun, in a masochistic, “I guess I’ll play one more round” kind of way. The mechanics are tight, the classes are iconic, and the art style is timeless. But Valve’s neglect has left TF2 feeling like a haunted amusement park: creaky, understaffed, and overrun by gremlins who think they’re running the show. Bots still plague servers, updates are rarer than a polite voice chat, and the hat economy is somehow more stable than crypto.

In short, Team Fortress 2 is a paradox: a masterpiece of game design dragged down by a player base that’s equal parts toxic, stubborn, and dumber than a sack of hammers. If you can stomach the cesspool of humanity and laugh at the absurdity of it all, it’s still worth a spin. Just don’t expect anyone to say “gg” unless it’s dripping with sarcasm. 2/5 stars—one for the game, one for the memes, and zero for the guy who just called me a “filthy casual” while rocket-jumping into his own team’s sentry.

The 'Meet your Match' update proved even a 9 year old game will succumb to the trend of matchmaking and force players to only play on Publisher servers. 

Instead of encouraging the individual to host their own servers or join others, Valve chooses to take the bandwidth and discourage community servers by filtering traffic. 
Where then players are greeted by bots, unbalanced teams or 10 minute matches that nobody gets to stay in after. The threat of bots is always alive as long as Valve continues to funnel the majority of tf2's playerbase into their own servers, where they do little to no moderation.

Valve should bring back the ability to select teams, in order to keep games balanced. Valve should also bring back the quickplay system. It kept both Valve servers and dedicated community servers populated. And matches within community servers are allowed to go on for hours, meaning you can play on the same map/gamemode to your heart's content.

Tf2, as a software, was developed by Valve, yes. But its very experience was developed by the community FOR the community. Don't let anyone tell you Valve can replicate it through their servers alone.

team Fortress 2 is a true classic FPS pvp gaming experience.
It may have its fair share of negatives, like bugs, and cheaters,

But the positives are that it is  the definitive experience of what gaming was like 18 years ago.
It was a gem back then and it's a diamond now.
A true timeless classic that has aged like a fine wine.

even if you somehow missed this masterpiece, it still has a STRONG 40,000 daily players, and for good reason, so give it a shot, 
and you'll see why this game from nearly 2 decades ago still outclasses most modern triple-A titles.

Its distinct and memorable set of classes and their weaponry appealing to a wide range of playstyles across almost 200 maps with varied gamemodes makes it one of, if not the best multiplayer first-person shooter of all time, all for the price of free.

I'm sure there's a good game buried somewhere underneath, but if you're the type to do more than only do the main story, not on their exact brand/specs, it's not worth it, even on sale.

Writing this review after finally beating the game for the first time on a 335 hour playthrough in which I did essentially everything possible to on a single playthrough and close to maxed all achievements.

I'll start by saying it's rare for me to finish a large, sandbox RPG like this. Oblivion, Skyrim, Fallout, sit among the many "started but never finished" games that just couldn't hook me long enough to play through a multi-hundred hour game. Cyberpunk did that for me.

I think the reason for that, which was unexpected to me, was not merely the beautiful setting or addictive and face past action; it was the narrative. Installing Cyberpunk for the first time, I was expecting an "okayish shooter" to pass the time. Instead, I got a deeply gripping narrative filled with characters I came to care about and consistently dark and soul crushing decisions with real consequences.

Cyberpunk 2077 is the story of V, a girl (or guy) who just wanted to live, but has had that choice taken from her. Its story boils down to the decisions V makes while on a quest to cure herself, while also trying to balance her morality and protect the people she comes to care about along the way. But Cyberpunk isn't a place for happy endings, and it never felt like there was a right or wrong choice, just ones I could live with more than others.

Cyberpunk was a rare and unexpected treat that has absolutely earned its place among my all time favorite games.

I genuinely don’t understand what they did to this game or why. 

I had well over three tone displayed in game (modded sometimes didn’t count playtime). 
I was excited to get into the new DLC with my character, only to learn that it’s essentially impossible. 

They fundamentally changed literally every single system in the game. 
All of them. 

Not like… a little tweak here and there. Fundamentally, every aspect of how the game once worked, is now different. 


Here’s everything I noticed in the 4 hours I forced myself to suffer through it:
-You no longer derive stats from equipment. 
Every gun you pick up will do the same thing the guns you already have do. Maybe it will look a little different, or use a a different ammo… but the damage numbers are identical. 

Same seems to be true of even the legendary weapons. 
Your damage seems derived from your stats, skills, and chrome (cyberware). 

-Clothing no longer provides armor, save for a very select few. 

Every scrap of cloth you get is worthless. Some offer mild bonuses and like… set options… but those bonuses are marginal at best.

All the armor you’re gonna get is gonna come from Chrome.

-Cyberware is now your primary and only mechanism of gear-based progression. 
It determines almost everything you do, and no longer functions the way it used to. 

You are now hard-limited by your physical cap of how much chrome you can have. That seems primarily to be determined by your skills/attributes and character level/rep. 

-you no longer use healing items the same way anymore. It seems like you are given a certain number of heals per fight, and that’s that. Weird design choice. 


I dunno. I can’t figure out who this game is for now.

it's alright. theres honestly not a whole lot of content outside of the main story. theres like 4 or 5 side stories you can do that are pretty short. other than that youre basically doing repetitive chore missions or dicking around waiting for someone to call you so you can progress through the story. The power scaling needs to be worked out better too, seeing how even on the hardest difficulty youre basically a god at level 20. I really feel like i shouldnt be able to walk into a group of enemies, stand in one spot, and one shot all of them so early in the game. 

This one might just be a me thing, but theres too many loot drops. after every fight all i see are these colorful X's on my minimap and my little goblin brain doesnt let me leave until ive collected a bunch of bullshit that im never going to use anyway. i end up spending way too much time collecting, organizing, and selling items for money that i dont need. 

All things considered id say its a 3.5/5 stars. The story is pretty lacking for how big the game is, and the power scaling is just ridiculous to a point that the game becomes very trivial early on. Other than that, i mostly had fun milking what little content there actually is in this game.

Besides being unhealthy, that should tell you something about the quality of the game. I started my character on a whim when I had a break from work, said I'd just do the character creation. Picked the corpo lifepath. Right away, I was kind of hooked. Walking around my office, trying to figure out the relations between all of my superiors, I had no idea how deep this rabbit hole went. I thought Jenkins and Abernathy would be people I would need to know, people who would be with me for the entire game. By the time I got to the six month training montage with Jackie, I was seriously excited. And the next day when I finally had the time to sit down and play for 6 to 8 uninterrupted hours and did the Heist mission, holy crap. 

This game is incredible. It has its flaws, but if you love open world games, first person shooters, deep character customization, roleplaying games, good characters, good story, freedom within missions to complete them however you want to, devs that reward careful planning and scouting, but also dont punish you for running in guns blazing and gorilla arms swinging... you'll love Cyberpunk 2077. The world alone is worth the price of entry. It's just a stunningly beautiful world. If you're on the fence, buy it. I highly doubt you'll regret it. 

I put off my purchase for four years just to make sure all the bugs and kinks were ironed out. [h1]A successful dystopian adventure[/h1]

This game does the cyberpunk genre justice. You move through a city driven by corruption and greed, ruled by wealthy mega-corporations. The dystopia feels real because it builds on experiences we recognize from our own time, just without regulation or control. The whole city is packed with ads on every corner: weapons, gambling, sex.

The top earners in the corporations act and think just as morally questionable as the criminal organizations underground, which gives the hopeless dystopian vibe a lot of credibility. Everything is loud, flashy, and broken in one way or another. It’s a world where nobody cares about you and you shouldn’t expect any empathy. People are exploited and used for maximum profit.

The setting is very coherent, and the characters feel believable in their actions and attitudes regarding the reality they live in. The gameplay is solid, but it’s a real shame that a game with such a strong focus on customization doesn’t offer a third-person view. The soundtrack is phenomenal and adds a lot to the atmosphere.

Many side quests can be approached in different ways depending on V’s abilities, and some side characters have surprisingly deep storylines that can really hit you. And Night City doesn’t hand out happy endings out of goodwill.

Driving doesn’t feel particularly satisfying, but on foot the game plays quite well. There are also lots of small details you can discover while exploring that have little or nothing to do with the main story, yet contribute a ton to the setting and overall atmosphere.

Personally, I’d say the final product still falls a bit short of the expectations that were built up, but the purchase was absolutely worth it.

Night City: bright lights, big guns, and even bigger feelings.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a sprawling open‑world RPG where you wander, shoot, hack, flirt, and occasionally get shot while looking fabulous in leggings with neon spikes. Once notorious for being a buggy mess at launch, years of patches and expansions have turned it into a very positive experience loved by a huge playerbase — with lots of story, choices, and post‑launch improvements still drawing crowds every night. 

Pros:

Deep Night City with tons to do and explore 🌆 

Strong story & memorable characters (Phantom Liberty adds even more) 🧠 

Still huge, still popular — even years later with a very positive Steam rating 📊 

Cons:

Not perfect — bugs and odd behaviors still crop up sometimes 🪲 

RPG mechanics and some systems can feel a bit uneven depending on playstyle 

Verdict:
From disaster at launch to beloved cyberpunk RPG, this is now one of the most talked‑about open‑world games out there. Recommended if you like story‑driven RPGs and neon‑soaked chaos — especially on sale. 🎮

From the moment I started playing Cyberpunk 2077, I was captivated by its rich world and immersive storytelling. Despite having only about 82 minutes of initial playtime on PC—just to mod and transfer my saves to PlayStation—I’ve logged over 150 hours in the game. This truly speaks to how captivating and engaging the experience is.

Cyberpunk 2077 stands out as one of my top 10 favorite games of all time. The detailed world-building in Night City is unparalleled, with intricate narratives and complex characters that kept me hooked from start to finish. The freedom to explore and customize your experience is truly remarkable, and the modding community has only expanded the game’s potential, making it even more enjoyable.

What sets Cyberpunk 2077 apart is its blend of deep storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and a dynamic, living world. It’s a game that rewards exploration and creativity, and it’s easy to see why it’s become one of my all-time favorites.

In short, if you haven’t yet ventured into Night City, I highly recommend it. It’s a game that truly deserves a spot in any gamer’s top 10 list.

Absolute Masterpiece – Night City Finally Shines! (★★★★★)


I waited until the 2.0 update and the Phantom Liberty DLC dropped to dive into Night City, and I can honestly say it was worth the wait. This is, without a doubt, one of the best single-player RPG experiences I've ever had. The game has achieved a level of polish and immersion that few titles can match.

The Story & Characters: The narrative is incredibly compelling, mature, and emotionally resonant. V's journey is an emotional rollercoaster, elevated by brilliant performances, especially Keanu Reeves as Johnny Silverhand. The side quests are where the game truly excels; they are often better written than most other games' main stories, filled with depth, moral ambiguity, and memorable characters like Judy.

The World: Night City itself is a visual and atmospheric marvel. Every neon-lit street corner, towering skyscraper, and gritty alley feels alive and meticulously detailed. Driving around with the amazing soundtrack playing while the rain reflects off the puddles is an experience in itself.

Gameplay & Combat: The combat is fluid, fast-paced, and incredibly satisfying. The reworked skill trees and cyberware system offer a huge amount of flexibility, letting you become an unstoppable netrunner, a chrome-plated brawler, or a stealthy assassin. The choices you make genuinely impact the world and how missions play out, adding significant replayability, that is until you leave Hanako waiting at Embers until our Sun will end its life by expanding into a red giant, engulfing inner planets like Earth, then shedding its outer layers to form a planetary nebula, leaving behind a dense, Earth-sized stellar core called a white dwarf that slowly cools and fades over trillions of years. 


CD Projekt Red has delivered on the game's original promise, transforming a rocky launch into a genuine triumph. If you held off because of the initial reviews, do yourself a favor and pick it up now. This is a must-play experience.

Booting up Cyberpunk 2077 is like jacking straight into Night City’s datastream—neon-soaked streets, chrome everywhere, and vibes cranked to max like some preem Lizzy Wizzy BD. The world feels alive, chooms: corpos scheming, street thugs hustling, and fixers dropping gigs like hot data shards.

The combat? Preem. Whether you’re blasting gonks, slicing with monowires, or quickhacking enemies into flatline mode, it feels slick once you’re chromed up. The story hits hard too—full of moral gray zones and moments that make you stop and think, like a real braindance.

And the achievements? Absolute nice to grind (expect for some endings ) but nevertheless nice to spend time on them—pure nova. Each one feels like scoring serious eddies, rewarding you for exploring every dark alley and wild build Night City has to offer.

Sure, it had some rough patches back in the day, but now it runs way smoother and feels like the game it was always meant to be. If you’re into deep stories, open-world chaos, and that high-tech low-life aesthetic, this one’s worth the jack-in.

I’d totally recommend it, choom. Cyberpunk 2077 is nova-tier now—don’t sleep on it.

Yes but with huge caveats.

One, some of the dialogue is off (it's usually the blue side questions that sometimes seem unaccounted for).

Two, some of the main stories feel truncated. Others don't. 

These first two complaints can be reasonably defended by the size of the world and story they were trying to tell. Given the immense scope of the game, they aren't particularly damning.

But the game being janky as hell years after release (and after claims that 2.0 polished the game) is really inexcusable. I honestly think Red bit off more than they can chew with worldbuilding, but whatever. Let's get specific.

The cars and driving generally is just chaotic. I mean, personally, I wish devs would just stop putting cars in games until you can reasonably drive them without fishtailing all over the place. BUT maybe I'm just bad at driving.

BUT even if I am bad at driving, the autopilot justifies my complaint even more because even it can't drive well. First time I pressed autopilot the vehicle literally turned left and plowed into a wall. It consistently did this. It also consistently just ran into the back of cars. And at one point there was a car pile up that the game's engine clearly didn't know how to resolve, so it blew all the cars up. One car fell right next to me, upside down, the people inside looking deadpan (but not dead).

It breaks immersion.

And I wish that was all that broke immersion. I tried several times to do stealth and the game said "no thanks." And it wasn't my fault, either. One time I put down a body I just knocked out. No one was in the room. No cameras. No nothing. Suddenly everyone in the building gets alerted. Apparently this is a glitch where if a body is moved into a wall, the game engine freaks out and pushes it out. But this can sometimes be interpreted by the engine as making a loud noise like a gunshot. So screw me.

I shouldn't have to fight the NPCs and the engine.

The engine couldn't figure out which UI overlay I was in several times. For instance, there was one time when I could only see a conversation when I used by cyber optics.

People walking through walls. Bodies buried under objects, observable only by the loot sign. So on and so forth.

These things break immersion, and a game like Cyberpunk 2077 relies heavily on immersion and tonality (it's literally why they chose the first-person view and not the third-person view).

The mechanics are sometimes dubious. I had a hard time choosing what guns I wanted to run. SMGs and pistols use the same ammo. Apparently pistols do more headshot damage, and SMGs spray more bullets. But I could never figure out why I'd really choose one over the other. I think you could reasonably run through the game with one gun (probably a pistol) and never bother with any of the other guns, so why bother having so many types?

And the mechanics sometimes worked in weird ways. One time I wanted to merely incapacitate people in a building. There's ammo for this. Pax ammo makes all your shots non-lethal. So I equipped on a single shot weapon, the smart sniper rifle. Good, yeah? Can't go wrong. One high-damage bullet and they all go to sleep.

Nope. Apparently with a high-damage shot, the "gore" mechanic registers with the engine before the "pax" mechanic. So if you do a shit-ton of damage (like you'd do with a headshot from a sniper), you blow their head off no matter what. This wasn't explained and ruined the quest.

It's not just that the mechanic isn't explained, it's that the conflict between these divergent mechanics (gore vs pax) seems stupid. If I choose pax ammo, that is a very intentional choice as a player. I very clearly want to be non-lethal. So depriving me of that just because of how the gore mechanic works seems counter-intuitive to good gameplay.

And, honestly, lots of things feel "lazy." During two quests, bodies, people, and cars disappeared as I was walking along. This is aggressive clearing by the engine, freeing up resources for whatever scene comes next.

A lot of games use gentle clearing, removing these assets to free up resources when you, the player, aren't looking. This preserves immersion.

But this engine used aggressive clearing. In one case, I was in a room that was just before a big boss fight. I walked up to some characters and initiated dialogue and the room cleared right as the conversation started. This isn't a coding issue; it's a staging issue. The assets should've been cleared not when the conversation started but when I moved to the next room and the door closed behind me. Instead, the devs just wrote a code to free the resources up as fast as possible, not bothering to keep immersion intact.

And again, immersion is paramount to this style of game.

Defenders say the aggressive clearing is needed because the game is so resource heavy. I find this doubtful because, again, it's a staging issue, not a coding issue. If you know a quest is coming, put reasonable measures in place to keep the clearing hidden. Put in an extra room. A dialogue that stops me from moving. Something.

The story is good, though. Phantom Liberty is definitely the highlight. But overall, the reason it gets a thumbs up is because I found it enjoyable overall, even if a bit annoying.

Cyberpunk 2077 is an absolutely awesome game — easily one of the best I’ve ever played.

Beyond the wonderful and deeply immersive gameplay, what truly elevates it is the philosophical core. The game doesn’t just show a futuristic city; it explores where humanity might be heading. Corporations, AI, the Blackwall, transhumanism, Soulkiller — all of it ties into unsettling questions about identity, consciousness, and what it really means to be human.

The idea of copying a mind, losing the self, or existing as something almost human creates a genuine existential tension that sticks with you long after you stop playing. Night City feels alive, oppressive, beautiful, and tragic all at once.

This isn’t just an action RPG — it’s a story about humanity facing its own reflection in technology. An unforgettable experience.

Cyberpunk 2077 is pure style and soul. Neon-soaked streets, killer music, insane atmosphere. Night City feels alive, dangerous, funny, and way too real sometimes.

The story goes hard. Keanu Reeves as Johnny Silverhand is iconic, and Phantom Liberty is on another level. Reed (Idris Elba) steals the show with full spy-thriller energy. That DLC alone is wild.

The side quests are where this game really shines. Weird, emotional, unhinged, and memorable. Dialogue choices actually matter and let you be whoever you want to be. No two moments feel the same.

Cyberpunk 2077 is bold, creative, chaotic, and unforgettable. Leaving Night City after 203 hours felt like saying goodbye to something special. <3

Cyberpunk 2077 is finally in a great place. On v2.3x, performance was smooth and stable throughout.

Gunplay, movement, and customization feel great, and Night City looks incredible—especially with path tracing. The characters are memorable and player choices actually matter.

The main story is a bit short, side “Gig” missions can feel repetitive, and progression caps too early, but these issues don’t outweigh the experience.

Overall, a very strong and immersive game that I absolutely recommend.

Absolutely masterful.  Whatever issues may have plagued this game on launch - as of 2025 (going into 2026) - software here is spotless.  The story and [i]game[/i] underneath shine as brightly as I imagine was intended from the get-go.

I didn't rightly [i]know[/i] what I was getting into here.  I have no prior experience with CDPR games, so the writing took me by surprise.  If I had to expect anything, it would have been another Skyrim - a long list of checkboxes to tick and a rote, tired gameplay loop that gets boring as quickly as you reach the end of it, padded out by bullet sponge enemies or simply making you [i]walk farther.[/i]  A bunch of faceless, soulless PG-13 robots that exist to push you along to the next theme park ride.  But that's not at all what we've got here, not by a long shot.

I look at this, look at the hours I've put in here, in what feels like such a small amount of time, and I do not consider one minute of that time wasted.  Of course, there were issues, but they were so infrequent that experiencing the issues themselves stood out to me.  The fact that any occurred at all made me realize how seldom they happened.  There is no 'filler' here.  Everything that exists does so for a purpose, and of the time spent just going from A to B, there was always something fun to do in between, whether that was some kind of side-thing, or just the movement itself.  Everything was done fantastically.  Of the issues I had throughout my time with this game, all of them were either forgotten or resolved themselves before the end.

Truly the only issue that hasn't been fixed is that there isn't [i]more[/i] to some of the narratives, but nothing feels like it got the MGSV treatment.  Nothing here is half-finished or cut short, the game's lore doesn't just exist stuffed away in audio or text logs - though there are plenty of the latter if you like reading.  Some things just end on a cliffhanger.  Things you're never meant to know, maybe.

This game isn't the kind you can make a sequel to, I don't think.  At least not for another decade or so, give or take some kind of narrative epiphany.

The story was written by people who understand how people speak, and did not pull punches for the sake of pleasing either the player themselves or the PC in-universe.  There [i]are[/i] cases where you have to make decisions and you cannot do everything you can possibly want in one playthrough.  There are decisions with consequences that will affect how you play, and more importantly, how you [i]feel[/i].  You can savescum of course, but the only one you're cheating is yourself.  Robbing yourself of the experience you've just invested hours into seeing through.  This is not a game for the guy who wants to save everyone.  There's no all-seeing god looking over you to lower your score at the end for killing people instead of knocking them out.  There's just you, the world, and your conscience.

The topics covered in this game's story, among other things it holds, have always been extremely interesting to me in particular.  There are so many parallels here to things I've personally dealt with in my life, things I've already had to consider, problems I've solved or thought I had solved, now staring me right back in the face, in a way that seems as real as any sort of digital "reality C" can possibly ever be.  It may as well be real, with how it f-cks with my head.  I guess that's just art, isn't it?

This game made me change as a person, for the better.  Sounds dramatic, but that's the truth.  Through all the sci-fi bullsh-t, I see bits of myself in this thing.  I have walked away with new, perception-altering experiences tucked away somewhere in my brain, to inform my behavior down the line, am I to ever find my way into these situations again.

Maybe now I'll put together what being alive means.  I've got the pieces right in front of me - Disco, NITW, and the rest from my time in meatspace.  Maybe this was the last one.

I'm frankly not sure how this game receives acclaim now despite it still being somewhat of a mess. Granted, most of the large issues such as crashes (Most of the time) or overall surface presentation have been resolved in due part to patches. However, I question whether or not this approach to game design is going to work out for studios when they can't even out develop a game from a decade ago or more. There are multiple arguments or conversations to be had about why the game shipped in such a state for the initial release, but it doesn't help everything has to be reworked and tacked on due to poor planning. Such additions don't feel natural personally and very awkward during a playthrough. 

I can at least praise the concept/art/music aspects of the game or even the general plot of the story, but interest just falls off for both areas so quickly after Act I. It would at least hold up in some regard if it played like an RPG, but a lot of times you are forced into doing whatever the scenario wants you to do. This is also strained by the fact that a lot of the time this feels like it wants to be more of a movie or some single-track amusement ride on rails than a game.

I don't like shooters, I don't like American cheese and there's no way I was buying this sh1t they couldn't even be arsed finishing.  No way was I supporting a company like that.  Well I stopped being a little b1tch and did just that and bought it.  My mate gave me £10 gift card for Christmas, so I only paid £7.50.

Is it cheesy American crap?  Yes.  I have played the intro and got to say that this cheesy pile of turd is actually pretty enjoyable.  Not sure why, it's just kind of fun and funny.  

I absolutely do not see this opening up in to some masterpiece of a game but it's whacky and fun and I'm pleasantly surprised.   

Are mashed up bodies with tiddies out strewn around everywhere and getting my face smashed with a cosh really necessary?  Absolutely.  I'll give it that, it does give me a few laughs.

Was probably worth £7.50 just for the hour of fun I had with it tonight.  It's a pretty easy recommend.

Oh and the OST got some bangers too.

Truly awesome game, just beat it for the first time but feel like I only scratched the surface. So many different ways to go right up until the very end. The game lets you play the way you want most of the time, except for the (arguably) forced stealth missions. But stealth in this game is typically more forgiving than other games where stealth missions feel like a chore.

The game looks great, though may take some tinkering with graphics settings depending on your setup (I was on AMD Ryzen 9 5900X, RTX 4070 and 32GB DDR5 RAM, frame gen got me to a consistent 150-160 fps on high settings iirc). The game also sounds great and stuff like vehicles, guns and voices sound great. The main character male voice sounds like a major douchebag, which may or may not be your thing. I haven't heard the female MC voice, but many seem to prefer her.

Characters are where this game brought me back to the days of New Vegas. Through all the game's bullshit bugs and lack of elegance at times, the story, world and characters kept me coming back for more. I plan to come back to the game to complete it with different endings, paths, etc.

Overall, great game and I definitely recommend it for people looking for a fun RPG with plenty of content that can potentially last you months. It may seem a bit overwhelming with all the NPCs calling you so much and with how big the world is. But take the dive and you won't regret it.

This is one of my top five story games of all time and easily one of my favourite games ever on PC. 2077 is immersive on a level that you just don't get from any other story game and it's why I got drawn to it in the first place. No cutscene outside the endings, all story and interactions and rendered in game and happen seamlessly between gameplay and it's incredible in how revolutionary it is. The characters are so in depth and believable and it's so interesting to dive into them and understand their personalities and viewpoints. I am so incredibly attached to the characters in this game, Jackie, Panam, Judy, Victor, Johnny, Rogue, Mitch, Claire, River, Misty, Goro, Reed, Alex, So Mi and so many more. I love them all and I can only hope we can get even more content around existing characters in other Cyperpunk instalments.

I first purchased CP2077 when it came out, spent 15 minutes ingame and was heavily disappointed, I felt like I had been scammed. I googled my concerns, found that there were many others like me. I refunded the game, and never looked back.

Until now. Man, what a comeback. What a STORY. I played 80% of the game in vanilla 2.3, and THEN I modded it and WOW. It's like an entirely different game both times. There's a ton of depth, a ton of different ways to play. Stealth? Done. Shoot em' up? Done. Cars? Weapons? Almost unending variations, then mods will add even more if you wish. Every time I turn down an alleyway I haven't explored, I find something new to do. 

The story progresses at a rate that gives you a chance to relish in a feeling or a mood, but still moves along fast enough that you can spend an hour each evening and feel like you accomplished something.

Just buy it if you haven't tried it, and if you like it as much as I did, there's an expansion that added almost an entirely new main story worth of content. 

I am pleased with CDPR and the efforts they took to fix the game, and I am VERY excited for a sequel.

I'll start by saying that I'm not the type of person to play through the same game twice, very rarely do I even buy the same game for multiple platforms. As of writing this, I'm playing through Cyberpunk 2077 for the fifth time across Xbox and Steam. It is that good.

The gameplay and customization is great. You really can go at most scenarios however you wish, be it stealth, guns blazing, turning enemies on each other, or even charging in with a plastic meat stick. There's a solid perk system that allows you to create some interesting, highly specialized builds.

The story is well written and entertaining, even the side missions and filler tasks have their own little stories that occasionally tie into the overall plot. I have found myself actually getting lost reading logs and listening to dialogues just to see some of those webs that the writers at CDPR created.

The setting and visuals are amazing. There's a reason this game has been used as a benchmark over the last five years, but beyond that, it truly is something to see the neon filled, futuristic dystopia that is Night City.

Controls are awkward, do wish in settings you could remap controller keybinding.  Game assumes I'm using mouse, but only using keyboard/touchpad.  

And slight pauses, like in conversation, game hangs after you respond, makes a bit awkward.  I'm assuming this is because I've got a budget gaming laptop.

Other than that, this game is immersive, incredible graphics, has style, flair, personality, darn good storylines, easy to get lost in it.  I never played Grand Theft Auto, so this is 1st time playing a game this gritty.  My current player, studly dude wearing increasingly more girly makeup, and plan is to have him swap genders once he makes enough money for a sex change operation.  

Currently, I think what cracks me up the most...  I'm a stealth, patient player.  Can wait aeons, calmly, for enemy to make a mistake, then snipe them from afar.  So hunkering down behind a defense, in shadow, while enemies are yelling at me from afar calling me ****, all sorts of taunting, like being on grade school playground.  Makes me LOL literally.

Being able to pull out my gun and shoot somebody in the face who'd been domestically abusive, shoving women around, is quite cathartic.  

The level of detail is impressive.  Like, scenery, billboards, advertisements, urban design, bars, characters, so much depth, attention to detail.

EDIT:  it does the thing i hate.  you spend so much time building a character, getting invested, then the game just randomly kills that character, forces you to spend an unnecessarily long amount of time stuck between an endless series of cinematic sequences, then forced to do restricted activities, frustrating, as an underpowered character you don't care about cuz the game killed the character you were invested in.

still a good game.  i'm mentioning this in case this is the kind of things that bugs anybody else.  god, it's like warframe's new war quest all over again.

I've been playing Elden Ring for an embarrassingly long amount of time, and my friend suggested I give Cyberpunk 2077 a try. I'm going to spend a lot of time on this game.

After following this game's hype train from its 2013 trailer to launch, I guess my unfilitered dog-shit opinion is warranted. Unless you've been completely offline for half a decade, you'll know that this game's debut was one of the most controversial and damaging game launches seen up to that date. Fast forward 5 years and you'll see many praising this game as "one of the greatest comebacks ever bro!" thanks to constant patches that were necessary to keep CDPR's reputation from sinking to the ocean floor, and an excellent anime launched nearly two years after the base game. I would never call Cyberpunk a "bad game" by any means, it's just if you ever stop to look at it in context, you'll see the broken promises, lost potential, the voids left behind by story rewrites, and an ultimately hollow feeling world.

Since Cyberpunk 2077's identity at launch became more known for its bugs than anything else, other pressing issues were quickly eclipsed behind NPCs walking through walls, cops spawning out of thin air to punish your crimes, and enemies t-posing while using the sandevistan. However gamebreaking (and hilarious), because the bugs and glitches that held the publicity spotlight were getting fixed, people began to forget the fact that the game was a mere shell of what was promised over the course of the 2010s.

I would say that this is especially true after the anime, Cyberpunk: Edgerunners, came out in 2022 and pumped new life and a new fanbase into the game. Most everyone who jumped in after watching the pop-culture phenomenon anime got to experience a completely different game than those at launch. Many new and returning players quickly began to praise it as a complete comeback akin to No Man's Sky. Ironically, Cyberpunk completely swept the "Labor of Love" award from No Man's Sky that year at the Steam Awards based on its newfound popularity, which I, and many others at the time, would say was mainly thanks to the popularity boost by the anime. However, many players who had been playing since launch were rather confused by CDPR winning the award, since all they were doing as "Labor" was fixing bugs and reversing asinine gameplay choices that should have been ironed out before delivery. They weren't even adding content to the game at that point. Effectively, Studio Trigger carried the corpse of Cyberpunk across the finish line, and CDPR got a crown for it. 

I wholeheartedly believe that CDPR does not catch enough flak for their broken promises and false advertising leading up to the game's launch. This game continues to advertise itself as an RPG, and the actual commercial advertising leading up to the game's launch promised a deep RPG experience akin to the tabletop game. Each of the unique lifepaths you chose for your V were going to have vastly different consequences on the gameplay depending on what you chose. Instead all you got is a flavorful 20 minute section at the beginning of the game according to your lifepath before your character flows into the same overarching story regardless of choice. 

Fallout 4 style branching dialogue runs the show with "Yes" (Corpo) "Yes" (Nice) "Yes" (Snarky) "No" (Mean) that ultimately changes nothing for the most part. Sometimes dialogue options can lead to extra bonuses if you choose the lifepath option, such as calming a hacker down with the Corpo option to where she gives you some extra eddies, but that's about it. The only time your choices will actually have an impact on the game is during the end. You will choose your ending and that's it, that's pretty much all the agency that you have. Outside of that, the story of your V will be the same as anyone else's. Even the way you build your character with upgrade points does not really matter since you are granted enough points to build an effective jack-of-all trades. And you can always just respec your character if you feel like your build does not benefit you. If you look at Cyberpunk as an action game with a couple RPG elements, it's a fantastic at what it does, but going off what it was advertised as: Cyberpunk a completely lackluster RPG.

One of the more nitpicky issues I have with Cyberpunk is the game's style and fashion. You might be ready to say "But Woomy, Cyberpunk is all about style over substance!" and I would completely agree with you. I would actually argue that base game Cyberpunk has a completely lacking in style for a cyberpunk setting, especially for something that takes place in the flavorful and stylish Cyberpunk universe itself. The base game's clothing options look more like what would be depicted by a stereotypical millennial in San Francisco who thought that mashing the styles of bandits from Borderlands with the fashion choices of the average level 1000 in GTA online would make for the perfect depiction of Cyberpunk's available style and fashion. During your gameplay, you'll find plenty of cheetah print fedoras, leather pants, rusty respirators, and worn out looking military surplus clothes, but nothing that really screams "high-tech, low-life" or "cyberpunk". If you want to argue with me "Well the chaotic nature of Cyberpunk is its style!" please just look at the ads leading up to the game's launch, and then look at the database of clothing options offered in the game. Simply just look at the stylistic differences between the style of the 2013 announcement trailer VS what was delivered in the base game in 2020. Beyond that, the styles that CDPR advertised in their "Style vs Substance" advertisement made before the game's launch are not even offered in the base game, making it another complete false promise. You can see them start to get touched upon in the game's DLC, Phantom Liberty, but even there, the list is cut too short for what should have been. It's rather pitiful variety for a game that takes place in a universe that's about people desperate to look, feel, and be unique in a world wrought with nihilistic consumerism. You can still tell that the game's amount and variety of clothing options were designed to fill the game's loot pool when it was running off of the horrid armor/clothing stats system that hindered the game at launch by forcing people to run around in underwear and netrunner headsets for the sake of stats. Now, the stats are gone, but the lacking fashion choices remain.

Ultimately, I would say Cyberpunk did not even begin to shine until its DLC, Phantom Liberty, came out. It could be said that wherever Cyberpunk fell flat in polish, character agency, style, and story, Phantom Liberty addressed it and fixed it within its own complete package and amazing self-contained story. It honestly feels jarring going from Phantom Liberty and back to the comparatively unpolished base game. Ultimately, Phantom Liberty left me wanting more, even when I knew I could not ever have more.

All in all, if you are going to buy Cyberpunk, please remember that it is ultimately not an RPG where your choices matter. It's an action game with a few RPG elements and a solid story that lacks polish literally everywhere besides the beginning, and the end. It's one of those games where if you ever stop to really look at it, you can still see and feel so much of the lost potential and broken promises around every corner. I can recommend the game with what it currently offers, but I can only recommend it if it's on sale alongside Phantom Liberty, as I feel like that is the real Cyberpunk 2077 experience.

Cyberpunk 2077 is a stylish open-world action-adventure game that excels at atmosphere, world design, and player freedom. Night City is dense, visually striking, and packed with handcrafted detail, making exploration consistently engaging. Combat and hacking are flexible and satisfying, supporting multiple playstyles without overwhelming micromanagement. The presentation—music, visuals, and performances—is exceptional, and many side missions feel thoughtfully designed rather than repetitive filler.
This game quickly rose to the top of my list of all time favourites. Great story and characters, engaging and fun gameplay, awesome soundtrack

Story:
Probably the best story in a RPG open-world game. A lot of twist and turns, engaging. None of the take this go there type of quest, each quest is waiting to suprise you in every turn. Some of the best character written as well, each of them feels unique and almsot actually alive. Hands down best endings in a RPG, none of them feels out of place, all of them logically make sense and feel like its something a real human can choose. And the Phantom Liberty DLC is what every DLC in a RPG should be like.

World:
Developers did a wonderful job crafting the world of cyberpunk, I will say it is the most immersive experience I personally have ever played in a -first/third person RPG. From the colour palet, intricate use of light and shadows between streets, to the ambient sounds, cyberpunk is a world that truly draw you in (or make you feel uncomfortable cause of how horrible life in NC is). 

Balance/different play-style:
The game used to be quite unbalanced, meaning certain play-style is significantly more rewarding than others in every difficulty. With the patches given with Phantom Liberty, I can say the skill tree is quite balanced, meaning you can use every play-style in every difficulty and be effective. Granted in the hardest difficulty there are certain play-styles that are easier to be effective, but other ways of playing works too. So you won't feel like you have to choose a particular way to play the game just because that is easier.

Bugs:
Like any game, this game has bugs. None of them game breaking. The npc T-posing and vehicles spawn out of nowhere bugs from the early days are gone. 

Mods:
There are so many mods, you don't need any of them to make the game playable, but there are some very good mods that can cater to the kind of experience you prefer in cyberpunk, and make the game even more immersive than it already is. I personaly recommend the Nova city mods, make the lighting in the game much more realistic and in turn, makes NC's different districts looks even more distinct than it already is.

This was an amazing experience, I wish I forgot the story, so I can feel the same feelings i had the first time playing it. absolute tear-jerker. even though there were some bugs, I had an overall great time playing this game.
Great story, great characters, fun and lots of options for gameplay and combat. I highly recommend.

Cyerpunk had a rough start, as we all know. It released as a shell of empty promises and ambitions that the developers had for the game but couldn't or wouldn't be able to implement in time for release.

CDPR redeemed themselves over the years by fixing this game, and righting the ship. Right now, it is a masterpiece, with an incredibly good story and realized near future dystopian world that is straight out of the genre bests like Blade Runner, The Matrix and Akira. It wears it's influences on it's sleeve but it stands on it's own.

I truly think it might be CDPR's best game now, even after the rocky start. Phantom Liberty injected such life into this game, as well as the 2.0 (and subsequent) updates that overhauled the game systems, RPG elements and progression to be just flat out better. 

The best thing about this game is the story has meaningful choices to make. It has a somewhat open-ended world but a strong, character driven narrative that doesn't pull it's punches. There are consequences to your actions and several endings that reflect that, and your relationships with certain characters can definitely change depending on what you decide to do. I love this and I wish more games had meaningful story moments like this.

Gameplay has been so much improved from it's release that it doesn't even resemble it's original build. Everything is just so much more fun and streamlined (for the better) now in the latest updates that I feel like different builds and playstyles really stand out. 

I highly recommend it to everyone, except I strongly suggest you have a decent computer to run this. This game is playable on older hardware but you're doing yourself a disservice by not being able to use Ray Tracing and some newer gen tech (like Frame Generation) to take advantage of how great this game can look and play. I upgraded in the middle of my third playthrough and was blown away at what I was missing out on.

A supreme achievement in the land of gaming. 
This game does not revolutionize story-writing, gameplay, cinematography, open-world, RPG systems, and many other elements it contains, but it certainly excels in each one of them, providing a product of life-changing quality. Its story is amongst the best ever written, in general. 
The game is not without flaws, as nothing is, but they're so minor, they turn bleak when compared with everything else that's being presented on the table. Yes, the police system is still a bit shallow, yes occasional bugs still appear, although the game has been fixed in a major scale; yes you still cannot romance Takemura, but all of that falls apart under the weight of its positives. 
There is only a small number of games that deserve such high praises, but Cyberpunk 2077 will surely stand the test of time as one of them. One could say - Cyberpunk will [i] [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AN1RJF55NXI&list=RDAN1RJF55NXI&start_radio=1] Never Fade Away. [/url] [/i]

I finally caved and bought Cyberpunk 2077 about a month ago. I'd been avoiding it since the 2020 launch disaster, but choom... I regret waiting this long.Night City is straight-up intoxicating. I started as a streetkid netrunner, and I'm already 42 hours deep with no signs of stopping. The main story hooked me hard—Johnny Silverhand in my head is equal parts annoying and iconic (Keanu Reeves kills it), and the Heist mission had my heart pounding. But the real magic? The side content. Every gig feels like its own little cyberpunk short story. The Panam quests out in the Badlands are peak—riding with the Aldecaldos, that sunset convoy scene? Chef's kiss. Judy's storyline hit me in the feels too; CDPR really knows how to write romance that doesn't feel forced.Gameplay is addictive as hell. Quickhacking enemies from across the street while chugging a NiCola is god-tier fun. Swapped to a gorilla arms/monowire build for a bit and now I'm ripping doors off cars and slicing through gangs like butter. Driving finally feels good (thank you, patches), and the gunplay has serious weight. Graphics on my RTX 3080 with path tracing? Night City's rain-soaked streets look unreal—neon reflections everywhere, crowds that actually feel alive.Phantom Liberty is next on my list—heard Dogtown and Idris Elba are worth it alone. Only complaint so far: I wish there were more apartment customization options, but that's minor.If you're still sleeping on this in 2025, wake up. It's not just "fixed"—it's one of the best open-world RPGs out there now. Zero regrets.10/10 so far

I’ve been watching Cyberpunk 2077 from a distance for nearly five years, following its patches and improvements without playing it. In 2025, I’m finally jumping in so this review reflects the game as it exists today, not the problems at launch.

At its best, Cyberpunk 2077 shines in its hand-crafted spaces and curated missions. Clubs, bars, and districts like Japantown or Corpo Plaza feel dense, intentional, and visually exceptional. When the game narrows its focus to authored content, it works extremely well.

Where it still struggles is the open world. Traversal is slow and unrewarding, vehicle handling is painful, and the game compensates by flooding the map with fast-travel points which is a clear admission that moving through Night City isn’t very fun. The streets between major locations often feel like filler rather than meaningful gameplay space.

Random encounters like NCPD alerts, cyberpsycho sightings, and gang activity all lack depth and consequence. Over time, they blur together, encouraging a blunt “kill-on-sight” playstyle rather than supporting role-playing. 

That said, the game is absolutely still worth playing and buying. I’ve been borderline obsessed with it for the last two weeks, which hasn’t happened to me with a game in a long time. The cyberpunk aesthetic, lore, and curiosity about Night City carried me deep into the experience. The game also works surprisingly well as a “turn your brain off and go loud” RPG. I’ve been playing my character like a full cyberpsycho no stealth, killing everyone on sight and it feels oddly aligned with how the game is designed.

I can easily see myself replaying it later with a stealth-focused build to explore a different side of the systems. Even with its flaws, Cyberpunk 2077 in 2025 is a compelling, addictive game especially if the world and genre already speak to you.

Completing Cyberpunk was a powerful experience. I want to share my thoughts while the emotions are still fresh.
First of all, Night City is not just a set; it’s a living organism. And the characters make it live. Jackie Wells has become a real bro for me. His attachment to his mother and sincere love for Misty make his image human and worldly. His vitality, ambition and sincerity caught on without trying to appear as someone else. His loss is felt acutely, not just the death of a loyal friend, but the loss of a sense of security. The city suddenly becomes empty when the only person who believed in you without any hidden motives disappears.

Special thanks to the developers for Judy. Stunningly written character with a solid character, behind whose external harshness hides an aching soul. Her strong independence and anarchist spirit combine with an inability to cope with emotional problems and a tendency towards self-destruction. Despair, sabotage and emotional problems seem very real, not just a perfect option of romance, which makes her journey more impressive. Great empathy caused the similarity of this character with me, forcing to engage in self-analysis. Not just an admiration for the character, but a chance to better understand yourself. It serves as a kind of mirror reflecting my inner conflicts, fears and desires. It shows that you can be both strong and vulnerable, idealistic and realistic, that you can fight injustice while seeking inner peace. Her story is a reminder that even in the darkest world you can find light and hope, and it’s normal to open, even if it’s scary.

The ending of Arasaka is remembered for a long time, dark and psychologically difficult. In exchange for the promise of life you give up your freedom and dignity. In this ending you understand that for Arasaka you are not a hero or even an ally, but a valuable asset or just a lab rat. Friends from a past life either distance themselves, or look at you with pity.
The space station scene where V endlessly solving the Rubik’s Cube is a brilliant way to convey mental decay. You repeat it again and again, but it does not bring satisfaction. It is a symbol that the V's mind is damaged, and Arasaka simply calibrates the remnants of your personality. When V in rage or despair disassembles the cube and finds a red devil inside, this is the moment of truth. It’s the realization that there is nothing human inside you anymore, only corporate code. You survived, but the price of this life was so high that life itself lost its meaning.

One of the drawbacks for me is the lack of a canonical end. I appreciate when there is a clear conclusion in the narrative, where everything is wrapped up and understood. Not when you have the option to select a favorable outcome for yourself. It's preferable to have one clear conclusion. Even if it leads to disappointment.

I've played Cyberpunk on it's initial release back in 2020. And even though I did not have that much performance issues, I had a lot of expectations that weren't met. So back then I would rate it 7/10. Decent game, nice world, but with a lot of unfulfilled potential. 

Now, 5 years later, and with the Phantom Liberty DLC, I thought: let's give it another go. Did not regret. I can't describe how pristine and alive this world feels. It's immersive, the story is good, just doing your own thing in Night City feels good, naturally even, and there's so much to do that does not feel like a grind or repetitive at all. 

It's insane to me to see how much has changed for the better. CD Projekt Red, I take my hat off. Game's a 10/10 without question now.

Cyberpunk 2077 is the kind of game that boots up and immediately asks: “What if capitalism, chrome, and bad decisions had a really good soundtrack?”

Why It’s Actually Incredible Now:
Night City is one of the most immersive open worlds ever made. It feels alive, loud, dirty, and dangerous.
The story hits hard. Characters are memorable, messy, and painfully human.
Combat is flexible: guns, hacking, blades, stealth, or full cyber-psycho blender mode.
The game looks insane. Like “stop and stare at puddles” insane.

Things You Should Know Before Plugging In:
This is a story-first RPG. If you skip dialogue, you’re missing the best part.
Builds matter. Random perks = sad V. Plan ahead.
Driving is better than launch but still… let’s say “stylish chaos.”
Bugs are mostly gone, but Night City still believes in character.

Pro Tips for New Runners:
Don’t rush the main story. Side quests are where the soul lives.
Read shards and messages — the worldbuilding is hidden everywhere.
Invest in cyberware early. Flesh is temporary, chrome is forever.

Emotional damage is unavoidable. Save often.

Final Verdict:
Cyberpunk 2077 went from cautionary tale to redemption arc done right. It’s immersive, stylish, emotional, and genuinely memorable. Not perfect — but bold, ambitious, and finally delivering on its promise.

You won’t just beat this game.
