The coolest videogame city. I sometimes wish I lived in Night City. I played this in 2024, 4 years after release, and only remember a bug in the prologue where npcs were stuck t-posing in a cutscene montage. Hopefully this game served as a lesson to CDPR. Surely they made serious internal changes to their marketing team because what it is now is a great game in its own right, thanks to the developers who had to clean up their mess (also shoutout to Mike Pondsmith).

The combat is the most fun I've had in a long time. Enemy camps offer versatility (long sightlines for sniping, hacking opportunities, secret stealth routes) and I often changed combat methods during fights. The grind for clearing out locations did not feel tedious at all. The rpg elements include character creation and combat playstyle. The only choices you make are how you want to deal side quests and the ending for the main story. Another thing is, the game has an awkward rhythm since the prologue is lengthy and the main questline is very short comparatively.

I'm not always invested in videogame plots, but V's story ended up working for me emotionally. There are also a handful of memorable side quests where the stories fit perfectly in the bleak cyberpunk setting, my favorite being Sinnerman. The DLC doubles down and gives an even more bitter story with Songbird and Reed.

As for negatives, I would've liked having some more compelling side characters (Misty and Panem were all I cared about in the main game). Keanu's voice acting was ok, Grimes should not have been allowed to voice anything. There are a bunch of megacorps established the Cyberpunk 2077 universe but this game mainly features only one, Arasaka. There was a side quest that seemed like it was starting a plotline dealing with another megacorp called Militech but it went nowhere, which was disappointing.

 If they had advertised this as the mostly-linear immersive action adventure game it is, Cyberpunk 2077's memory would have been far better than what it is currently known for.
Its a good Game. A few stalls. Interesting story line.

⭐ 9/10 – I Came for the Cyberware, Stayed for the Chaos ⭐

Cyberpunk 2077 is a neon-soaked, morally ambiguous playground where you can customize your implants, drive ridiculously fast cars, and somehow survive a city that seems determined to kill you in at least three creative ways per minute.

The world of Night City is breathtaking — dense, vibrant, and packed with stories waiting to unfold. The characters are memorable, the quests are often hilarious or heartbreaking, and the main story is engaging enough to make you care about a bunch of people who are probably going to get cybered anyway.

Combat is slick, hacking feels satisfying, and the driving physics are… well, let’s say fun in a destructive way. The bugs exist, sure, but sometimes they’re so ridiculous you can’t help but laugh — like when a NPC phases through a wall while screaming existentially. Classic Cyberpunk.

If you enjoy open-world RPGs, absurd cybernetic enhancements, and a city that refuses to play nice, Cyberpunk 2077 delivers a wild, unforgettable experience.

Highly recommended. Upgrade everything, survive the chaos, and maybe don’t anger the mechs.

"Night City always wins"

That's what I was told before starting this game for the first time. I didn't think much of it but after advancing through the main story I began to understand what this actually means. Sure you can be the main character, a legend of the Afterlife, Corpo scum or just a regular guy trying to stay alive but no matter what you do, this city will put you to your knees in the end. 

Cyberpunk 2077 is much more than just a game, it is something that you can be part of. You can be stranded in the middle of the badlands with no human in sight but then you spot a car off the road and decide to look what has happened, upon arrival you see a NCPD officer covering up his tracks after killing someone they weren't meant to off. Upon getting too close you get shot and have to make a decision. It's you or them! After helping yourself with staying alive you can uncover the whole situation. The officer just wanted to feed her family and the payout for the gig was too good to pass on. You look down on the ground, her lifeless body right infront of you and you start to realize that this city doesn't need you. It breathes and goes on no matter if you're there or not.

I just can't help myself getting immersed in these kind of situations. Daily biz that shows you the dreadful reality of your life in this city. Barganing with someone you are meant to flatline just for them to tell you that they were screwed over by some corpos and it's not their fault, really let's you think about what you're doing.
In other games i just get the quest, fulfill the requests, maybe listen to the dialouge as to why this was sooo important to the quest giver and then move on.
In Cyberpunk 2077 I indulge in the jobs and gigs given to me. Letting a fixer only have a few gigs available and unlocking more once you earned their trust and proven your worth really lets you feel like you have a connection to the other characters, They aren't just NPCs, they are your Employer, your fellow merc and sometimes your choom.

Never have I ever felt so much about an NPC dying as I did in this game. It felt real in a way. You learned so much about them over the course of the story that it really hits you when they are suddenly gone and you can see the pain in their buddies faces. The first time I finished an ending and the credits rolled I just sat there and thought about everything that had just happened. For the first time in a game I intentionally let the credits finish rolling and didn't even try to skip them. The calls of all your chooms and fixers, after you completed the main quest hit right where they need to and I started to really feel sorry for all of them. Because no matter what fun you had with them, no matter how close your were and how deeply you cared about them, in the end "Night City always wins"

This is not supposed to be a review, it is a love letter to the creators and the characters in the story they created. With almost 300 hours on a single save i have yet to experience everything this game has to offer and i'm looking forward to the sudden thought of wanting to indulge in this world again.

It was a preem experience and no matter what Night city throws at you, I always strive to be a Legend again!

I waited years to write this review: Cyberpunk 2077 is my favorite game of all time.

I rode in on day 1 with very little issues, and I did not try to crank it too high on my old 980ti. I play with a 4070ti now, and a 3070ti laptop, and this game still WOWs me. I love this game: the story, the characters, the fun, the love the devs put in all of the updates, the graphics, the music, just all of it. ALL OF IT. To me, this game is a 9.9 and truly, I hope someday a game will beat it for the top spot in my heart. It would be a perfect 10, but... it needs a better character creation without mods to make it better. Like, complete body and face sculpting to perfect your desired look. I know what I am asking, and its a BIG task, but that is why this only take 0.1 from the score. PLAY THIS GAME.

TLDR; I picked the game up on sale for $20. I could have spent that on a loaded Chipotle burrito and produced a more satisfying pile of shit. 

Once you get past the unique backstory prologue (which takes just enough time to pass the refund threshold, for some crazy reason /s) the writing becomes boring, predictable, and weak. There are no stakes to the game at all, they gloss over/montage away the only interesting part of the story (getting a foothold as a Merc after your prologue), and then there is a huge cast of random people calling you constantly that you supposedly met and formed tight bonds with in the part THEY SKIPPED. All of the expository parts of the story are all tell, and no show, with only one real visceral moment at the end of the first heist. However that moment is fully robbed of any and all interest and stakes, because you literally have never met or heard of the people involved until the 5 minutes before things actually happen. 

And then there is the completely false promise of "impactful decisions that ripple into the fabric of the story". There are approximately three choices you make that actually change anything about the story, and one of them is what gender you make your protagonist (spoiler alert: it just changes which two people you can romance. That's right. 4 options, and two are blocked dependent on what body type you pick). 

"You have two weeks to live!" - you can sleep for months of in-game time and nothing bad happens. 

"You are an integral part of this power struggle!" - All of the people involved in the power struggle, even those that die by your hand, would have everything that happened to them, happen, regardless of if you are there. 

No stakes. No interest. No impact. No advocacy. Not a worthwhile story.

The combat is mid at best, boring at worst. Character customization does almost nothing impactful for combat aside from unlocking movement options that are unreliable and repetitive. Particularly good at headshots? Too bad, they straight up barely matter because... ummm, pain inhibitors? Combat is trying to give power fantasy while also offering little more for difficulty scaling than increasing hp pools and damage mitigation like this is 2008 WoW. Out of combat, talent builds are more or less just for finding shortcuts in missions and side jobs that are gated behind 'tech ability X/20' and similar random skill gates. 

Dialog is frustrating as well. The game prides itself on not having many cutscenes after the initial exposition montage, but that means that the flow of conversation and dialog is chopped and screwed depending on if your character model is standing the right distance away and facing the correct direction from the NPCs that are supposed to talk next. You are constantly waiting on NPCs to start saying their next line so you can proceed with walking slowly behind them from one location to the next, so you can turn around and go back to where the conversation started so you can actually start the mission. The dialog itself is littered with the jargon of the source material, which is easy enough to pick up as you play, but it feels more forced than natural, and does nothing to try to ease the player into it. I've played for almost 60 hours, and I could not tell you the difference between 'Choom' and 'Gonk' if you put a comically large gun to my head. 

And then there's the launcher. Why. Why. WHY does every single game demand a developer-controlled launcher that does nothing but advertise DLC and other products that, if I am going to buy them, I will get from Steam anyway? Just frustrating. You know what everyone loves about GTA? Not the launcher. 

I have scoured this game for redeeming qualities. I am still working on finishing all side quests and gigs searching for anything to make me feel like I didn't waste cash on this lauded game. But frankly if I could go back in time and stop myself from buying this game, I would tell myself the truth: Cyberpunk 2077 is just Watch Dogs (2014) with a layer of spackle and ray tracing on it. 

Don't bother.

I feel it has to be said - the game ‘Cyberpunk 2077’ is this era’s very own ‘The Wire’.
I realise this may seem a strange thing to say at first, as ‘The Wire’ was a different medium, a television series, set in the real world, at the same approximate dates as it was made, while Cyberpunk 2077 is a CRPG set, not only in a sci-fi future, but an actual parallel timeline to our own.  But this is where the big, important differences stop.
When the HBO television series ‘The Wire’ came out, it blew audiences away with the depth, scope, breadth, and sheer profoundness, in storytelling, quality of acting, use of the tools of the medium, and, if that wasn’t enough, people’s very perceptions of what the limits of the medium used to tell the story were.  The rules of how deep a story could go, how big it could be, how relevant and important to our time and society something made within such a medium could get.
So, when I compare it to Cyberpunk 2077 on those criteria, I cannot find two examples closer.  This game took the very concept of a story told via computerised gameplay, and utterly revolutionised how deep, important, and relevant to our current social issues that story could be.  It blew players, including myself away, as we found ourselves submerged in a world so utterly real and compelling, with such complex characters, deep, rabbithole subplots, perfect voice acting, and mind-blowing atmosphere, that there was no way of leaving that place the same as when we went in.  And it did so with the kind of brilliant, intelligent, and engaging gameplay that perfectly completes anything achieved in this medium.
If you haven’t tried this game, whether you’re interested in the medium as a whole or not, you should play this game.  It is too important to miss.
Tell your friends, tell your neighbours, tell your family, tell your Gran, who constantly complains about ‘young people’ and ‘violent video games’ and ‘millenials being a problem’ for whatever reason.  Whoever misses this game is missing the most profound commentary on our society out there.

Its a game that oscillates between gorgeously rendered environments and cars clipping through the ground, between well written quests and broken triggers, between likable characters and a half dozen cigarettes floating around Keanu Reeve's face. Its the very definition of a mixed bag and despite the various issues surrounding its launch I think that, foundationally, Cyberpunk is a pretty solid game.

Cyberpunk 2077... Where do I even start?

The characters, the music, and especially Johnny Silverhand give the game this raw energy that makes you want to do something creative yourself. It’s the kind of game that makes you want to pick up a guitar, turn the amp up, and just play. It’s not perfect, but it doesn’t need to be... pure, exciting, and fucking preem is how I'd describe it.

242 hours on a single playthrough over a few months. This game grabbed ahold of me, hard. Amazing story (stories tbh, many of them), the most immersive world I've ever seen with great design on all levels, fun mechanics, soundtrack is fantastic, and just so drop dead gorgeous. I don't think I've ever cried this much to a game before, and there was plenty of goof too. Perfect? No, it's an open world game. They're never perfect. There are bugs here and there, but the mess I heard about at launch is nowhere to be seen.

It's an awful, awful city, but I could still see myself moving in to several places there. The Kabuki Roundabout and the market nearby I found especially appealing, but there's also Little China and Japantown. They just felt so alive and homely somehow. Northside, Charter Hill, and Rancho Coronado gave me bad vibes. But overall, I completely fell in love, with the places, the people, the atmosphere... and with all the anguish that entailed. It really managed to put a lot of real life things into perpective. So yeah, this gave changed me.

If you still have any doubts then I don't know what to tell you. Just play the game, you gonk!

Without mods, they've done great. Story and world building are solid, characters are interesting, gameplay is well developed for all playstyles. There's an insane amount to do for completionists and most of it doesn't feel too tedious. For second playthroughs the act 1 skip makes good choices and sets you up well. Wish they had more than just one character reset but that's really negligeable. Romance options in the vanilla game are also kinda bland with Panam being the only sane choice. With mods this is one of the best powerfantasies on market. Become a cyberninja, chromejock, or netrunning god. Enjoy extra gigs and streets of chaos. Play a visually fantastic first person experience however you like. The community is great and a good portion of the collections on nexus are pretty thoroughly tested for something that's free. When it says easy install they mean it.

It took me quite a while to finally get into Cyberpunk. Friends who played spoke very highly of this game and so I decided to finally try it out after all the updates and fixes.

I have to say CDPR has done a great job with it. Can't speak about all the issues when it was released but current state of the game is great. 

Story is quite cool. Side missions and gigs are fun to do. Yes, it does get a bit repetative at some point but I feel like all big open world games get there at some point.

I would definitely suggest it. Especially since you can get it with a good discount quite often.

A Grand Theft Auto, Blade Runner, DeusEx, The Matrix, Ghost in the Shell, Shadow Warrior, mashup; that's the feeling I have while playing Cyberpunk.  It's futuristic nature and grand scale add to the allure.  With all the shiny glitz and pomp the story and music really drive the addiction for me.  The arc, takes you where you've never been, introduces you to people who become as close to family as you can have in a game, and all that, pulls you in and won't let go.  

The skill tree is unique.  It's the way in the game to build your character meaningfully and level up.  The interesting aspect of it is, you can't balance across all skills, you have to focus on specifics.  That makes all the difference.  Handguns in this game are wild, but paired with your own cyber implants, it goes wild.  Smart weapons are fun, hacking them is funner!  

Night City is vast.  It's fun to explore.  While exploring, the radio creates an ambiance that's almost soothing.  I rarely find myself fast traveling anywhere as a result.

This game has been reviewed many many times, so it's impossible to add anything unique here.  I will say however, whether this game intentionally did this or not, it instills a sense of loneliness.  Everywhere you go in the game, you're surrounded by people but usually alone.  When you connect with another in the story-line, they always leave or die.  Again, I don't know if this was intentional, but it's a feeling that follows you everywhere in the game, and it adds weight to everything you do, every decision you make, and every happy, or otherwise, event.

This game still has bugs, and they are often noticeable, but for all it's flaws, after having played for some time, I personally feel as though this has created an entirely new genre of game-play that will be mimicked for many years to come.

My Love for Cyberpunk 2077

Cyberpunk 2077 is more than just a game to me; it is an experience that pulls me into a world full of emotion, chaos, and freedom. From the first moment I entered Night City, I felt connected to its atmosphere, characters, and story. The neon lights, futuristic technology, and deep choices make the game feel alive and unforgettable.

What makes Cyberpunk 2077 even more special is how it brings my friends and me together. My friends Cr0w, Smokey, and Tokyo all loved the game as much as I did. We spent hours talking about the storyline, our different choices, and our favorite characters. Each of us experienced the game in a unique way, yet we all shared the same excitement and passion for Night City.

The game also taught me how powerful storytelling in video games can be. Every mission feels meaningful, and the choices you make shape who you become in the game. Playing Cyberpunk 2077 with my friends made the experience even better, turning it into something we all remember and enjoy together.

In the end, Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game I love—it’s a world I shared with my friends, and that’s what makes it truly special.

Came a long way from when it originally launched, the main story is relatively shorter than expected, but it definetly makes it up with the open-world and side content available. The rest of the gameplay feel like a cyberpunk-esk version of GTA V but with more emphasis on RPG elements.

Cyberpunk is the first game where I want to stop at every POI, do every bounty, side gig or mission. Every second of this game is peak gaming.

Been wanting to play this game for very long time. Now I'm a working man, I now got to buy and play it and it did not disappoint. Sure there is still remnants of the bug when it was first launched back then but it's very rare and it's not game breaking anyway, in fact got a laugh out of me.

It feels like everything that can be said about Cyberpunk 2077 has already been said - but in a way, that’s exactly the point. The fact that people are still talking about it 5 years later is proof that it has earned its place as a modern classic.

Despite its rocky launch, occasional writing inconsistencies, and a main story that can at times feel more linear than expected for an RPG, the care the development team has put into the game and the addition of Phantom Liberty has helped solidify the game as a genuinely great experience, offering fun and flexible gameplay, a wide range of viable builds, a gripping narrative, memorable characters you grow attached to, and an outstanding voice acting cast that truly brings the world to life.

And this is without even addressing the game's world's level of immersion, or the strength of its art direction and visual presentation.
epic masterpiece. I typically dislike city exploration and night time in RPGs, not here: strolling in NC was a bliss each and every minute. also V being one hell of a woman. superb!

The story line with Panam will always rest in my mind and remind me that even in the grim experience of a dystopian technological future there's always going to be people living outside of the system and refusing it at every turn for the sake of self agency. That gives me hope.

It has a long story but I could never get enough. I just finished my first playthrough and I know I got many more to come. I can not recommend a game more then Cyberpunk 2077.

Tried to play this a while ago on a far worse PC, it didn't run so well and still seemed to have a lot of bugs that were frustrating enough to deal with that it made me drop it entirely for several years.

Since giving it another shot recently though I had a far better time with it. I hardly experienced any bugs during my entire playthrough and got way more immersed in the world than I expected to. It still isn't perfect and in my opinion has a few areas that could be improved (many of which they thankfully did address and improve upon significantly in the DLC) but I do think the game in it's current state is well worth the time if you're interested in it, especially if you include the DLC.

Visually stunning with possibilities to parkour around the city.

The game does not let you change your build more than once so it also limits fun when you get bored of your build.
Lots of characters feel flat. Lots of story lines felt unpolished or butchered in production.
Lots of side quest are locked to the progress of other side/main quests and sometimes you have to wait for hours until the quest becomes active again or you just miss the trigger that you cannot possibly know about and essentially waste a lots of time to be left on a cliffhanger.
Poor pacing, poor scaling, questionable writing, absolutely terrible launch.

Cyberpunk 2077 is wild! Night City feels huge and full of life, with something exciting happening everywhere you look. The gameplay is really fun, whether you’re hacking, fighting, sneaking around, or crafting. The story choices like Corpo, Nomad, or Street Kid actually make a difference and keep each playthrough fresh. The side quests are just as great as the main story, and there are tons of cool details in the world. Honestly, this is the best game I’ve played. I keep coming back to it again and again.

At first I hated it and uninstalled it before finishing it. I tried a second time and hated it again. Then Cyberpunk became what it is today and entered my top 3 favorite games of all time.

The graphics are simply unreachable for any other game—light-years ahead, especially if you use mods. Nothing comes close.

The city is breathtaking, and even after hundreds of hours I’m still discovering locked doors and secret places I’ve never seen before.

It’s true the game isn’t perfect (perfection doesn’t exist), but thanks to the enthusiasm of a huge modding community, if you’re patient you’ll find the mods that fit you, making your Cyberpunk experience unique and personal.

If the game is still so popular and so heavily modded, it’s because of how the developers turned around a product that launched in a disastrous state and made it the masterpiece it is now.

Night City doesn’t welcome you.
It tolerates you — briefly.

You arrive as V, thinking you’ll make it big.
Money, chrome, reputation.
Night City hears that and immediately schedules your emotional collapse.

Every street is neon, every alley is danger, and every NPC looks like they know something you don’t.
The city breathes, glitches, lies, and somehow still feels alive enough to judge you.

Then there’s Judy.
Quiet, emotional, and carrying more unresolved feelings than the entire city combined.
Her story isn’t loud — it just sits with you, heavy, reminding you that Night City doesn’t just break bodies, it breaks hearts too.

Combat is chaos with style.
Guns blazing, hacks flying, mantis blades out — all while your minimap politely suggests routes you will absolutely ignore.
When things go wrong, they go wrong fast… and usually in slow motion.

And of course, Johnny Silverhand.
A walking midlife crisis with a guitar and too many opinions.
He lives in your head, insults your choices, and somehow becomes the most honest voice in the room.

The story isn’t about saving the world.
It’s about surviving it — long enough to decide who you actually are in a city that wants you replaceable.

• Installed chrome → Lost a piece of myself.
• Trusted Night City → Night City laughed.
• Still chasing legends → Because quitting isn’t an option here.

Cyberpunk 2077 is style + identity + emotional damage.
If you love this game… congratulations, Night City already owns a part of you.

Cyberpunk 2077 was a game I dismissed at launch. Overwhelming negative reports, all the videos of the  bugs and glitches. so I never touched it, until I caved and watched Edgerunners (well over a year after the anime aired) which reignited my curiosity, and when I finally stepped into the game, I was stunned by how much it had evolved, and how much it wasn't all the negative things I thought it'd be. What once seemed like a cautionary tale of hype now felt like a living, breathing world transforming it from something I ignored into one of my most cherished gaming experiences.

I attempted to play this game years ago, but they seemed to have fixed all the large glaring bugs. I'm not done with a full playthrough yet but I do recommend this game for people who like FPS and RPG hybrid games. I'd say it's more of an FPS than Fallout.

This isn't like The Division or something where you can't take on high level enemies just because they are high level. Sure, you can't take on a gang of upper level enemies but one or two you'll be ok against even at lower levels. That said, you will die quite a bit early on if you are a rush in and start brawling type like my character is.  However, know what type of build you are going for before starting the game. 

I'll update my review when I've completed the game.

Not really my game. There was so much hype for this game, and the graphics [i]do[/i] look stunning, but the story is not really that interesting in my opinion. I appreciate the effort being put into giving cut-scenes more choices by allowing you to select the response to something another character says, but at the end it feels like whatever choice you made didn't really lead to a different outcome.

Sometimes I just want to sit back and enjoy the cut-scene.

I can't really describe it, but somehow, even though you are doing [i]more[/i] yourself in a cutscene, it feels very like a scripted scene. The game [i]wants[/i] you to walk to somewhere, only to get more dialog. It's like the game is telling you step by step how to progress, instead of treating you with a cinematic masterpiece that is a cutscene.

Obviously one of the best games ever made.

While Cyberpunk 2077 came out in a half-baked rush state, it's undeniably a fairly polished game now and definitely worth your time if not for one playthrough. Before the long form review, I'll say I've played both the main game and Phantom Liberty twice, of those I played 2/3 lifepaths; however I still have yet to complete all endings, all sidequests, and the nomad lifepath. This means that there's still a lot of side content I never finished due to burnout with the game.

So the long review? Cyberpunk 2077 is a flawed but good game that takes the hallmarks of games like GTA and attempts to put a coat of Cyberpunk paint on it, while this does mean the gameplay is fairly strong and CDPR's standard build/playstyle flexibility exists, gameplay can get stale fast in longer sessions; however this is generally made up for by great voice-acting, good to excellent environmental storytelling, and a semi-compelling main narrative. Overall I had fun with my time but definitely not a game that's endlessly replayable or repeatable. 8.5/10

*FYI Mac users, Mac port runs great barring a few bugs here and there, if you haven't already, definitely pick this one up on sale.
Masterpiece, just a few years too late. Kudos to the CDPR devs to getting it in the state it is right now. Now just don't repeat this mistake for Cyberpunk 2.

It’s the end of 2025. Most of my friends played this game by this point, and all of them sung serenades for it. “The DLC just made this game goated.” And so, I thought it’s finally time for me to give it a try. Here are my thoughts…

The game is beautiful. The city is finally living and breathing, and works mostly like clockwork. By the point I got to the DLC though, I started experiencing some major stuttering when many NPCs were present on screen, but I’m happy to write this off as suboptimal hardware. Interestingly, the stutters continued even outside of the DLC area, where they previously didn’t occur — not sure why this is. Otherwise, I had just 2–3 crashes over the playthrough. Considering how disastrous the technical state was at launch — a massive improvement. Other impressive things include: the ambience, atmosphere, sound design, environment, and everything else having to do with the world. Outstanding.

Story — wouldn’t call it amazing 10/10 content, but it’s solid enough. What’s noteworthy is that the overarching narrative didn’t stand out nearly as much as some little moments and details, either in main or side missions. These really shined through (e.g. Kerry’s reaction to you playing guitar at his house — my God, that was so cool). This is what really helped with immersion and with keeping my interest — even if I didn’t care much about the story at times, I was still curious about certain interactions characters might have with each other.

Speaking of characters — the writing is, again, mostly solid. 
For me there was a caveat — I didn’t really manage to connect with the majority of them. I did say I enjoyed interactions between characters, but I don't mean the characters themselves. That is with exception of Jackie, having started as Corpo, Reed, and, surprisingly, Brendan (what the hell right?). Many of the characters I didn't hate, but that's not a great achievement. Johnny especially — I was mostly annoyed with him at all stages of the game, which sucks, because he’s the foremost character. The legendary Johnny Silverhand, no more than an angsty teenager. Songbird likewise — the game kept telling me I should care for her... but I just failed to. Judy's quest I straight up skipped — the point of her character flew over my head entirely. Think I maybe understand what the writers were going for: it’s supposed to be a city where everyone’s out for themselves, so you aren’t necessarily meant to like most of the people in it. It’s similar to the show Euphoria in this sense (although on a lesser scale), and there, this point is also by design. If so, I can live with this, even if it's not my cup of tea.

Keep in mind — THIS (all the above) is what you are going to be playing the game for. It’s not GTA, it’s not Skyrim/Fallout, or any of the other AAA RPGs. More notes on why I found it so — below.

Gameplay — I haven’t played with the “magic” system, which I heard was fun, but still — on normal difficulty you are literally just cruising through everything. I’d suggest playing on harder difficulty, but there isn’t an enemy variety to speak of to justify making them bullet sponges. If you’re satisfied with the combat, then maybe that’s OK; personally, I wasn’t entirely.

Here comes the sad part — I really thought that, as my friends suggested, post-DLC, all or most of the initially promised features/fixes would be added. No. From minor things like wall-running, which still isn’t there, to major stuff like police AI still being dumb as hell, driving sucking ass, plentiful and engaging side content like in Witcher 3 being sadly absent, to name a few. For the latter point here, I mean specifically quests such as the meditating monk (either single mission or very short questlines) — there weren’t many such quests, and most of them were a chore to complete. Gigs I also found less entertaining than contracts in the Witcher. I have to stress that this isn't just me being salty about the broken promises. These genuinely felt like core parts of the game were seriously undercooked, even after 5 years of updates.

All of this breaks immersion significantly, but could be forgiven if gameplay and narrative were in tune. Witcher had the same problem, by the way. However, in Witcher it was borderline negligible; here it’s way worse. The game starts, they say you’re on a timer. Mentally, you want to get the important stuff out of the way and then return to side content. Then the game just ends upon completing the final mission — you need to reload a save afterwards. As such, you need to complete every side objective within the span and context of the main story.

So you’re telling me that I have two weeks left to live, and then I can just wait half a year in my room for certain events to take place, finish the story, and then perish at the exact moment it's convenient for the plot?

I have to say that CDPR makes great games, but this is the greatest sin they commit many times — gameplay and narrative just don’t mesh with each other. This also ties into a previous comment — this isn’t a sandbox RPG into which you could/should sink 1000s of hours, The game ends where it ends. However, many design and marketing choices point to it being such. This created an uncomfortable dissonance in my mind as a player.

TLDR:
Didn’t mean for the review to get this long, but I’ll leave it at this: Cyberpunk has its good moments, and it has its bad moments.

To compare it to a movie again (sadly, that’s the best analogy I can muster for now) — if it was a 2-hour-long one, I’d say, “I’m glad I watched it,” and wouldn’t return to it in the future. Here I can say exactly the same thing… but it was 120 hours long.

It’s good, but I don’t think it’s good enough for what it's trying to be.

From Buggy Mess to Absolute Masterpiece

I played through the entire game at launch in 2020. Back then, with all the bugs and awful optimization, the only thing I could really praise was the story - and even that felt hard to appreciate through all the crashes.

Cyberpunk 2077 is now a legit 10/10. After years of patches and polish, this is finally the game we were supposed to get. The story is still incredible - dark, heavy, with choices that actually made me sit and think. The characters feel real and stay with you long after you finish. This is "mature" in the best way - not just edgy violence and sex, but genuinely thoughtful storytelling about life, death, and what it means to be human.

And Phantom Liberty? Absolute banger. Seriously one of the best expansions I've ever played.

I've done 100% completion now. Not a single regret about any hour I spent in Night City. If you skipped this at launch like most people, now's your chance. CDPR really pulled off the comeback.

Highly recommended.

Probably my favorite game of all time. This game is amazing.

For almost 7 years, I waited for this game. My excitement started from the early trailers, gameplay demos, all the way to the iconic trailer with Keanu Reeves. It launched in 2020 in a terrible performance state, which made me hold off on buying it back then. But I was confident that after waiting nearly 5 more years, with countless fixes, updates, and patches, the Cyberpunk 2077 I had been longing for would finally be playable smooth, without major issues, and with minimal bugs.

We start by choosing our life path: Nomad, Streetkid, or Corpo. Honestly, I was curious about all three, but I preferred Nomad because it felt the most unique to me. Then we head to Night City to become a higher class, more intimidating mercenary. As for the story, I have zero complaints. I loved the flow from beginning to end: plenty of plot twists, jokes, and sharp satire woven throughout. The only disappointment was that the three life paths only differ in the prologue. I had hoped for much deeper differences, something that would encourage multiple playthroughs. Still, I absolutely loved the story that puts you in the shoes of a dying mercenary constantly accompanied by Johnny Silverhand. The missions offer multiple approaches usually stealth or direct combat, like most games. What really stands out (classic CDPR strength) is the dialogue feels like a movie. A single conversation can easily last 30–60 minutes, deepening both the story and the Cyberpunk world itself. The portrayal of massive corporations with overwhelming power is excellent make you really feel like an ordinary citizen who can’t possibly stand up to what the corpos control.

The world itself is absolute cinema. Night City feels incredibly real and beautiful. Every detail is there: huge corporations, restaurants, brothels, bars, gangs, prisons, and countless small touches scattered everywhere. Weather cycles are varied and gorgeous, like morning, afternoon, night, rain, thick Blade Runner style fog everything is rendered stunningly.

Unfortunately, activities are limited to main quests and side quests. The good news is there are tons of side quests, and they’re very varied not just “kill this, kill that.” Some are silly, some are heavy on dialogue and uncovering secrets. The main story missions are delivered brilliantly; everything is told in detail and clearly if you pay attention to the conversations. Dialogue choices feel meaningful (though there aren’t tons of them), and they do affect the story. Skipping side content has consequences, including on the endings. What I missed was small, low stakes activities to slow down the pace things like eating at restaurants or doing silly random stuff. Because everything is tied to quests, the pace stays fast the whole time, which can make you tired more easily.

V’s cyberware, weapons, and skill trees are great. I love how detailed the cyberware system is you can build exactly what you want, and it has a huge impact on both combat and stealth. The skill tree influences gameplay too, though the options for truly changing how you play are somewhat limited. Weapon variety isn’t massive, but the rarity tiers and four main categories give each gun a distinct feel like rifles, SMGs, melee weapons, and ones integrated with your cyberware. Early game combat and stealth felt pretty rough, but once you upgrade, combat becomes extremely satisfying and deadly while still feeling well-balanced against enemies. The only letdown is the stealth takedown animations—they’re bad and there’s basically only one type.

Graphics don’t need much explanation: this is one of the most beautiful games I’ve ever played. The immersive, terrifying future city is depicted gorgeously. From the lavish, neon reflected heart of Night City to districts like Kabuki and Santo Domingo with their own distinct vibes, to the rundown, chaotic outskirts everything is portrayed incredibly well.

Vehicles were awful at launch, driving felt terrible. But once you progress, earn money, and buy proper cars or bikes, driving becomes enjoyable. My only complaint is that navigation would be better with arrows on the road rather than just the minimap it’s hard to drive while constantly glancing up.

Overall, I’m extremely satisfied with Cyberpunk 2077 after waiting 7 years for it. The story, gameplay, world, and atmosphere are all fantastic. I’m glad I waited longer so I could play a mostly fixed version without bugs or major issues, I sank almost 70 hours into it, often playing 4 hours a day and losing track of time. I love all the little details: fast travel via metro, clothing and weapon shops, driving around listening to the radio stations (many songs are original and all of them are great). My only regrets are that the main story feels shorter compared to a heavy narrative game like The Witcher 3, and so much content was clearly cut, things like the nano wire hacking, wall climbing with mantis blades, and many features shown in early demos that never made it to the final game. It really feels like the rushed launch prevented the game from reaching its full potential. Still, I’m not fully satisfied yet. I’m still hungry for more Cyberpunk content, which is why I’m so excited to play the Phantom Liberty DLC.

I’m also currently finishing the prequel anime series, Cyberpunk: Edgerunners.

And I’m already incredibly excited for the sequel, that I hope it brings tons of surprises and all the content they couldn’t include in this one.

This game still has so many bugs from not letting you punch people with your fists, to cars straight up disappearing out of thin air. i enjoyed that game a lot

I played this game at release for about 10 hours and was really disappointed. I uninstalled and never played it again until now. What I just played ends up somewhere on my top 20 all time! I can't believe how good this game ended up being. 

The main quest is good, That's all a main quest needs to do. it doesn't shit the bed and ruin everything else. The side content blew my mind. I couldn't believe how engaged I was in the writing behind a tiny NCPD scanner quest on occasion; quests that would feel like radiant, automatically-generated content in other (lesser) games. Gigs seemed like mini-quests as well and yet they were really well written and I can't think of a single one right now that I didn't like. 

The real stars of this game are: 1.Night City itself and 2. The characters. Graphics are never a primary focus for me, but in this case, they really bring the world to life. This is definitely the best looking game I've ever played. I never skipped a single ride in the passengers seat because I just wanted to look out the window and take in the city. There are games with an art style that I appreciate more, but I'd have to really think about it to give anything more credit than this. 

I have a lot of problems with the game. They just get overshadowed by the things I loved. First and foremost, the atrocious release can never fully be forgiven. We've all heard all of those arguments. I don't need to rehash them here. But it was messed up. I don't feel cheated all these years later anymore, but imagine if I bought it on the previous gen consoles. Next, I think this game is horrible at teaching you how everything works. I think the dialogue is great except when they are trying to be cool. Johnny's dialogue has a lot of stuff that just feels silly. I'm not talking about writing generally, I'm talking about style and syntax here. There's also conceptual complexity in the stories background that leaves me a little bewildered. I didn't enjoy the combat until I got a decent sandestivan (sp?). I wish I could have forgone netrunning earlier and just player with slow-mo start to finish. I loved the cars but I felt like all that effort was kinda wasted by the end of my time with the game. There was not enough to do with your car collection. The last one might be a bit controversial, I felt like Phantom Liberty was a step down in quality for me. The whole James Bond spy thriller thing was great, breathtaking even at times. But it still felt like a modest downgrade with regard to the universal themes, genre tropes, atmosphere of the base game. 

I finished a near complete playthrough. I got all of the endings, all missions (that I know of), all gigs, almost every NCPD scanner blip etc. and it never got old. I am even now sad to uninstall the game. I'm really going to miss this place and these people. I haven't felt that since Fallout: New Vegas. I'm not exaggerating when I say, I'm 100% confidant that I could start the game over right now and play it to completion and my opinions wouldn't change. I'm 150 hours in (lots of AFK has my playtime way higher but the in-game timer says 160). That's mental. 

I love it! I'll definitely come back in a few years. This is something special folks. It really challenges my capacity to stay mad at CDPR. Hmm...still won't buy their next release when it comes out though. They have to do a bit more penance for me.
Only played the street kid story line and I'm hooked.

This game made me wonder why Gaming is not considered to be an art form.

Wanna go around killing people with shotguns? Go ham. Wanna be a stealthy ninja? Go nuts! Wanna chop people into pieces with katanas? Start dicing! Wanna be a wrecking ball with a baseball bat? Go wild!

The build diversity is absolutely insane in this game.

So yeah, gameplay is amazing. Graphics, visuals, audio design, soundtrack, characters, voice acting, plot, storylines etc. etc. All first class.

If you wanna have fun then I just suggest you experiment by yourself. Don't look up guides. Play around with cyberware, try out the guns, figure out a playstyle that you feel fits with your V. Don't rush the main story. Do the gigs, side gigs and whatever else you find. Pickup loot to sell and buy condos, cyberware and cars. Take out cyberpsychos without killing them, or kill them if that's what you feel like doing. I'm not your dad so you can be sloppy if you want to. Just have fun with it!

When Cyberpunk 2077 first launched, it was a disaster. No sugarcoating it.
But today? It’s a completely different game — and honestly one of the best open-world RPG experiences you can play right now.

Night City finally feels alive. The lighting, the reflections, the atmosphere… sometimes I just stop and stare at the world. The soundtrack is insane too — it keeps you in that perfect cyberpunk mood.

✔️ [h1] What I Liked [/h1]

Combat 2.0 is amazing – melee, hacking, guns… every build feels unique.

Perks actually matter now – every point changes how you play.

Incredible story and characters – some missions stay in your head for days.

Much better optimization – runs smoothly on my setup without issues.

❌ [h1] What Could Be Better  [/h1]

Still has some funny bugs here and there — NPCs walking through doors or cars falling from the sky. Night City things.

The police system is improved but still feels a bit teleport-happy.

Endgame can feel a bit empty if you already finished the main and side content.

✔️  [h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]

Cyberpunk 2077 finally became the game it was supposed to be.
If you skipped it before — now is the perfect time.
If you played it at launch — this feels like playing a brand-new game.

[h3]  Highly recommended. Night City awaits.  [/h3] ✨

Absolute masterpiece.  
I had never played a CDProjectRed game before, so have no fanboy memories of the witcher etc etc. 

But Cyberpunk absolutely blew me away with every minute of gameplay.
The world, the combat, the music, the driving, the missions, the sheer amount of content.  

Were there small bugs and glitches? Sure. Did I care? No. Because the rest of the experience genuinely blew my mind so much that I belived for 95% of my playtime - I was a merc in night city. 

I guess one of my biggest 'fears' of this game was my belief that they would use Keanu as a 'star attraction' -  but his character and his story are written so well, that he feels like his own solid identity.

Anyways - If a rich story, great open world with lots of unique missions, stupid amounts of replayability , fantastic voice acting and animations, absolutely sick and FUN to play unique builds interests you, get this game.  After the first five hours, you'll be hooked. 

Thanks to all the dev's who worked on this - Your passion for this game showed in every single minute I lived in Night City.

I beat this game quite a while back and having nearly put 100 hours into this game as of today, I couldn't go without writing my review. 

I'll start by saying this game is great. Before playing this game I saw all of the reviews about the story being out of this world and all that, but if I'm totally honest, the story was very slow for me to get into personally. That's not to say it wasn't great, as I did enjoy it overall. The opening of the game is fantastic but I found myself going in and out of interest throughout. Its VERY dialogue heavy, so if you're someone who doesn't have the time and patience to watch the long cutscenes in between the gameplay, then this game may not be for you. But if you're into story based games and are willing to put the time in, then it is worth it. 

The gameplay is one of the strongest things about this game, but it doesn't hold your hand in main and side missions, which is cool for the most part, as your not tied down to complete them in a specific way and your free to find solutions on your own, most of the time.. This was a breath of fresh air! 

I didn't play the game at its release, so I can only judge it by how its been in recent times, and I will say there are the odd few bugs here and there, but nothing game breaking. 

There's actually SOOO much content in this game, to the point where its mind blowing to be honest.. I don't think there's many games out there that can compete with Cyberpunk in terms of just the sheer amount of content! 

As I said this was a slow burner for me, and I think the main reason for this was the characters and voice acting. I just didn't feel invested in a lot of the characters and found the main character boring as heck, but I decided to stick with it despite this and once I got to the Phantom Liberty DLC, it was almost like something clicked and I was back in. 

One thing I will say that this game nails, is its atmosphere in Night City.. Honestly there's only a few games that can even compare to Cyberpunk in that department.. Its right up there with RDR2 in terms of immersiveness and realism and that's probably the biggest compliment that I can give it!

Overall I did enjoy this game and would recommend it to anyone, although it may not be for everyone. I really hope they decide to do a sequel to this game as I'm with those who say this game is highly underrated. Its clear that a lot of time and effort went into creating this game so it deserves all the praise  that it gets.

In conclusion: If you go into this game expecting it to be this flawless masterpiece from start to finish, then you may be a bit disappointed. But, if you go into it with an open mind, give it some time and just try to enjoy it for what it is, then I do think you'll end up having a great time with this game!

I had heard that the bugs with this game were fixed, but that was not the case for me. Visual glitches where people, objects, and cars clip into each other or suddenly respawn are extremely frequent. Dead bodies are especially glitch-prone, although at least they're sometimes funny. I had one outright freeze requiring a force kill and restart.

The many NPCs roaming the world are very stiff, and their interactions unnatural. This applies to cars driving as well. The world does not feel rich and full of things to find as you explore, it feels hollow. Ultimately it is not immersive and comes off as a mediocre video game, not a living world.

The gameplay is pretty standard fare FPS stuff. Moving around just feels too janky for melee combat to be satisfying, despite their focus on making it a viable strategy. Jumping over things and leaping toward enemies just doesn't work very well. The only interesting thing here is the hacking aspect, which they did do a good job with.

The menus, which you will need to be interacting with all the time, are a pain on controller. They seem to have simply taken the mouse-based menus and done a poor job of adapting them for a controller. Often you'll need to be simply navigating the menu by controlling a virtual mouse pointer with your thumbstick. This was very surprising and disappointing, making good controller-based menus is table stakes for a game this big.

The story is the only interesting thing about this game, but it moves far too slowly. After an awesome intro, it slows to a crawl and gets way more boring, just dangling the promise of something interesting in front of you to keep you going, while drip feeding little hints of what cool thing might be in the future.

All in all, a game that is much too big for its own good. It's spread very thin.

Cyberpunk 2077 is the only game where you buy a $3,000 cybernetic eye just to still miss every shot, crash your car into a vending machine, and get emotionally manipulated by an NPC who looks better than you ever will.

Night City is alive. Too alive. Every pedestrian has a full backstory, a trauma, and a reason to walk directly into your car at 200 km/h.

The graphics? Insane. My GPU aged 5 years in 10 minutes. Ray tracing so realistic I could see my own bad life decisions reflected in puddles.

The story hits hard. One minute you’re saving the city, the next you’re questioning free will, capitalism, and why Keanu Reeves lives rent-free in your brain telling you to commit crimes.

Bugs? Sure. Sometimes NPCs T-pose to assert dominance. Cars spawn inside other cars. But honestly… that just makes it more cyberpunk.

Cyberpunk 2077 isn’t just a game.

Good game with the same issues as The Witcher 3.
Pros:
+ Good main story and side quests (sometimes)
+ Nice voiceover
+ Huge city with a lot of secrets

Cons:
- Inventory is the same mess as in The Witcher 3, hard to find anything, hard to navigate, no persistent filters, no bulk actions
- Battle gameplay is kinda average, in most cases it's just 2-click combat or plain shooter with not a lot of possibilities
- Game physics behaves super weird sometimes, stuff jumps and explodes when you loot something, bodies of enemies lie on walls or in the air, etc.
- Parkour is also totally random; sometimes a character can parkour, sometimes stops, and can't do anything, and it's not fluent in any way.
- Enemies are super aimy, can easily target me moving behind a wall. Also, sometimes they start spamming with grenades (grenades are so not needed and unnecessary in this game IMO). 
- Still a lot of issues 5 years later (enemies in walls, cars spawn upside down, can't loot sometimes)

This isn't a power fantasy. It's not supposed to make you feel like a badass hero who saves the city. If you went in expecting that, you fundamentally misunderstood what the game is trying to do. CP2077 is a 60+ hour meditation on what it feels like to literally lose yourself in a world that was built to grind you into paste.

**Your body is not your own.**

The first-person perspective isn't just a design choice. It's the entire point. You're locked inside V's skull, and from minute one, that body is a problem you're trying to solve. On one hand, you're installing chrome; turning yourself into a modular meat machine, subject to market logic. You're not "upgrading." You're commodifying your own flesh. On the other hand, the Relic is killing you from the inside. Your body is simultaneously a DIY project and a terminal diagnosis. You are, at all times, a dying animal trying to pretend you're a immortal god.

**Night City is not a playground.**

The open world isn't freedom. It's a cage designed to look like freedom. Every icon on that map? That's not content. That's a shift. You're doing gig work. Literally. The game takes the structure of a modern open-world game (all those map markers, all those side hustles) and reveals it for what it actually is: late-capitalist piecework. You are a precarious laborer in a precarious world, and the "choice" you have is which fixer to bleed for today. The constant flood of calls, ads, and notifications aren't immersion-breaking; they're the point. You're never alone. You're always being sold to, called on, managed.

And yet you're not alone in another way, too. You meet people. Judy, Panam, Takemura. You form actual connections. You have conversations in dim apartments and on rooftops at dawn. You fall in love, maybe. You find a community. But here's the trap: those connections can't save you. They can't change the structure. The system doesn't care that you have people who love you. The Relic is still killing you. The gigs still come. The city still runs on your body. You're surrounded by genuine human connection in a world built to atomize and consume you, and that makes the alienation worse, not better. You're lonely *and* not lonely at the same time, and neither state offers escape.

**Johnny Silverhand is the ghost of a dead revolution.**

The Relic isn't just a plot device. It's a hostile takeover of your consciousness by a failed radical. Johnny represents every angry kid who thought you could burn it all down and start over. He tried. He lost. And now he's a tumor in your brain, forcing you to reckon with the fact that all the old ways of fighting back are dead. He's the political unconscious of the setting; the corpse of 20th-century rebellion haunting a 21st-century graveyard. The conflict between V and Johnny isn't a buddy comedy. It's two incompatible ideologies fighting a war on the battlefield of a single, dying brain.

**"Becoming a legend" means destroying yourself.**

The game keeps telling you to become a legend of Night City, and everyone acts like that's the goal. But look at what that actually means. Johnny's a legend. He's dead, and he lost. David Martinez from Edgerunners? Legend. Dead. Legends in Night City aren't people who won. They're people who burned so bright they couldn't be ignored on their way out. The game is offering you a choice between surviving as a nobody or dying as somebody. And here's the kicker: the survival endings feel hollow. The "good" endings are the ones where you go out swinging. This isn't about accumulation or victory. It's about sovereign self-destruction; choosing the terms of your own end in a world that wants to choose them for you.

**The combat system is a lie you tell yourself.**

And here's where it gets really interesting. The gameplay loop lets you become an absolute monster. Sandevistan time-dilation, gorilla arms, mantis blades, reflex tuning; you can build V into a one-person apocalypse. The combat feels incredible. You feel unstoppable. And that is the *point* of the dissonance.

The game lets you feel like a god in a body that's rotting from the inside. Every upgrade, every perk, every piece of chrome makes you better at solving problems that don't matter. You're getting stronger in a system that's already killed you. It's the perfect mirror of consumer culture: here, have this power, this product, this upgrade. Ignore that it changes nothing about the structure that's killing you. The progression system is a coping mechanism. You're playing a power fantasy inside a tragedy, and the tragedy wins.

But then, and this is crucial, the game lets you *use* that power for something that matters. The "blaze of glory" ending is where all that mechanical mastery finally means something. You've spent 60 hours building the perfect killing machine, and now you get to spend it all on one last, doomed, beautiful act of defiance. The gameplay power isn't there to let you win. It's there so you can choose *how* you lose. That's what makes it a legend. Not that you survived. That you got to decide what your death looked like.

Cyberpunk 2077 is not here to make you feel good. It's here to make you feel *something*; specifically, what it's like to be a person in a world that has mechanized, monetized, and moduleized every aspect of existence, including your own body and mind. It's a game about trying to find meaning in a system designed to extract value and then discard you.

Cyberpunk is in another league. This is one of these games we'll all look back on as a major event in the history of gaming. If you are a discerning individual of high taste, this game is preem. I cannot recommend it enough!
- It's like GTA in the near alternate future.
- The level of immersion pushes forward the open world RPG genre. 
- Action was great, many ways to get things done leaving this game have an incredible amount of content in a single release, and the work continues with the expansions, fan mods, etc.
- Visuals are great, not much else to say these days for that. If on PC there's a lot of flexibility as you get up the hardware scale.
- This review is after 2.3, I played the update before and thought it was great too. 
- The story was enjoyable but went by too quickly! Or I wish it was longer, your choice. To new players interested I'd say if you want a really good experience you could spread out finishing all of the main missions and secondary missions.
- I can't emphasize how much this game just grabs hold of you. You'll be speaking in the Night City brainrot in no time. Enjoy every bit!

The word on the street is that the longer you play it the more you will like it. But the more I played this extremely scripted, limited, tedious virtual novel wearing the skin mask of a half-baked Far Cry beta, the more I disliked it. Jack of no trades and master of none. Even at 20 dollars this was too much. People say (rightly) that Ghostwire Tokyo and Starfield are half baked mediocrities, and to a certain extent they are right, but I would happily play them for hours compared to spending one more hour in this tedium simulator. The first does urban exploration better, the second at least lets me explore its bleak dead world without having to be pestered by a phone, endless cutscenes, and nonstop mostly linear dialogue as its core focus. 

If 'Press E to advance conversation' was a game.
More than a game, it's an experience. One which you wish you could relive for the first time again. One of the best games of this century, easily.

Cyberpunk 2077 2025  A masterpiece for the ages.

I really wish there was a way to write informal reviews for games, without having to recommend them or recommend against them. Because that what this game would get from me.

Now, don't get decieved by Steam saying, I'd only have 5 hours in this game, because I don't. I've been playing this game since Version 1.1, if not 1.0, and finished the entire game, including the DLC. In total, I have around 100 hours, most of that on GOG.

But to my opinion on the game. Do I enjoy it? Yes, I do. Is it amazing, has barely any bugs now and runs great? Absolutely not.

It's a good game. It's unique, does things no other game does and I enjoy it because of that. It's far from amazing, though, and still doesn't even remotely live up to the promises CDPR made before release. But it doesn't need to, it's fine as it is. You can do stupid builds (I built a nearly invincable V, that does way more damage than he should) and I love it for that. It has a ton of completely useless, yet very interesting features, which I'm really a fan of.

It does have a ton of bugs. Some funny, like cars randomly exploding, losing all doors and wheels or NPCs casually walking over things they shouldn't be able to walk over (like cars or walls), but some are really annoying or even game breaking. I'm pretty sure there's also a memory leak somewhere in there, which I ran into a few days ago. Additionally, the game has a few issues with the AMD GPU driver ever since CDPR released the 2.3 update, leading to a ton of micro stuttering and issues with path tracing. That's annoying as heck, and if you enable path tracing even game breaking. What doesn't help is, that the FSR 3 implementation is probably the worst out of any game. It's horrible. FSR 2 is fine (FSR 2 is just old), but FSR 3 is not. So on a Steam Deck, if FSR 2 is too low quality for you, then I'd recommend getting Decky and installing Optiscaler through that, making it possible to use the leaked (by AMD themselves) version of FSR 4. And weirdly enough, on my PC, I feel like the game had less issues on version 1.1 than since 2.0. Despite my PC getting a lot more powerful and the game getting a lot of updates since then. Or perhaps the game has more issues on more powerful PCs?

The performance is... Fine. It's not bad, especially on lower end hardware (like the Steam Deck) the game runs actually surprisingly well, but on higher end hardware the game seems to not scale as well as I would expect. The DLC also has some performance issues, meaning it will struggle on lower end devices, like the Steam Deck and the Switch 2, even though the main game runs fine.

I really hope, that Cyberpunk 2077 2 (or whatever they'll call it) will have less bugs and better performance. And that they'll bring AMD FSR Redstone to both this game and it's sequel.

Horrible performance even at this day. I have a 3060 ti nvidia card, intel I7-9700 and 32 GB of DDR5 ram. 
I got stuck on the loading animation while trying to fast travel to the apartment, had to alt + f4 to exit. The loaging times in general takes 1-5 minutes, my PC sounds like a jet engine with settings on medium and the nvidia superresolution on ultra performance. 
Sad to see that after all this time its still not in the state it deserves.

I first played Cyberpunk 2077 on PS5. I came back again. And now here I am on PC for my third playthrough, willingly returning to Night City like it didn’t already ruin me emotionally twice.

Cyberpunk’s comeback story is real. What was once rough around the edges is now one of the most immersive RPG experiences you can play. The world is dense, atmospheric, and dripping with style — Night City isn’t just a map, it’s a place that pulls you in and refuses to let go.

The storytelling is where the game truly shines. Characters feel human, flawed, and painfully memorable. You don’t just complete quests — you get invested in them. Some side missions hit harder than main storylines in other games, and Johnny Silverhand remains one of the best “problematic roommates” in gaming history.

Combat feels tight and flexible, especially on PC. Whether you’re going full netrunner, guns-blazing merc, or stealthy cyber-assassin, the systems finally work together the way they always should have. Driving feels better, movement feels smoother, and everything just clicks now.

Visually, Cyberpunk 2077 on PC is unreal. Neon reflections, rain-soaked streets, detailed interiors — it’s one of those games where you stop mid-mission just to look around. The soundtrack is elite too, perfectly matching the tone whether you’re cruising the city or spiraling into existential dread.

Final verdict:
⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

[b]TLDR:[/b]
Cyberpunk 2077 is a good game, and does many world building aspects better than I have ever seen in any other game. The city and its citizens, in particular, are a level of immersive I have never seen before. Truly well done. However, narratively, the devs have clearly decided on the favored ending and make it incredibly apparent to the player how wrong they are if they don't choose it. They have also left in both silly and game breaking bugs that are incredibly easy to catch, with even Bethesda doing better in some aspects.

[b]The (VERY) Good:[/b]
-CD Projekt Red have really managed to breathe a new level of life into the city environment that I have never seen before. I strongly recommend ignoring getting a car until after you leave the first area. It really is impressive and immersive when walking around.

-They have done a good job in making the permanent companion character grow on you over time. Their attitude progression towards V, the player character, appears natural, and I went from disliking them to caring about them at the end of the game.

-Much of the main story and side quests are well designed. Even the equivalent of fetch and radiant quests manage to have a level of variety not seen from other developers. It was quite enjoyable playing through them.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
-The devs are not truly offering the player a choice in how V, the player character, views the world. Having played through all the endings, it is extremely clear that only the companion NPC vendetta choice is truly supported by the devs. They have made it so that any other endings V takes result in him being either neutral or hyper critical of the results, even when the outcomes are almost entirely as desired. This also applies to the DLC endings.

-The friendship/ intimacy paths were not done well in this game. One NPC's path is clearly more fleshed out and based in actual relational development norms, but almost all require suspension of disbelief in how they progress. It was extremely jarring in one path that was at a "we (literally) met yesterday to do a gig together (the friendship NPC being forced to participate) and succeeded and are relaxing/ light celebrating while waiting" to suddenly "hey, I wanna be close and touch you."

-The devs are also providing unrealistic amounts of support to Bethesda's past position that large open world games are inherently buggy. It becomes obvious how bad the situation is when your character surviving an encounter depends on the game mechanics actually working, being most apparent in an ending called (no spoilers unless you search for details on Google yourself) "(Don't) Fear the Reaper". In it, you realize how unacceptably broken and unreliable the detailed mechanics are. It is clear that the devs could (and I would argue, should) have spent time resolving this issue.

-There are bugs in many of the endings, with some being potentially game breaking. An example is one involving an NPC driving the player to a destination (no other choice here). In this ending, the NPC pathing can be utterly broken merely by the NPC driving mechanics the devs have built into the game. I realized this once the NPC took me to Pacifica when I was supposed to be taken to North Oak (opposite ends of the map).

-They have bugs even Bethesda has resolved years ago, such as objects freaking out when you turn away from them. Turning back will show them launching into walls, the ground, and the sky.

[b]The Annoying:[/b]
-Why make the vehicle speed so obviously wrong, CD Projekt Red? It is incredibly noticeable how wrong it is. Just divide all the numbers by roughly 2 and be done with it. This complaint only matters because so many other "realistic" aspect are well polished enough that it jarringly stands out.

I have so much to say about this game.

This writing is excellent, and it gets even better in Phantom Liberty. A beautiful story with well written, charismatic characters. The city feels alive, very well-designed and (often) beautiful to see. The gameplay and gunplay are fun, also thanks to the pumping soundtrack during fighting sequences, which is very good.

However, I do have to say that there was a lot of misleading/pumped-up marketing leading to the release of this game. It has been promoted as if it was going to be this extraordinary, game-changer RPG game, but the game didn't end up being any of that.

One of the things I found mostly jarring, is that the main story felt disappointingly short. When I saw the "point of no return" pop-up show, I had a funny facial expression because I really did not think I was nearly close to the end of the main story. I really feel like a lot of the game content should've been part of the main story. At least the Rogue, Panam and Judy arcs.

Even after 5 years from its release and multiple game patches, I experienced a lot of technical bugs, many of which really worsened the enjoyment and immersion of the game. One of them is Claire driving through the whole city and going crazy at the end of the first The Beast in Me mission when choosing to get back to the garage with Claire. I encountered other game and quest-breaking bugs like this.

Cyberpsychos appear on the game map at all times — this means V technically already knows where each one of them is located. This doesn't make much sense. If there were really 17 cyberpsychos in the city all at once free for days, I think the city would've already been burned to the ground. Would've been much better if Regina simply called her whenever she was close to a cyberpsycho. If V went away instead of defeating it, Regina would call V disappointed and angry since her research would be negatively impacted. The way the mission has been implemented in the game just feels faulty.

Characters are allowed to call you during missions, which can be very bothersome and can disrupt conversations, cause confusion and not being able to listen to mission conversations.

Interactions with Panam when the player is Female V can get very sappy, which feels very unfitting and weird since Panam is straight. I understand that there's a thin line between just looking at two big friends and two friends who look like they're into each other — but it clearly goes over it, and it feels like we're just living the exact same Panam you'd experience with Male V, except there's no kissing or sex scene.

UI is nice, but some of the beta concepts objectively looked better.

The game shows a "Skip" prompt on the bottom right when having conversations with characters. You can disable this from the main menu in the Interface section, and I've had it disabled since the first 10 minutes of the game, but it appears that the prompt still shows up in a couple of situations (I've seen it pop up when talking to Lizzy Wizzy for the first time).

The first hour of Phantom Liberty seemed incredibly unstable. Arriving at the Dogtown border - flatline. A few minutes into Dogtown — Flatline. Middle of fighting the Chimera - flatline. I've gotten more crashes in one single hour than I had in my entire playthrough.

I've played the game in Italian and the work that has been done on the localization is simply superb. Probably THE best localization work that has ever been done on a videogame, up there with The Last of Us games. I've listened to other voice over languages such as English, German, Polish and Brazilian Portuguese, and it really seems like CDPR invested a lot into localization in other languages, which is something awesome. Being able to experience the story, the characters, and being able to listen to all sorts of NPC conversations in my native language truly enhanced the immersion of the game for me. Everything has been localized meticulously, with attention to detail, and every small interaction feels natural.

The facial animations with JALI technology help the immersion and voice over even more, with naturally moving lips based on the dialogue audio. However, I have to say that, more often than not, facial animations would have this sudden switch to a different expression in 1 frame, with no interpolation, which feels very jarring.

Overall, I cannot say that I don't recommend this game. The technical bugs can be very frustrating, but other than that, there's a beautiful game. It's clear that a lot of love has been put into it. The story, the characters, how alive and living the city feels, a lot of things are very well-built in this game. It seems like most of its issues come from a rushed release, which is a big shame.

If your looking for a fun and dystopian style futuristic game, this is honestly a fun one. after its rough start and major issues, CD did a great job making this a fun and play able game for anyone to indulge in, as well as having revamped the skill trees to make more sense and have a better impact to how you can/want to play the game!

[h1]First Impressions[/h1]
I wasn’t sure about Cyberpunk 33 at first. I tested it through other means before buying it, played about 30 hours on one save, dropped it, then came back later and did another 40 hours on a new run. After all that, I finally bought the full Ultimate Edition. Now I’m 40+ hours into the legit version and basically addicted.

I doubted the game early on, but the more I played, the more it hit me how good it actually is.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
The world is insanely well-built. It feels alive in a way most games don’t even get close to. Night City actually has weight, personality, and emotion behind it.

Whenever “I Really Want to Stay At Your House” comes on the radio, it just hits straight in the chest. The game nails the vibe. The city feels full and alive. It’s the kind of world you just exist in, not rush through.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Combat and Gameplay[/h1]
Combat feels solid. Guns, movement, abilities – everything clicks. It’s fast, responsive, and actually fun to experiment with.

Driving is way better than I expected. Vehicles feel grounded now instead of stiff or floaty, and cruising through the city at night is honestly one of my favorite things about the game.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is on another level. The writing, the characters, the emotional punches – I’m almost done with the main story again and on the DLC path now, and it still hits just as hard as the first time.
They wrote something real here. It sticks.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]From Disaster to Greatness[/h1]
Yeah, everyone knows the game had a brutal launch. But they fixed it. Completely. The devs turned it into something genuinely great. It went from a joke to one of the best RPG experiences in years.

They rebuilt this thing into a monster of a game. Respect where it’s due.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Cyberpunk 33 is worth buying, worth playing, and worth finishing. The world, the story, the atmosphere – everything just comes together. I can recommend it easily to anyone who wants a powerful story in a world that actually feels alive.
