Night City still feels like the lovechild of Blade Runner and a malfunctioning toaster, but at least your car won’t get stuck at red lights anymore (unless it’s being dramatic), because AutoDrive finally learned the difference between “stop” and “GOOOO.” 
SteamDB

Thanks to this update, your ride will now overtake traffic, ignore semantically annoying signals, and generally behave like your ex who never respected boundaries—minus the emotional trauma. 
Bo3

Photographers will rejoice that Photo Mode is less hostile now. NPC collision is disabled (translation: you can smash granny into a car hood and finally get that avant-garde shot for Instagram), and pretty much all poses now work for everyone. 
SteamDB

Plot holes? Mostly fixed. Quest bugs that once made your game laugh and crash are now politely ignored. It’s basically Night City saying: “Look, we still hate your saves, but we’ve learned to behave… some of the time.” 
SteamDB

And yes, you can finally turn off that obnoxious vignette effect that made you feel like you were constantly staring out of someone’s eyeballs. 
Reddit

But let’s be honest: Cyberpunk’s real personality is its bugs. If a cyber-waifu doesn’t spontaneously bail for Mars or your car doesn’t do a spontaneous barrel roll in traffic at least once per session, did you even play? (Answer: yes––but you’re doing it wrong.)

In short, Patch 2.31 feels like the game waking up with coffee and deodorant: slightly more polite, marginally less suicidal, still absolutely chaotic. Night City won’t change—but it might stop trying to murder your vehicle.

The most 6/10 game I've ever played. For all of its promises of being an RPG, you have very little meaningful choice in the story and gameplay. Quests typically have one outcome, rarely two, and the outcomes often just boil down to what kind of vendor trash weapon you get as a reward. Combat is divided into conventional gunplay, which is fine; melee combat, which is weightless and uninteresting; and quickhacks, which are useless for 50% of the game and blatantly overpowered and boring for the other 50%. 

The world has nothing to do but engage in repetitive combat encounters, side quests and main story missions are all variations of combat and stealth encounters with no interesting mix-ups to the gameplay. The writing feels like the first draft of a 9th grade edgelord's fanfiction, and all of the characters so painfully dull it actually became a chore to suffer through their cutscenes. I want to shout out Keanu Reeves in particular for giving his usual bored, monotone drawl for a 100 hour game.

One of the most worthwhile games to play, not only because of its diverse gameplay with many character customization options, but also because of the music that evokes a certain feeling in the player, especially the song "I really want to stay at your house." The NPCs in the game interact with the player in a way that's not typical of other games. The Phantom Liberty DLC expansion clearly shows the difference between Night City and Dogtown. Some parts of the Edgerunner movie are also recreated in the game, such as "David's Jacket" and "Guts, Rebecca Shotgun." These are items you can obtain in the game thanks to scenes from the movie, which makes the characters even more important. Furthermore, the game's six endings offer players a multi-layered emotional experience. In short, Cyberpunk is a game worth trying and experiencing from many different perspectives.

This game gives you the satisfaction of so many of your little interactions with characters getting recognized later, it feels like you have an impact on the world, and that's all I really wanted. What a wonderful game.

I never thought I'd play this game. I remember when it came out and it was a laggy, buggy mess. But, time passed, five years passed, and the game was 65% off. I decided to give it a try.

I ended up enjoying it a lot.

The story follows V, a mercenary for hire in Night City (essentially a futuristic Los Angeles). Your character's background (Nomad, Street Kid, Corpo) influences the start of the story and gives some dialogue options. I chose Nomad, the other two seemed kind of generic. From there, you are given story missions to complete and optional gigs from fixers (quest-givers), and other side jobs. The story at first is just okay. The biggest problem is it goes all over the place. There are so many story missions that left me scratching my head, not sure why I was doing this, and sometimes outright bored. Things get a lot more interesting in the 2nd and 3rd acts of the game. There is some overlap with the story of [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i], which surprised me It gets pretty depressing from that point, there aren't real happy endings in this game. It reminds me a bit of  I also bought the "Phantom Liberty" DLC, which adds onto the base game. It also gets pretty depressing  The story in that is compelling and is a lot easier to follow. I recommend buying it if you care about story in games. It adds several new missions too which is nice.

Your stats points affect how you approach missions, of which there are many. Many are your standard "kill x" and "retrieve _" but there is a lot more than that, I was surprised by the variety. I decided to pour my points into body (health), tech ability (cybernetics and armor), and reflexes (blades). There is also a skill tree connected to each ability, granting unique powers. I unlocked the ability to finish, instantly kill, low HP enemies with my blades, granting a temporary movement boost, deflect enemy bullets with my katanas, leap at enemies, and dash through midair. I also invested in cybernetics to increase my defense, HP, and crit chance. In the end I ended up being a cyber shinobi tank, 600 HP, taking bullets like they were rubber, and slicing through enemies like butter. This was very fun to say the least. There are other options available, you can specialize in blunt weapons like clubs, and hacking or stealth. The latter I didn't do because I'm too impatient. There are many other gameplay features, too many to name, like racing, hiring a prostitute, and romancing characters. There are two romance options per gender, a gay and a straight option. The gay characters hint at their sexuality in dialogue, but only barely, which is pretty annoying. I ended up romancing Kerry, who decided not to leave Night City with V, because his music career was more important. Fuck him for that. He's dead to me.

My main problems with this game, besides the story being weak at times, is the games' performance. Every time I would go to the map to track a fast travel point and a mission, I would get a massive lag spike for several seconds. The game also crashed and froze several times. After I completed the game, it asked about returning to a previous save with something special waiting for me. I said yes and then it crashed. That felt supremely ironic. This could be a problem with my PC but it runs  [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i] without issues, so I'm not sure. Sometimes missions also didn't spawn, and I had to reload a previous save, which was annoying. If you have a lower end device, then you're likely to run into problems. I also wished romances had a bigger effect on the story, after you romance a character they'll sometimes message you about coming to your place, where you have a date night. V went on a date with Kerry every time he asked and he still wouldn't leave the city with him, so again fuck him.

[i]Cyberpunk 2077[/i] is no master piece, but it's come a long way since it's release, and is a really good game. If anything I mentioned sounds interesting, I recommend buying the game. Just keep the caveats about the story and game performance in mind.

Cyberpunk 2077 is an great game. The city is diverse and feels real. The characters and organizations in the game are realistic and all are likeable in their own way. Driving cars, shooting, and running around all feel good and are very fun to just do without a purpose.

The story is great too. It has it's moments, some more memorable than others, but the characters and plot are all very cool and immersive. The twists and emotional moments are all touching and will stick with you.

But the game has some bugs. Most bugs that still exist aren't very bad, but they are noticeable and take you out of it sometimes. Like when the bartender at the Afterlife pours a drink, and the drink floats in the air rather than staying in her hand. To me it's not a dealbreaker, but bugs like that shouldn't be there after five years of being out.

Cyberpunk 2077's performance is notoriously bad. It's basically the new Crysis. On my 7900xtx and 9800x3d I played at 4k medium settings and I think it hovered around 70-80 FPS. This is without graphics mods or performance mods.

The draw distance in this game can't be changed. And it's a problem. Building details, street marks, foliage, rocks, all of that kind of detail noticeable pops in and out as you drive. Sometimes it's not so bad, but when you notice it, you really notice it.

Overall the game is great. It has some graphics hiccups but I think the story and gameplay make up for it. Maybe getting it on sale would be best since it's an older game and has some unfixed problems though.

a game so good i can't bring myself to end the playthrough. i am too attached. 

for its faults there is nothing like it. no piece of video game media has ever made me feel the way cyberpunk has: nothing has made me think like it does about life, about friendships, about an innumerable (at least for the purposes of this short text) amount of abstract social and philosophical ideas. every part of night city is festering and screaming to be ripped from the roots but this (due to my fault) awkwardly-phrased proverbial tree has grown to be a whole city which is all that's holding up these poor million of souls. what are you but an insect in the bark? the world doesn't care or do anything for you, in fact it hates you for having needs, you are at best beneficial in a symbiotic sense to it with your continuing capability to consume. the game teaches you human life here is worth nothing- but instead of leaving it there utterly nihilistically like a lot of stories do, it shows you the importance of personal relationships and friendship and discovering the inherent worth of others and yourself, no matter how fucked and complicated it all is we're still capable of the same base contact and that cannot be taken away so easily, which i thought was beautiful. there is NO winning and you should STOP trying to win, there are things around you worth living for but any attempt to go on an upward trajectory will forever be on a greased incline. every story you come across is shaking you violently to stop kidding yourself.

all in all what terrific science fiction it is. i think the best in the genre that's been made on the medium so far.
shooting people is pretty fun too.

please, if you are buying this and starting a first playthrough, trust me and choose the corpo-lifepath. it gives you the most emotional stake in all of the story, especially in the first and third acts. female V's acting comes off a bit easier to interpret in the way you'd like -- no hate intended to male V's actor, he also does a fantastic job but I felt as if some of his line delivery had more of a preconceived harder set feeling superimposed on it in comparison with female V's who's less angularly pointed(?) delivery felt easier to project my own reading onto, though I may also just be relating to woman protagonists more in general.

I will never understand the Souls-like genre. Everybody seems to love it. I get recommended these games multiple times a year and yet every time I try one, it feels like the same experience all over again.

When Dark Souls 1 and 2 were still a novelty I actually UNDERSTOOD the appeal. “The point is that it doesn’t handhold you” great. That made sense at the time. But this genre has been run into the ground. Over and over it’s the same setting, the same tone, the same "mythic past" or "bleak dark future" where the bloodied, tarnished, vanquished whatever must fight Eli the All-Mighty Executioner to prove their worth. It’s creatively stagnant.

What really loses me is the design philosophy. What skill is actually being tested when you’re ambushed constantly, die, respawn and then simply remember where the traps are? That isn’t "skill" it’s memorisation. By that logic Far Cry 3 is a Souls-like because you die once, then know where the pirates are next time and sneak up on them. Maybe I just don't GET it.

The genre is also an oxymoron. Souls-likes are constantly framed as niche, hardcore experiences, yet they are massively popular. They sell millions, dominate charts and dozens of them release every MONTH. That isn’t niche. The appeal often seems less about fun or creativity and more about being able to say “I did it or something.”

I’m not here to trash THIS specific game. Elden Ring is clearly well-made and crafted by the original architects of the genre. But Souls-like games have been mythologised to such an extreme degree that they can never realistically deliver what people claim they do. They don’t meaningfully prove skill, they don’t offer an especially interesting challenge and for me, they’re rarely fun.

It’s just not my cup of tea. I'll keep it in my library to play on rainy days.

Maybe I just need to get good.

Ah.. Elden Ring. Seni incelemek, İstanbul’a benziyor. Biraz tatlı, biraz acı. Biraz emin, biraz değil. Üzümlü kekim mi diyeyim, kabusum mu? Karar vermem güç.

Evet, üstte belirttiğim gibi. Zor, bir o kadar da güzel bir oyun. Yoran, bir o kadar da haz veren bir oyun. İstanbul misali. 

Elden ring her şeyden önce muazzam dövüş mekanikleri olan, mükemmel atmosferi bulunan, zorlayıcı, etkileyici bir oyun diyerek başlamak isterim. Gaming dünyasının olmazsa olmazı gibi bir oyun bu. Soulslike’ı sevdirecek boyutlarda başarılı. Fakat öyle bir sıkıntısı var ki, siz sormayın ben söylemeyeyim. 

Oyunda bir mod kurulumu yardımıyla duo oynayabiliyorsunuz. Fakat bunun bir dezavantajı olacak. Eğer duo’ysanız, sürekli oyun dünyanızın raid yemesine hazır olun. Bu raidler o kadar saçma, o kadar aptalca ki, tüm oyunun güzelliğini gölgeliyor adeta. 

Anlamlandıramadığım bir şekilde pvpsi her daim laglı. 10000 megabit internete de sahip olsan, vuruşlar hep laglı bir şekilde rakibe gidiyor. Vurduğun halde canını azaltamıyorsun. İşin PvP kısmında dodge sisteminde sıkıntı var. 

Daha da garibi, bu raid esnasında gerçekleşen PvP düellosunun, hiçbir şekilde adil olmayışı. Gelen kişi itemsel ve level olarak sizden çok da güçlü oluyor. Bundan da saçması, siz bir boss fight’ının ortasında raid yiyorsunuz ve eksik pot’la oynamanız gerekiyor. Sırf bu sebeple oyuna dislike atasım var, ama bunu yapmadım. Çünkü bu, haksızlık ve duygularımla hareket ederek yaptığım bir puanlama olurdu.

Alınız efendim. İndirimde kaçırmayınız bu oyunu. Alıp da bir gün oynarım bea diyerek de almayınız. Hemen indirip başlayınız. Pişman olacağınızı sanmıyorum.

he game freezes like crazy for no reason. I’ve tried every fix under the sun, and the only upside is that I ended up optimizing Windows for my other games. Even so, I pushed through about 12 hours of gameplay, but it’s just boring and slow-paced. It’s a gorgeous, massive open world that feels empty and lifeless—even the Human NPCs feel like zombies. The story is just 'meh.' I guess it’s a matter of taste, but for me, it was a huge disappointment.

The only thing I didn't like was being forced to sacrifice a friend and not having a reasonable alternative to avoid it, because even after using a certain needle that reverses the effect, the friend doesn't return for a final dialogue. I found it harsh and unnecessary; in my opinion, the tarnished are unethical for accepting this, and the game promotes it as the right choice (forcing the creators' vision onto the player, and not giving them a real choice).

Achei pesado e desnecessário, na minha opiniao o tarnished é anti-ético por aceitar isso, e o jogo prega como escolha certa (forçando visão dos criadores para o jogador, e não dá escolha real para ele).

Once I got a controller, everything became much easier due to more responsive controls and whatnot, even on this potato laptop.

Some critiques:
1. Some of the level and arena designs are quite poor in that they present difficulties unrelated to the game mechanics but are purely technical such as giant bosses in tiny arenas which lead to cameras constantly clipping into the walls and the boss itself
2. These poor design issues combine with poor controls to create situations where you are really fighting against your own PC and camera rather than the boss itself, which can be a challenge in itself but not the enjoyable point of this game.

All in all, still a very enjoyable game with an actual challenge.

Elden Ring is likely one of, if not, the best games I've ever played. The spectacle, the feeling of victory - the grandiose of it all truly feels like a once in a lifetime experience. I fear I will never play a game as marvelous as ELDEN RING.

Elden Ring is a beautiful, yet cruel game that rewards persistence and grit; the stunning world you enter is violent, unforgiving, and harsh... Yet the player persists. The sense of accomplishment that comes when you finally conquer a challenge you'd been stuck on, or finally clear a dungeon/castle is something I've never experienced in a game before. 

Elden Ring is the definition of a legendary journey. You will face overbearing hardship across the wide, open world that is The Lands Between, with each of its distinct regions posing different challenges.

In Caelid, you'll be challenged by vast amounts of dragons and putrid, rotten creatures. Liurnia of the Lakes will have you battling mages and spirits, while the Mountaintops face you with snowy trolls and giant crows. Each region is distinctly difficult - and the vastness of the open world poses a new challenge at every turn.

The vastness of The Lands Between is complimented greatly by the diverse array of challenges presented all throughout. In each crevice, you'll find catacombs to conquer, a hidden boss, or an NPC you've never seen. The world of Elden Ring is full of things to see - each testing your persistence and skill.

Elden Ring is without a doubt, a MASTERPIECE - not because it is forgiving, but precisely the opposite. Elden Ring is a test of determination and persistence; completion is proof of struggle - and I love a good challenge.

I am obviously not the typical Souls player. I liked Sekiro and Bloodborne and to a lesser extent DS1, 2 and 3, but I just found this to be dragged out way too much, be way to focused on making specific builds and so much essential stuff being hid around the massive world. It was just too much and not explained in any way. 

Often losing track of what you were supposed to do when sidetracked by some dungeon, and often you find yourself in areas that you are way underleveled for. Last part was especially aggregios to me, because the game felt more like a mmorpg grind rather than a souls-experience. Also, a ton of essential stuff is hidden in dungeons or other maps that are theoretically "optional".

At the end, I just wanted the game to be over so I could call it a day and not feel like I wasted my money, but that is more on me and my stubbornness I guess. Felt relief to be done with the bosses more so than accomplishment like I did with other entries. Especially because some had cutscenes you had to skip every time, some had annoying walk-backs, and others had annoying, tedious first phases. 

I understand why people like it. But I personally found it way too much, given the typical amount of repetition you need to do in order to progress a boss. A lot ended up feeling more like a chore than something I really wanted to progress because I couldn't wait to experience what was next.

just not my kind of game.  having to memorize attack animations, getting punished for rolling 10 frames too early, banging your head against a single boss for hours, etc.  If you like Dark Souls games you'll like this, I personally find this genre aggresively unfun.

I love this game so much in so many ways, but at times it's a very love hate relationship. Going into it, I felt the game was overhyped, and even several hours hours in, I still felt that way and was close to dropping it. Then something clicked, and I can wholeheartedly say that yes, this game does deserve the hype, and I cannot recommend it enough.

This was my first FromSoftware game, and I do not think I will be playing another, not because this one was unenjoyable but just because I'd like to keep this as the standard of soulslike I got to experience, and the open world Elden Ring offers, from my understanding, isn't offered in the other games. In many moments, Elden Ring felt like the perfect game, however it does have its flaws, so I guess it isn't a perfect game? I feel the first playthrough of this game is something that you'll never quite be able to capture the feeling of again, in all the right ways. 

The game’s lore is deep, but its story is not told through a traditional main storyline narrative. Instead, the player needs to put together pieces gathered through NPC dialogue, world exploration (environmental details), and item descriptions. Additionally, there is no quest log, and little guidance on where to go or what to do next. Even after completing my first playthrough, I still did not have a solid understanding of the story, and most of what I know now came from external sources. However, that's not to say I wasn't picking up what the game was putting down. Interestingly, when I replayed the opening cutscene in New Game+, it felt completely new because of how much I had learned during my first playthrough. The more you understand the world, the more rewarding exploration and side content become. However, you are probably not playing Elden Ring for its story, but for its gameplay and challenge. 
In my opinion, the world is the game’s greatest achievement. It is massive, detailed, and genuinely feels alive. The art direction is stunning, with a wide range of distinct regions, and for the first time since games like Red Dead Redemption 2 and CD Projekt RED titles, I felt truly immersed again. There is a constant urge to want to keep exploring and see what the world has to offer.

However, the beauty of the world comes with a steep initial hurdle. The lack of direction makes it easy to spend hours exploring without feeling like you have made any real progress. My first 10 hours were spent wandering aimlessly, and that nearly made me quit. It was only after following guides to understand where to go and how to build my character that the game opened up. Once it did, exploration became far more satisfying, though I still frequently looked things up, from build optimization to hidden bosses. 
The combat and boss fights are what the game is best known for, and overall, they deliver. The game offers strong build variety through weapons, spells, talismans, and skills, and most playstyles are viable. You can also respec your character's skill points later on, which allows for experimentation. While the game is challenging, I do not think it is as punishing as its reputation suggests. Most bosses took me fewer than 10 attempts, and if something felt impossible, there was always the option to explore more, level up, and return stronger. In that sense, the player has some control over the game’s difficulty.

That said, the combat is not without issues. There is a noticeable difficulty spike in certain late game areas where even regular enemies deal excessive damage. Some encounters feel unfair rather than challenging, with stun locking enemies or poorly designed bosses. Many large bosses suffer from awkward hitboxes or fights that revolve around chasing them for extended periods, which is simply not enjoyable. Unfortunately, even the final boss falls into this category. Enemy aggression also became a constant annoyance, with enemies chasing far beyond what feels reasonable. 
Despite its flaws, I enjoyed the base game enough to buy the DLC at full price. Visually, it lives up to the base game’s world design, but the difficulty is noticeably higher, and exploration feels tense rather than rewarding. Many of the combat issues present in the base game are amplified here, and the frustration often outweighed the enjoyment.

The DLC bosses are not difficult in a satisfying or engaging way, but instead feel frustrating and exhausting. Difficulty and challenge do not automatically translate to good boss design or enjoyment. Rather than feeling creative or well-paced, they often rely on constant aggression, excessive attack chains, oversized AOEs, and very limited openings. It felt like Many encounters came down to dodging insanely well only to be rewarded with like two seconds to retaliate, which quickly becomes draining.

To be clear, I beat the main bosses in the DLC and then more, which I feel is important to say given how often criticism is dismissed on the basis of skill. If this style of design works for you, then that is completely valid, but for me, it made many fights feel more annoying than challenging. While the DLC does include one of my favorite bosses in any game I have played, Rellana, the overall boss design direction was disappointing.

I would only recommend the DLC to players who truly loved the base game and want to experience everything it has to offer. If not, I would say skip the DLC, leave it at the base game.

The game does have New game Plus so if you want to play the storyline again without restarting a whole new character you can and yes you can also play with your friends even if you start a new game plus but my rating for the game is a 3 out of 10 In my eyes it was just too overhyped even for 2025 and going on 2026.

Lovely gameplay. 1st of all there are a lot of DRAGONS (very cool)!!! Game stays truly interesting and extremely fun. It's frustrating and I'm saying that in a good way since it's pushing you to learn to dodge better, to manage your flasks better, to approach the boss with different strat etc. It has beautiful areas where the structures and/or the flora looks fantastic, and also PUTRID areas... where there are creepy freaky monsters waiting to ambush you and slice and dice you! It has great map as well, with lots of different areas and each one is unique in its own way!! The bosses are also amazingly designed with each one being very different from other ones. There are no two alike bosses which helps keep the game fresh and fun. The variety of weapons and armor is so much as well which really helps in above said "different strat" finding. Respecing your character is also easy so you can switch you playstyle almost whenever you want! All in all 10/10 game and DLC (dlc rocks as well, final boss fight is crazy good and epic!).

My comment is mainly aimed at people who... like me are not huge JRPG or die & retry players and are thinking of trying Elden Ring as they first FromSoftware game. Because I think everyone else reading this, will most likely love this game. You still might be like me and hate it despite your best efforts. I actually wish I hadn't bought it or put so much time into it.

I've logged 60h+ because of a friend of mine who is a huge fan, convinced me to play co-op. So he held my hand and helped me (basically carried me) for the whole adventure.

- While the game is overall showcasing beautiful landscapes and epic scale, I can't get past the "dated" look it has in terms of noisiness in detail, the dirty textures, the illogical structures  and somewhat empty flat barren lands of nothing. I can't really get behind the generic look of some of the maidens or some of the un-describable monsters. That isn't to say there aren't pretty areas or characters, but it felt hugely inconsistent to me.
- I didn't feel like I experienced much of a story, or narrative elements beyond a few cutscenes, and obscure dialogues sprinkled across hours of gameplay. I am also the kind of player who needs a journal/quest log of some kind, to understand or remember what I've found, what I'm doing... and how any of that matters.
- The inventory, dialogue prompts, consumable/equipment switching all felt really clunky and badly designed to me. Like why do you'd have to make sure to talk to an NPC 6-8 times in a row to make sure you exhausted all topics with them to receive a reward... the only way to know ?? Another player who did it before...
- I kind of got the idea of the combat where you want to be meticulous and not button spammy... but I swear my weapon went through the enemies more than half of the time, and yet I'd go flying if they so much as looked at me funny.
- Quests and object unlocks and secrets and ridiculous platforming that all seem to be tied to "you just had to know, be incredibly stubborn/curious or did it by accident by playing this as if you were a game tester" Spending literally 20 minutes scaling a wall that doesn't look climbable, all to drop down somewhere to pick up one rare item that you wouldn't even know was there....

So....... even after 60h... I didn't like the game. I was not having fun and as much as I wanted to join my friend in his enthusiasm for FromSoftware games... I kept finding more things against it...

Here is my opinion on ELDEN RING.

Pros:

1. The Great Katana, especially with Cold infusion and Chilling Mist
2. The lore
3. The cutscenes (+the voice acting)
4. A few of the bosses like Messmer or Mohg
5. Some of the scenery

Cons:

1. The open world feels useless and way too big.
2. You need to grind materials/runes for everything.
3. Bosses are spammed and copy-pasted across the world, besides they just feel unfair, delaying their attacks too much and being way too fast in their attack outcome.
4. Bosses like Promised Consort or Malenia aren’t hard, they’re just overwhelming in their animations (I can’t see sh*t in that 2nd phase) and the sheer amount of attacks they throw at you.
5. Torrent dies everywhere, anytime. 
6. The camera just sucks, especially in fights with big bosses.
7. Invaders are either other casuals you beat in just a few seconds (20%) or some toxic little sh*theads, who can only win with their skilless twink gear (80%).

DARK SOULS III > ELDEN RING

Rise, Tarnished… and prepare to die. A lot.

Elden Ring is epic on a grand scale. Ridiculous in the best way possible.

This game feels like David vs. Goliath on drugs — and somehow that makes perfect sense once you’re playing it. Every fight feels stacked against you, every victory feels earned, and every boss defeat is satisfying. Period.

This game is so good.
This game is so beautiful.
This is one of the best open-world games ever made. Period.

Elden Ring is the kind of game where I can finish a playthrough, put it down for months — even a year — and come back like no time has passed. It always pulls you back in because the world, the combat, and the freedom are just that good.

There’s more than one way to play, and none of them feel wrong. Strength builds, magic builds, faith, dex, weird hybrid nonsense — it all works if you commit. The game respects your choices and then immediately tests them.

You will die. A lot.
Sometimes to a boss.
Sometimes to a random enemy you underestimated.
Sometimes because gravity remembered you exist.
And yet, every time you see YOU DIED, you just think, “Alright… one more try.”

Every time you beat a boss, it feels earned. Not handed to you. Not cheap. Earned. Period.

If I had to give a complaint, it’s honestly this:
I wish there were more bosses to fight.

That’s it.

Honestly, I could say so much about this game — the lore, the story, what’s really going on beneath the surface, the characters, the world, all of it. But no matter what I say, it wouldn’t truly do this game justice.

This game is simply that good.
Just play it.

Disclaimer: For most people, I actually would recommend the game. But, for me personally, the more time passes the more flaws I see in the game, and my ultimate opinion on it is that it contains an all-time great game, but also a lot of junk that was never a problem in FromSoft's older titles.

Obviously the visual art is masterful. Obviously the music is some of the best ever to grace a video game. Obviously getting a big stick to beat your enemies' asses with while you roll around like a madman is awesome. Obviously the spectacle and beauty of the environments and bosses are breathtaking. All of these things can also be said about every previous soulsborne game.

Unfortunately, this game also contains a humongous map that is honestly exhausting to explore, and frequently that exploration rewards you with discovering a copy-pasted mine/cave that probably has some loot at the end that you will never use. The huge map also spreads its scant cast of NPCs further out than ever before, taking an obtuse and mysterious NPC quest system present in Dark Souls and stretching it to the point of being literally impossible for me to keep track of. You will run into NPCs that you haven't seen in 10 or 20 hours, and without a guide, how am I possibly supposed to remember what they said to me last time and know how to progress their storylines? It's just, "Huh, there is that weird guy I met like 2 IRL weeks ago. He looks cool, but what is he even doing again?" Simply put, the game is too big and too long for me, it just gets tiring and cumbersome, I seriously just wanted it to be over by the time I was 75% of the way through.

I'm also not a fan of a lot of the boss fights. It takes a problem that started in Dark Souls 3 and cranks it up even further, which is the design idea of, "If we just put a bonfire right outside the boss arena, we can make it a 3-phase clusterjam with movement cancelling and 69 different attacks for the player to memorize, and it won't matter if the player dies 20+ times because they can immediately retry!" Too me, this is so much less fun than the classic Dark Souls 1/2 challenge of battling your way through a gauntlet of enemies and traps and then fighting a challenging, but not overloaded boss as the cherry on top. It used to feel like a boss fight was your opportunity to prove that you have mastered an area and are ready to move on. In Elden Ring, a lot of boss fights feel like a tacked-on reflex and memorization challenge that is separate from the challenge of the area itself.

While I can appreciate that FromSoft tried going bigger and grander, I ultimately feel like they lost some of the old magic along the way, and Elden Ring ended up being annoying and fatiguing in a way that their previous titles never were for me. What a shame, as this is clearly their biggest hit, so I guess I'm in the minority. I can squint and see a 10/10 life-changing game in it, but ultimately the size and length of the game, some of the ridiculously complex bosses, and the copy-pasted open world elements distract from the solid core and drag the experience down. I can confidently say I won't be replaying this game, unlike Dark Souls 1 and 2, Bloodborne, and Armored Core 6, which all sound very enticing to return to.

Maidenless? Not Anymore. I came to the Lands Between with zero expectations and left with emotional damage, a broken controller, and 200+ hours played. Elden Ring is not just a game — it’s an obsession.

“What’s that in the distance?” (worst mistake of my life) Elden Ring’s open world is basically a trap. You see something cool far away, ride Torrent towards it, and suddenly you’re fighting a boss you were definitely not supposed to meet yet. And somehow… that’s the fun. No markers screaming at you, no hand-holding — just curiosity, punishment, and eventually triumph.

Git Gud, But Fair. Yes, it’s hard. Yes, you will die. A lot.
But every death feels like your fault. Every boss — from Margit teaching you humility, to Malenia reminding you that she has never known defeat — exists to test your patience, not waste your time. When you finally win, the dopamine hit is unreal.

Elden Ring doesn’t tell you its story. It dares you to discover it.
Godfrey’s exile, Marika’s defiance, Radahn holding back the stars while rotting, Ranni’s long game… the lore is deep, tragic, and beautifully fragmented. If you enjoy piecing together stories from item descriptions at 3 AM, this game will ruin you (in the best way).

Art Direction That Carries the Game The moment the soundtrack swells during a boss fight, you feel it. From Limgrave’s calm despair to Leyndell’s golden decay, the world tells its own story without saying a word.

“I started Elden Ring as a newcomer, and finished it having played every FromSoftware game — that alone should tell you what kind of masterpiece this is.”

Is this game a masterpiece? Was the gameplay good? , nah not really it felt pretty stiff at times and janky ill be completely honest. There were quite alot of things I really enjoyed in this release to be quite frank, and completing this game felt like I had just impregnated 5 women at a beach bar in the Phillipines; Incredibly satisfied and also kind of empty inside. Elden Ring isn't really about the story in my books, or the end goal, it is about the journey and also surprisingly your choices although small do have consequences and weight. I will have to say I do recommend this game. 

When I started it, I dispised the lack of hand holding and still think that they should give you as the player a bit more direction due to the fact I just relied on youtube tutorials to be completely honest. But this game has grown on me since starting it. It definitely felt like a journey, albeit a miserable one that I admitedly just used god mode nearing the end but either way I did kind of enjoy it. 

Do i recommend it at full price? , not really, Also do I think this is the Skyrim killer everyone told me it was? , No it was some kind of strange masochism simulator that felt like it had its plot or lack of it torn out of some crappy anime with some of the hilariously cheesy lines from the bosses. But yeah on sale I do recommend it, it is definitely an experience.

Completed the game.  Level 168, ~160 hours spent.  Overall a brilliant game, I think perhaps one of the few games in which I’ve spent over 150 hours (perhaps only the second one on steam after cyberpunk 2077).    

Hardest bosses fought (in that order) - 
- Elden beast + radagon 
- General Radahn.  
- Malenia 

Also, ended up clicking on the blue summon sign and got Ranni’s ending lol. At first, it felt so anti-climatic, I mean I fought the elden beast for over a dozen times and then this ending ? But, after reading the lore, I feel this was perhaps one of the best endings.

Pros:
- The game has a brilliant core gameplay loop that pulled me in and kept me engaged through out.
- The art / graphics is truly amazing.  Every region feels different.  The palaces are designed beautifully  and they do feel like grand palaces !
- Some of the NPC’s and their side quests are interesting too.
- The world has a nice lore that kept me glued (just like the prev from soft game - blood borne).  I kept reading the flavor text on every item to understand more.
- The open world is brilliantly crafted with enough checkpoints and stuff to do to not feel frustrated / bored.

Cons:
- As with other from soft games, there’s little explanation of whats going on and very little assistance in terms of quests / where to go next etc.
- Enemy variety is not that great.  Many enemies repeat in stronger versions in the later areas.
- Boss fights are a hit and a miss
- Catacombs / caves have the same environments repeated with similar enemies over and over.  It got really boring towards the end.
- Weapon switching became a headache as you need smithing stones to level up (irrespective of your level/attributes) and in the early-mid game, you cannot really experiment much (until you find the bell bearings).

Might do another play through some day with more points in INT/ARC attributes which I never really got to explore.

Definitely in my top 10 of all time. 9/10 from my end :)

*This review was machine translated from Korean to English.

Elden Ring

The Magnum Opus: A Dream Combination of Open World & Souls

🌍 A Match Made in Heaven
First and foremost, this is the game I have always dreamed of. Merging the tension of Souls-game combat with the freedom of a vast Open World was a stroke of genius. The sense of exploration, the scale of the map, and the freedom to go anywhere are simply unmatched. It was pure joy.

⚔️ The Combat: A Love-Hate Relationship
To be honest, I initially hated the boss patterns. From a pure melee perspective, the game relies heavily on unnatural delayed attacks and excessive combos (which I despise). It felt like the developers were trying too hard to catch veterans off-guard.

👻 The Solution: Embrace the "Spirit Ashes"
However, the Spirit Ash (Summon) system changed everything. At first, I thought using summons was "cheating." I was wrong. The game is designed around them. When I accepted the Spirit Ashes as a core tool—just like my weapon or shield—the "unfair" bosses became manageable and fun puzzle pieces. Don't let your pride stop you. Summon your Mimic Tear, and you will conquer this world.

⚖️ The Verdict
The Greatest of All Time (GOAT). Despite my complaints about the delayed attacks, the sheer scale and ambition of this game overshadow everything else. It is an adventure you must experience.

The game is a true cult and the idea delivers. I love how you blend into this apocalyptic ideal of a world.

After around 500 hours across multiple platforms, I can confidently say that Elden Ring is one of the most extraordinary games I have ever played.

I earned the Platinum Trophy on both PS4 and PS5, reached > NG+7, and even started the DLC on NG+7 (don't you dare). Now, after building my own PC, I bought the game again on Steam – and somehow, it still feels fresh.

Every single time I start a new playthrough, despite knowing the map fairly well, I get that same feeling of genuine discovery. There is always the sense that I might stumble upon something I have never seen before – and every now and then, that’s actually true. Very few games manage to do this anymore.

In my opinion, Elden Ring succeeds where much of the modern industry fails. To give a small comparison: when Hogwarts Legacy released, I was disappointed by how every "event" on the map was immediately visible. Exploration quickly became repetitive. Outside of exploring Hogwarts itself, much of the world felt like filler.

Elden Ring takes the opposite approach. You are given a vast, unlockable map – but no minimap, only a compass. You don’t know what lies at a location. You might see what looks like a cave, a lake, a ruin, or a distant structure – that’s it. You go there, explore it, and accept whatever awaits you. The game doesn’t hold your hand, and that’s precisely why it works. The old Game Boy games – like Pokémon Red and Blue – didn't do it either. They rewarded you for trial and error.

Elden Ring is difficult, no question, but it rewards perseverance. While it doesn’t rely on the tightly interwoven level design of Dark Souls or Bloodborne, its open-world structure doesn’t weaken the experience – in fact, it strengthens it. The world, the soundtrack, the atmosphere: everything feels cohesive and unmistakably true to the FromSoftware formula.

That constant sense of tension, exploring unknown territory, getting ambushed, briefly fearing the loss of your runes; it all creates a level of immersion and excitement that keeps you pushing forward.

And then there’s the sheer variety of builds. Whether you want to become a powerful mage or fully embrace the Berserk vibe by wielding the iconic Guts-inspired greatsword – the choice is entirely yours. That freedom, depth and love for details is a huge part of what makes the game so special.

Another aspect I absolutely love is how the lore is not directly told. Instead of long cutscenes or exposition dumps, the story is hidden in item descriptions, environmental details, and subtle NPC dialogue. The game largely leaves you alone – and that's exactly what makes it so compelling. If you want to understand the world, you have to actively dig into it, piece things together yourself, and willingly fall down the rabbit hole. And if you don’t fully grasp something, the passionate community and lore-focused fanbase become an essential part of the experience.

In my opinion, Elden Ring will influence the gaming industry for at least the next decade or two. For me personally, it will remain one of the greatest games ever made – if not the greatest.

I genuinely love this game. My journey into Souls like games started with Dark Souls 3 to impress a guy, but I forgot about him and fell in love with the Souls like series itself. From there I moved on to Nioh 2, Dark Souls 1, and eventually the golden ticket Elden Ring.

What makes Elden Ring fun for me is the freedom in building your character. One second I'm running a pure strength build with dual colossel hammers, and the next I’m using a faith build blowing bubbles from a giant trumpet (yes, you read that right). The variety encourages experimentation and keeps the gameplay feeling fresh no matter how many hours you put in.

The characters and storyline are another standout. The world feels rich, emotionally engaging (catch me crying at war counselor Iji), and out of the six possible endings there are two that really stuck with me. 

Overall, Elden Ring is a game I’d easily recommend to anyone willing to dive into a challenging experience.

I have been told this game is a masterpiece worthy of a thousand hours of play. Cannot confirm. Elden Ring asks the question, why not open world? And I can honestly say that the open world nature of Elden Ring is it's greatest weakness. Vast expanses of landscape dotted with enemies scattered about that you can just bypass because you're on a HorseGoat. Sure...you can run into that boss far too early and really struggle and feel accomplished by beating it early, but more often than not I ran into bosses that were complete and utter pushovers. The dungeons would be the best part of this game if not for the high level of copy paste in each one. And Story? What story. Digging through obscure and obtuse item descriptions and NPCs that can be encountered in any order piece together...something? 

If Elden Ring is your game, I'm happy for you, but I found it to be overhyped meh.

[h2]So when does the game stop being boring?[/h2]

There's nothing I hate more than weak hooks and half-assed introductions. It's the most essential part of any medium, especially games you spend $60 for. I spent more time in the Character Creation screen than I did actually playing the game and in the end I had to yiff some sliders I found online because making a character that doesn't look like Gollumina requires a Masters Degree. All of that just to find out that the game is just boring.

[h3]Keyboard and Mouse[/h3]
Unacceptable.

"Just use a controller," they say while they wipe the drool from their mouth and load up another asinine take in the chamber. Put it to your dome and keep it to yourself. It was goddamn 2022 when this game came out not 2015 and this is a billion dollar company. There are indie games with better ports long before the astroturfed virus killed less than 0.01% of the population. There is absolutely no excuse for this shit.

I'm not an unreasonable man however. I can look past major flaws as I am one myself but keep the flaws coming and there will be nothing of value left.

[h3]Enemies[/h3]
I believe this is simply a genre incompatibility issue. I never played classic Dark Souls games as I preferred more iconic classics like Line Rider and 5 Minutes to Keep Yourself Safe. If I played Hello Kitty Island Adventure and got trick-shotted by Kuromi holding mid in de_dust2 I wouldn't be surprised because I never played that genre before. I'd just assume that's how the game is like and decide it's not for me.

That's how I feel about this game. I kept trying to attack seemingly less dangerous NPC but the only thing I could kill was a bird and some cattle because they didn't fight back and died instantly. All the actual enemies would kill you within two hits. Again, maybe it's just how the genre is like. Seems interesting and I guess a certain kind of player might actually like that kind of gameplay but it's just not for me.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
[b]If you're wondering if you should get this game, don't.[/b]
Anyone who would actually enjoy this game would have already decided to purchase it because they know what they're getting into. If you've attempted Dark Souls and didn't find it appealing, this game won't be any more appealing. It looks more appealing than Dark Souls but it still plays like Dark Souls nonetheless and that series isn't even fun at all.

I guess I don't get it. I don't see how this won GOTY 2022.

The combat is janky as all hell. The in combat controls are relatively terrible, like hit the arrow keys to switch weapons, but also need you hands on WASD and your mouse. Even on controller combat did not feel good, hold circle to run but you need to use triggers to attack but also hold down left trigger to shield or prep your skill/bow arrow. Want to quick heal mid combat? You're going to need to hit like 5 different buttons to find it in the inventory, equip it, the whole time you're dodging the enemies and then if you use it at the wrong time the enemy will hit you and negate any of the healing you just did. Ghost of Tsushima came out 2 years before and had far better combat than this game and still managed to be challenging and rewarding. Being purposefully obstreperous to create "skill" is not good design IMO.

The menu and controls are absolutely terrible. Q/E to move forward and backwards? I know its a fromsoft game, but there is no reason to make simple things like crafting and changing equipment obtuse for no reason. When I am using a controller the game is still telling me only the keyboard keybinds. So figure it out by experimentation or entering the crappy menus to look at the controls every 30 seconds until you memorize it. Why is it that other games will show you the proper controls for what you're using but in this game they can't have that simple QOL, purposefully obtuse design strikes again.

The open world is not great. I guess a lot of people enjoyed running around this area, but to me it feels empty and lifeless. A little bandit camp here, a few wolves or crab monsters there. Or better yet, follow a cool path around the mountainside. Guess what, it goes nowhere, now walk all the way back out. Your reward for beating this area, you get a white dot to interact with that gives you some recipe book that you immediately forget about.

Story? What is that? Just go explore.

I gave it the old college try and at no point in the few hours I played did I think "man this is really fun I want to keep doing this." Just doesn't have anything to keep me wanting to playing: no engrossing story, no enjoyable gameplay, just a barren open world to explore.

I guess I just don't get it.

I don't need to tell you that Elden Ring is a marvel of game design. There will, for better or worse, probably never be another game like it. If you care for a world with layers upon layers of history and civilization, Elden Ring is a tasty fuckin meal. Of course, as always, From's combat is top-notch. 
It is not a perfect game, but it is truly, truly magical for your first playthrough. My gripes are common refrains too - too many repeated enemies and bosses, the world is a little too big for its own good. Comes together to deserve every last bit of praise it gets, though.

I hate to say a game is 'hard' but it is not the difficulty per se that makes this hard, it is that it is non-standard from almost every other game I've played. The control is. . . unpleasant and counter-intuitive.  For example, when 'locked onto an opponent' moving back is always away from the foe, even if you have run past the foe.  Like circling a drain, and that makes it difficult when dodging or riding past (mounted combat) .  You run AT the foe and then stop, within range of the counter attack and you don't leave.  I'm sure I can train to deal with it, but. . . this is not the only game I play.  Futhermore, I still haven't figured out how to fire from the 2nd arrow slot on a PC.

I love this game. I'm a huge Dark Souls fan, and I was very excited for this game when it originally came out. I played it about one and a half times on PS4, and I decided to buy it again on PC. It's essentially open world Dark Souls, and it has one of the best open worlds I've ever seen in any video game. And it's absolutely gorgeous to look at! Apparently there were issues with performance on PC when it first came out, but either they've fixed that since then or it works better on Linux than Windows. Or I've just been lucky lol. It has run flawlessly for me so far. This is probably one of my all time favorite games. It's not perfect, however. There are some balancing issues, especially in the late game. As with all FromSoft games, there are sometimes issues with checkpoint placement and enemy placement. I really wish they would fix that. Checkpoints are a lot better here than in previous games, but they can still be an issue occasionally. Regardless, this game is amazing, and it's absolutely worth buying and playing from start to finish. I haven't played the DLC yet since I never got that on PS4 and I haven't gotten far enough in my current playthrough to start that yet, but the base game is already a masterpiece.

I really liked it!

+ Big world where it is fun that different people progress in different areas. It seemed less linear than Dark Souls in some areas and more linear in some.
But the player option if he is stuck in one place to just explore somewhere else feels very good.
+ There is Levelling and Leveling spots which is a good part of auto-balancing and making the game easier.
+ The game has intense moments but also a lot of low-risk taking-in-the-vista moments, with nice weather effects and light. And the game needs it! This part felt a bit like Shadow of the Colossus just roaming around. So while it is a hard game, the balance of stress is much better than many other "hard" games
+ The world feeling is again gothic solemn dark souls-y which is distinct popular and kind of meme-y in a good way
+ Stakes of Marika remove long runbacks to boss rooms often

- It is hard and frustrating mechanics in some bosses, and the input-reading boss waiting for your attack or healing to time his attacks punishingly feels a bit bad.
- Malenia was too hard but is optional and a friend helped me!
- you can easily miss questlines and lock yourself out of questlines without using guides

I just did not enjoy ER.

The combat is great, but the bosses are overly aggressive and are clearly designed with Spirit Ashes in mind. They hit hard, give you little to no breathing room, and have huge health pools. Without summons and soul grinding this game is probably the hardest Soulsborne game. But the summons trivialize everything and make many bosses  easily beatable within 5-6 tries. They failed to strike a balance. 

The open world is just bad. Plain and simple. It's dead, lifeless, hollow, and every synonym of these words. It was fun to explore for the first few hours, but it gets really boring real fast. There is just so much repetitiveness (reskinned bosses, reskinned catacombs, ruins, caves, etc.) that it made me stop exploring and just rush through the game so I can move on to other games I wanted to play.

The storytelling is From's weakest area, yet they decided to create an even deeper lore, make it even more cryptic compared to the other games, and combined it with a HUGE open world so the story and lore are even harder to understand. 

The level design is still good though. I'll give the game at least that. 

Thumbs down for me.

At first, it seemed impossible. I have to admit, I was very discouraged when I was unable to defeat the first boss. But, after multiple attempts, I was able to defeat it. When this happened, I felt that I was ready to find the Elden Ring and banish evil from the realm!

There are myriads of things I could sink my teeth into with this game, whether its the beauty of the world, the myriad of gameplay options, the rhythm, the music, and for that matter the modability, but in the end i can't say it any better than Max0r did:

"The open world RPG where you roleplay as the victim." 

And i have never felt more masochistic.

Feels like I'm one of the few people who didn't really enjoy this game. Sure it's pretty, there are a lot of things from the game that will pull on the heart strings etc etc. But everything feels clunky, Playing on keyboard and mouse feels terrible. I mean who makes shift jump and space sprint? Yes you can change it but they bundled dodging together with sprinting so if you want to dodge you'd have to hit shift which is awkward so I felt forced to keep it to default. 

They throw a lot of things at you even as a long term souls fan I felt myself overwhelmed with all the new items abilities. They added crafting and grinding for resources and a bunch of other things that feel really out of place for a game like this. 

Yes I know this isn't dark souls 4 it's Elden ring, but it feels like dark souls with a different name then downgraded in a lot of ways added a bunch of clutter and messed up the controls. 

The fan base is rabid if you criticize the game even slightly they attack you saying "git gud, you're just bad, the game is so easy just use magic or summons" etc. Yes just don't play the way you want to play which was the whole point of the souls games (no set in stone classes) just "only play magic and summons if you're struggling. Also if you play magic you're trash!" Makes no sense to be forced into one play style because of poorly designed game mechanics, enemies designs and enemy placement.

While the game is undeniably beautiful it's hard to enjoy it when you keep getting lost, frustrated, and dying to everything because you're not supposed to go that way yet because you're under leveled. Even when you do go the way you're supposed to it feels like you're going the wrong way because they throw so much stuff at you that kills you instantly. They set up road blocks that make it hard to run past on horse which tells the player "You're not supposed to go here yet" even though that is where you're supposed to go.

Yes, dark souls 1 had something similar to this with the skeletons outside of fire link or the ghosts if you took the elevator down. The big difference is the game isn't open world so it made sense. "I went this way and seemed way to hard, I went this way also too hard, let me go the only other way oh hey I can beat these hollows this must be the right way" You felt like you can make good progress and know where you're going. It didn't hold your hand but also guided you in a way that felt natural. You could see you were making progress and getting to the next bone felt great. In this game they feel like they are everywhere where you don't need them and no where to be found in areas you do need them. You don't feel like you're ever making progress, the only thing in your mind is "Am I even going the right way yet?"

 There is a faint way the game shows you where to go but I hate having to constantly check my map to make sure I'm going the right way being chased everywhere because even when you do go the right way you'll just get killed instantly by 20 ranged units shooting you across the map and almost never miss their shots.

There are a lot of enemies that just spam super powerful attacks that leave 0 opening for counter attacks. If you're lucky you'll get one hit in (but the trade off is he took out 95% of your health)

You can't turn off messages on the ground from other players, You might be thinking "Well you couldn't do that in the other dark souls and it wasn't that bad." Well unlike past dark souls games (like 1 and 3 since those are ones I've played for many hours) almost every square inch of land in certain areas are just covered in messages and 99% of the time it's spam unhelpful messages. They put them on top of levers in front of doors you want to open and of course the message pops up and not the thing you want to use. 

The only way to avoid this IS TO GO OFFLINE. Yes you read that right you have to GO OFFLINE to not have this happen. I guess they couldn't be bothered to add a toggle for messages. So if you don't want to see a glowing annoying message (which by the way the messages can easily be mistaken for items on the ground from a distance since they use similar if not the same glow) you have to disable PVP and summoning/getting summoned. Yes just turn off a major part of what fromsoft's games are known for just to not be flooded with idiots spamming random messages every two feet.

TLDR - The game overall isn't terrible. You'll either really love it or really hate it and I hated it.

The game to end all games. It's a bit too unclear in some of its questlines, it's a bit too unforgiving when it comes to some of the mechanics, it's a bit too big to be considered just a "game." However, once you reach the end, you find it all "just right." I can't -- in good consciousness -- truly recommend this game to everyone, because this is not a game for everyone: this is a game for the truly insane GAMERS who like hurting their mental and stressing themselves out. There's a reason why only 75% of players even made it to their first achievement and why 30% even make it to the very end: the only people who buy this sort of game are the ones who know they will like it. If you aren't immediately drawn in by the concept/genre of this game, you shouldn't even think about this game.

However, if you are one of those unfortunate few who would risk everything (time, patience, etc), just to slay multiple disabled demigods, then maybe this game if for you. I finished my playthrough with 81 hours, and I'm sure that there is still more I missed (I didn't even touch the DLC) but I'm more than ready to get off this ride. It's a game with endless replayability and bountiful lore. Anything less than a 10/10 would be a disservice to how well-polished (even with the annoying bugs) and clearly loved this project was.

Elden Ring is visually extraordinary and mechanically restrictive.

The world, lore, and environmental storytelling are exceptional. The art team and narrative contributors deserve praise.

Unfortunately, the core gameplay philosophy prioritizes punishment over expression. Boss design often enforces rigid behavior, discouraging experimentation and turning mastery into memorization.

Difficulty is not the problem — lack of player agency is.

I finished the game, but the final hours felt like endurance rather than engagement. Challenge should elevate the player, not domesticate them.

A beautiful world constrained by an authoritarian design mindset.
This game is so good that i would let Miyazaki impregnate me for a sequel

I’m not a fan of attacks with excessive delay, repetitive dungeons, or attack patterns so aggressive that bosses feel like they have unlimited stamina, it’s clearly not a masterpiece — but there’s no doubt it’s an excellent-quality game that any fan of Souls-likes and open worlds will enjoy.

the game just feels massive and alive. The open world is crazy in a good way — you can literally go anywhere, get lost, and end up discovering something that feels like it was placed there just for you. The combat hits that perfect mix of punishing and satisfying, and playing it on PC makes everything smoother because you can tweak your graphics, controls, and frame rate the way you want.

Boss fights? Wild. The sense of adventure? Addicting. And the freedom to build your character any way you like just makes every playthrough feel different. It's basically that perfect combo of challenge, exploration, and “just one more try” that keeps you hooked.

One of the best Souls games From has made. A gem.
Best game I have ever played, it's big, it's exciting, it's fun.

Base game: Plenty of areas to explore, beautiful and rich in lore that ties well with DLC content. 

DLC: Map can be a little sparse and spread out in some areas. Even if there isn't anything to do, the empty area can be quite picturesque. Boss fights are significantly more challenging and interesting than the bosses in the base game.

Summary: This game is a must-have even if you do not intend on playing it much. This is one of those games perfect for playing in an apocalypse when you have way too much time to kill. Base game + DLC for the full experience. Replayability is excellent. The pricing on this game is extremely reasonable when compared against other games in the same price range. You will get your money's worth by purchasing this game because it is a 1000+ hour game.

Cons: Can be repetitive after you've 100%'d the game and have several completed runs under your belt. A lot of the game is traveling/running but the map is easy enough to navigate after gaining familiarity. Can seem like a difficult game at first but difficulty goes down with more hours spent playing the game. You may need to purchase a controller to enjoy the game because playing the game on keyboard and mouse feels weird.

10/10 game

[h3]The Positives[/h3]
• Gorgeous [b]visuals[/b] 
• Atmospheric [b]sound design[/b] 
• Exceptional [b]soundtrack[/b] 
• [b]Classic Souls gameplay[/b], refined and expanded 
• Profound [b]build variety[/b] with lots of viable playstyles 
• Mostly phenomenal [b]boss encounters[/b] 
•  Massive [b]open world[/b] 
• Challenging yet usually [b]fair and rewarding difficulty[/b] 
• Cryptic and highly engaging [b]lore[/b] 
• [b]Jaw-dropping moments[/b] on your first playthrough 


[h3]The Negatives[/h3]
• World is [b]too large[/b] with serious pacing issues in later regions 
• Second half relies on [b]recycled bosses, enemies and dungeons[/b] 
• Some [b]bosses[/b] are overtuned in ways that feel artificial 
• Several [b]questlines[/b] are easy to miss without a guide 


[h1]Verdict[/h1]
[u][b]A monumental and atmospheric action-RPG[/b][/u] with unforgettable moments, held back by pacing issues and recycled late-game content.
Worth it at a discount of 15-100% (0% = full price, 100% = free).

After playing this game as a solo and a duo I can confirm the game still makes you want to commit....  10/10 SOTE DLC makes the game somehow better than it already was.

Controls are straight crap, not intuitive at all. Would have enemies in front of me that wouldn't even get hit by attacks, just went through them. I requested a refund so fast. People talked this game up so much since it came out but didn't even meet the most basic expectations I had for it.

Open world is way too big and has barely anything worthwhile in it

Bosses like to waste your time with 15 sec combos with barely any punish windows as well as having straight up unreactable attacks

Whack balancing in terms of equipment (why would an int character use anything other than moonveil)

Exploration feels unrewarding with so many rewards being spirit ashes, crafting items or useless consumables

Game tends to reuse its content way too much

If you visited 1 type of an optional area (catacombs, mines, etc) than you visited 99% of others, the main difference being the loot you find in them (which is worthless most of the time)

The worst camera in any of the fromsoft games ive played (especially bad on big enemies)

Lock on targeting is way worse than in previous titles

Bad hitboxes (especially on the big enemies)

Sleep inducing mounted combat

Schizophrenic NPC quests

Max lvl weapon upgrades are still limited per playthrough

Left-handed weapons are still limited to only r1s

Technical issues (game randomly stutters/drops frames for no reason)

Abysmal netcode

Elden Ring is nothing short of a masterpiece—an extraordinary blend of breathtaking open-world design, stunning visual artistry, and deeply immersive storytelling. From the moment you set foot in the Lands Between, the sheer beauty of the world pulls you in. Every region feels handcrafted with love and imagination, from rolling golden fields and eerie swamps to haunting ruins and towering castles. Exploration never feels forced; the world quietly invites you to wander, discover, and get lost in its atmospheric charm.

The story, though subtle and mysterious, is absolutely fabulous. It unfolds like a grand myth, revealing itself piece by piece through encounters, item descriptions, and the world’s own history. The narrative invites curiosity and rewards attention, creating a sense of wonder rare in modern games. It’s a tale that sticks with you long after the final boss is defeated.

Elden Ring’s versatile playstyle is one of its greatest strengths. Whether you prefer brute strength, magic, stealth, archery, or a blend of everything, the game gives you the freedom to craft your own identity. Every weapon, spell, and build feels meaningful, and the flexibility ensures that no two players share the same journey. The combat is challenging yet fair, delivering some of the most exhilarating moments in gaming.

In every way, Elden Ring excels. It’s a game that celebrates exploration, creativity, and storytelling—an unforgettable experience that sets a new standard for open-world RPGs.

As a veteran of previous Soulslikes like Dark Souls and Bloodborne, I went in expecting pure punishment—and while it delivers in spots, it felt noticeably more approachable for me. After 100+ hours, I'd rate it a solid 9.5/10. 

It's not just a Souls game; it's a revolutionary open-world RPG. Let's break it down, spoiler-free! First, the world of the Lands Between is breathtaking and brutally immersive. It's a seamless open world where you can gallop on Torrent (your spectral steed) across vast landscapes, from golden plains to poisoned swamps and towering castles. Sites of Grace act as checkpoints, and here's the game-changer: you can often just run past enemies to reach the next one. 

No more dying 50 times to a single pack—explore freely, level up, and come back stronger. That said, forts, castles, and legacy dungeons hit like classic Souls levels: tight corridors, ambushes, and boss gates that demand precision. It's the perfect balance—freedom with teeth. Combat remains FromSoftware's gold standard: weighty, deliberate, and oh-so-rewarding. I focused on a Strength/Dexterity build with heavy Endurance and Vigor investment for survivability.

Early game, my Curved Greatsword was a beast—ripping through foes with slashing combos that felt unstoppable. But late-game? You adapt or die. Pierce weapons shine against armored behemoths, and status buildup becomes king. I leaned into frost and blood procs on glaives and polearms—freezing enemies to slow them, then bursting with hemorrhage for massive damage. The build variety is insane: respecc at Rennala, mix Ashes of War, slap on talismans, and experiment endlessly. Bosses like dragons and demigods require strategy—dodge rolls, parries, and pawn-like summons (your spectral steed helps too)—but victories feel earned.Difficulty-wise, it was easier for me thanks to Souls experience. 

Open-world progression lets you overlevel threats, grab OP gear early, and cheese paths. Newcomers might rage-quit, but vets get tools to tailor the challenge. No hand-holding, but golden guidance scars point you right.

Graphically stunning on PC, soundtrack epic, and replayability infinite with NG+. But overall? Peak FromSoft—exploration, combat, and build-crafting perfection.If you're a Souls fan or open-world lover, Elden Ring is essential.

Elden Ring is one of the most impressive games I have ever experienced. The open world feels huge, alive, and full of mysteries. Every location is unique, beautifully designed, and invites you to explore. The atmosphere ranges from mystical and calm to dark and overwhelming and that’s exactly what makes the game so captivating.

The soundtrack is absolutely masterful. The music fits perfectly in every situation, whether during exploration, intense boss fights, or quiet moments. It enhances the mood, builds tension, and often creates pure goosebumps.

The bosses are another major highlight. They are creatively designed, challenging, and incredibly epic in their presentation. Every fight feels like a special event. The lore and story, which gradually unfold, add a lot of depth and make the world even more fascinating.

For me, Elden Ring comes incredibly close to being a perfect game. It’s very near to what I would call a truly flawless and outstanding experience.

Elden Ring is an absolute masterpiece full of atmosphere, excitement, and unforgettable moments. A clear recommendation.

Elden Ring was the first soulslike game I ever completed 100% — all achievements, every boss, every corner of the map explored. No other game has ever pulled me in the way Elden Ring did: I kept telling myself “just one more area, just one more boss,” and suddenly dozens of hours had disappeared. The world, the lore, the music, and that feeling of overcoming impossible fights made it feel less like a game and more like a long, epic journey.

Now it feels like Miyazaki has “hooked” me into trying to finish every Souls game at 100%, because nothing else gives the same mix of challenge and satisfaction. Elden Ring didn’t just become one of my favorite games — it set a new standard for what I expect from action RPGs.
Nihil Nihil Nihil

Elden Ring Walkthrough:

*Spawn in.
*Go to Dragon Burnt Ruins.
*Open the chest underground.
*Get out of the Crystal Tunnel.
*Go to Caelem Ruins and head North-West from there.
*Find the carriage with chest in it.
*Open the chest. (However, be aware, courage is required.)
*Profit.

I'm sorry; I tried really hard to like this game. I've tried to like all of Fromsoft's games ever since Dark Souls 1, and this just doesn't have the same punch.

It's open world nonsense, repeated ad nausem. And for people who say each thing is unique, it's not. You'll see the same cabin over and over again. Sometimes It'll have the little offshoot building, sometimes it won't, sometimes it'll be mirrored, but it's the same damn cabin. It's the same camp. It's the same interiors of dungeons, just the layout is different. The same stalactites, the same patterns on the walls. Even the BOSSES repeat. I think there's... maybe a dozen BOSSES that don't repeat, out of... We got to Farum Azula and just... gave up. But all the content and side stuff beforehand. Even the first major boss has a repeat later. Yeah, the name is different, but the mechanics, movement, and model are exact (fine, the model is translucent, but that doesn't count. It shouldn't count!)

You fight one thing, you're pretty much GOING to see it again. And having to grind over and over for items to join up with my wife, and other things was just... unfun. And don't get me started on the random disconnects!

We booted up DS1 again, and there's STILL enough of a playerbase where we got invaded a decent amount of times. And you know what? I'm with them. I'd rather play DS1 again then this.

It's a challenging game that takes some persistence to get into. The fun in the game for me comes from learning the bosses' attack patterns and learning to dodge/parry at the right times. I find the open world to be somewhat of a drawback in subsequent playthroughs, when you just want to fight the bosses and not do all the content, but is a lot of fun to explore the first time around because there are a lot of things to collect. A boss run mode in New Game + would be a welcome addition to the franchise.

Going into this game I had some high expectations, and I am proud to say that it surpassed them all. This game by all means has some issues because pretty much no game out there is flawless. Some bosses suck, some things are buggy, "Quests" are kinda fucked because they're very easy to miss or fuck up blind, and balance is absolutely horrible (You're kinda forced to balance your power and enemy scaling yourself). But generally? This game is one hell of a masterpiece.

This game is amazing. Started kind of bummed out because of how weak I was at the beginning, so i quit for like a month. I couldn't refund it though so i came back and tried exploring a little more. Now i have played the entire game twice and i still have only scratched the surface of what this game has to offer. Also it doesn't help that the starting area is so dark and gloomy, but trust me the game gets beautiful.

Be prepared to spend the first 10-20 hours reading up anything about the game. Even how to aim a crossbow will require you to watch a youtube video, because it is never explained in game and requires 5 button presses. 
The pouch (quickslots) stopped working after 3 hours, so you would have to enter the menu and use the item from there and the menu does not pause the game, so basically you cannot use any item in fight.
Did not fix itself after restart, it's just broken now.
And the menu itself is painfully implemented. There are no tooltips whatsoever, it's like it was programmed 20 years ago. No tooltip what any stats do(only at level up), to see an explanation of the inherent skill of a weapon you can't see it in the gear screen, only in inventory after you use the "switch view" button, again no tooltip.

Many (small) enemies I encountered are very easy and in between there is here and there one boss enemy that is extremely difficult or often impossible with your current gear/level, you just don't have any indication about it beforehand. So you have to die to learn that. Often and everywhere.

I get it's supposed to be a hard game, but I fought mostly the controls, and the bosses, well maybe if you spend hours learning how fast every attack animation of the boss is you might time a dodge right? Some take long, some very long, some very fast and your own dodge is very slow (even with only medium weight equipped) so you have to just KNOW when the attack will land, you cannot SEE it. If I want to learn so many facts I will learn something useful like a new language, not timings. Let me dodge if I am fast enough to react. 

The lore may be hidden somewhere in item descriptions I have been told. The videos ingame tell you almost nothing.
