TLDR: Game is amazing, but Easy Anti Cheat is a piece of garbage that can crash your PC when launching.

This is the best souls game that I've played, and it ain't even close. Haven't played Bloodborne yet, so we'll put that into a little box. The open world does have a lot of copy paste, but most of it is decent and the main locations are great. Side locations can be really simple Bethesda tier dungeons, and others can be really creative and have a curveball at the end. The main locations are really good, and have many more unique elements to them than the simple caves, mines and crypts. Less tedious level design compared to DS1, and the enemies feel more fair than DS3, not that that game was always unfair feeling to me. The controls are amazing. A jump button can go a long way in games like this.

With all that being said, holy fk. I HATE Easy Anti Cheat. I hate it more than Denuvo (just hurts performance and nothing else. I hate it more than nProtect (not my favorite but still ok). Riot used some black magic when making Vanguard (doesn't crash lol). Easy Anti Cheat randomly crashes your PC when launching this game if it errors in any way. This can be before the game opens. This can be after the game opens and you're in the middle of the opening titles. This can be in a loading screen. It's even more likely if you tab over to your web browser and so much as click one thing. I have never encountered this much consistent crashing in a game, ever. I looked around and it can be due to applications conflicting with each other, "hardware problems" or "outdated drivers". It is the first one, without a doubt. My hardware is ok. My drivers are ok. No other game does this. I've had one or two other games crash on startup this year. Other games with Easy Anti Cheat. Funny. 

The fixes are to run the game or Easy Anti Cheat in the game files as administrator. Still happens. Repair tool for Easy Anti Cheat. Still happens. Verifying game files. Still happens. This piece of garbage needs to be fixed someday. Unacceptable that an anti cheat can crash a relatively healthy PC that isn't under load more than a few times. Besides, why should I need anti cheat when I play these kinds of games offline? Not Steam offline mode, but offline in the game settings. They shouldn't give a flying fk about anti when you're not engaging with any other players.

TLDR: Elden ring is a beautiful game where tremendous effort was made on its presentation.
The gameplay is whatever results when the artistic vision is realized.
How much you like this game greatly depends on how much you value appearance over gameplay.

Early 3D games had all sorts of problems with camera positioning,
but clever developers have solved all of these problems by now.
FromSoftware is uniquely positioned in that they haven't figured it out yet.
There are many reviews complaining about not being able to see what's happening because of how the camera works,
but more intelligent players understand that FromSoft is appealing to the nostalgia of boomers
that remember what games were like in the 90's and long for simpler times.

Quests in this game are refreshingly structured and all follow the following formula:
I don't know where I am going, not telling you what I expect of you.
So please look up my quest on the wiki and talk to me in the next location mentioned there.

Later stages of the game have many bosses that are so gigantic that attacking them means your entire screen is filled with feet.
It's another brilliant move by FromSoft to be inclusive to feet fetishists,
a niche that is egregiously underserved in gaming, as haele 3D just doesn't have enough feet for us.

Whereas FromSoft revolutionized gaming by introducing tough but fair fights with Dark souls,
we don't need another rehash of a combat system that has already been milked dry.
As usual FromSoft treads new ground by removing all the fun game and seeing if you can still git gud?
The game was designed like a mathematical limit, where the closer you get to the end of the game,
the more the game strives to erode your motivation to keep playing it.
Out with rewarding skill development and mastery, in with the boredom and frustration maximization.
Playing the game feels like working on a job you have already long grown tired of.
Where in dark souls you lose your humanity in-game, in elden ring you lose your soul in real life.
They took the novel approach of not playtesting the last 20% of the game.
And that's what makes it so great!

Maybe fromsoft just got tired of all of the players that keep yelling:
"I've platinumed every single FromSoft game"
and used that as an argument of validity to their criticsm.
Here's Malenia, platinum that!

FromSoft truly opened my eyes to a wider world.
I now believe that the pinnacle of game design is adding a boss to the game so difficult,
that so many players summon another player to do it for them instead,
that the player that others summon actually becomes famous for it.
I never would have thought of game design from that angle before Elden Ring.

Other innovations include Elden ring's increasing emphasis on verticality,
but still having the controls of a game where the world is flat.
Running into the smallest step known to man stops you dead in your tracks.
You can see your foot going higher than the step, yet you stay stuck dancing the running man.
When rolling backwards these ledges will teach you brand new insights into physics.

Some of the design choices are refreshingly devious.
Smithing stones are sold all the way on the other side of the round table hold as the smith.
You can't put a currently equiped weapon into the stash,
so every time you try out a new weapon and put it in the stash you get to curse at the developers.

Grab attacks are amongst the most hated mechanics in souls likes.
So FromSoft made sure to use the mechanic exhaustively and even the weakest of mobs now have grab attacks.
In fact, how about sending huge armies of gank at the player, all of which execute grab attacks?
FromSoft brilliantly builds upon that by making the animation for getting up the slowest one ever to sit through.
Even I don't take that long to get up in the morning, but this chad takes his time in the middle of combat.

By the time you get to the end of the game, you will start dreaming about fromsoft.
I still remember vividly seeing Miyazaki and his clan dancing around me in circles wiggling their middle fingers.

Jokes aside, I've never been this bored and frustrated while playing a game, but I still worked through it.
I beat every single boss in the game once and I platinumed the game.
And the most rewarding part of it all is that I never have to play this game again.
10/10 game a must play for anyone!

"Elden Ring is a masterful blend of intricate world-building, engaging storytelling, and challenging gameplay that keeps players coming back for more. From the moment you step into the stunning landscapes of The Lands Between, you are captivated by the breathtaking visuals and rich lore crafted by Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R.R. Martin.

The open-world design offers a sense of freedom and exploration that is rare in modern gaming. Players can tackle challenges in any order, allowing for personalized gameplay experiences. The combat system is both satisfying and challenging, with a variety of weapons and abilities that encourage players to experiment and find their unique playstyle.

The character designs and enemy encounters are meticulously crafted, providing a perfect blend of difficulty and reward. Each victory feels earned, and the game’s numerous secrets and hidden areas invite curiosity and exploration.

Elden Ring also excels in creating an immersive atmosphere, with an exceptional soundtrack and environmental storytelling that pulls you deeper into its world. Whether you're a fan of action RPGs or new to the genre, Elden Ring promises an unforgettable adventure that will resonate long after you've put down the controller.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for a thrilling and expansive gaming experience!"

I'd never played a Souls-themed game before. I knew the genre was difficult and I didn't enjoy it. I saw a friend playing Elden Ring for the first time, and he invited me to try it with him through the smooth co-op mode. I went into the game with a preconceived notion of how bad it would be, so I kept noticing flaws simply because I was focused on finding them. But the more I played, the more the game world surprised me.

The world feels endless. Every time you think you've reached the end, you stumble across new locations, secret areas, and enemies you've never encountered before. The enemy variety is amazing; each area has its own unique set of foes. The only other game I've seen this level of diversity is Hollow Knight. Furthermore, the landscapes are a masterpiece. The game offers a wide range of weapons, armor, and building options, whether you prefer to be a mage, a fighter, an archer, or anything else entirely, which adds a great deal of depth to the gameplay.

I finished the game with my friend, but later I replayed it on my own. That's when I started noticing some drawbacks. After my first experience, I tried other games of the same genre, such as Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, Dark Souls III, and Dark Souls. Compared to these games, Elden Ring was surprisingly easy, especially after the developers released updates. My second attempt was easier, but not as enjoyable. I defeated the toughest bosses on my first try, but some enemies were able to hit me through walls. Sometimes, even the regular enemies you encountered would attack me the moment I entered the arena, which was frustrating during the entrance scene.

I also completed the downloadable content, and honestly, I regret buying it. It doesn't offer much for $26. I know it's just an add-on, but at that price, it should have offered something more valuable, especially compared to Silksong, which offered a lot for only $7.

Overall, I'd rate Elden Ring an 8/10. It's a great game and worth playing, regardless of its DLC. It's a game worth trying.

It's definitely a very good game, but unfortunately it's not one I can be a fan of.

This is one of the first Souls-like games I've ever played. If this is yours too, I will tell you now, it's a different experience from any other genre of gaming. Instead of expecting success and rewards from it, you get the opposite. More failures is more rewarding than you think it is, even if it means punching a wall or breaking something, you learn from your mistakes. This game is one of a kind, it changed the way I've viewed games. Winning is not everything, winning is only a good feeling. Failing is a better feeling that makes winning feel more rewarding and celebrating. It teaches you a lesson of life. Failure. If you can't beat a boss in ELDEN RING, you're not a failure, you're only not giving up from there. If you're going through something tough in life, you're not a failure, you're only not giving up from there. You will win. It takes blood and tears to win in life and in ELDEN RING, but trust me, it will be worth it in the end.

This game and many other souls-like games have saved many people's lives from mental illnesses such as severe depression. It taught them that if they can beat something that took lots of work and effort to beat, they can take on anything in life and [h1]WIN[/h1]

[h1]It's tough, but not over.[/h1]

The base game is a good middle ground for players who want to challenge themselves, but don't want to reach a point where they either have to persevere or give up, as is the case with the Dark Souls series, for example. The open world makes it possible to avoid an overly strong opponent and return at a later point in time. There are also so-called ‘ghost ashes’, which represent summonings in battles that can make a difficult fight much easier. This makes the difficulty level more accessible.

The DLC is good, but a little harder than the base game.

As usual with FromSoftware games, the story is not very transparent, but rather has to be pieced together bit by bit. However, this results in a moderate story that, while not captivating me personally, did not disappoint me either. 

The graphics and soundtrack are well done and provide a fitting atmosphere for the different areas of the game. The immense size of the world contains many secret areas, items, NPCs and bosses that are a joy to discover. 

The PC controls also worked well.

The combat system offers many different ways to defeat your opponents, which suits the different preferences of the players. 

It didn't take much grinding to achieve all the achievements, which I found pleasant. 

It has a high replay value and is worth the full price.

Elden Ring DLC Review: It’s So GOOD and So GODDAMN INFURIATING!

Okay, let’s start with the good: Elden Ring is a masterpiece. It’s absolutely worth buying the DLC, no question. The world-building is chef’s kiss. The open world, the lore, the bosses—it all hits differently than anything else out there right now. The way the DLC expands on the already staggering universe? Pure magic. New areas? Insane. New enemies? Wild. But here’s the kicker: the bosses.

Now, here’s where my patience starts fraying like a rope after a marathon of frustration. FromSoft has done what they do best: they’ve created bosses so fucking hard, you’ll want to throw your controller into the goddamn void. And I mean hard in the way that makes you question everything you’ve ever known about your own existence. Your reflexes? Ruined. Your sanity? Shredded. That one boss that just sits there looking at you, and then out of nowhere slams you into oblivion for the fiftieth time? Yeah, I’m still salty.

Look, the difficulty is part of the charm for a lot of people. It’s what makes Elden Ring Elden Ring, right? But holy hell, sometimes I wonder if they just want us to suffer for fun. They know they’ve built a challenge that’s nearly sadistic, and yet… I can’t stop playing. I’m addicted. I keep going back. Even as I rage so hard I could probably break something, I’m still here, asking for more punishment. And the rewards are worth it—but goddamn, the cost is high.

In the end, this DLC is so fucking good that you’ll keep playing, even after your entire being wants to rage-quit, fist-pump your way through a wall, and never look at a FromSoft title again. But hey, if you’re a masochist who loves the idea of repeatedly smashing your face against an unyielding wall of difficulty, then yes—BUY THE DLC. You won’t regret it… or maybe you will, but you’ll keep playing anyway.

Elden Ring was the first game I ever platinumed, and for a long time I considered it the peak of gaming. After exploring other titles, it has not aged as flawlessly for me, but I still hold it in high regard and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a true open world experience. Unlike games that feel empty or overly curated, Elden Ring delivers scale, density, and meaningful exploration.

The world is rich in story, but the game does not convey its narrative in a traditional way. Most of the lore must be pieced together through item descriptions, environmental clues, and supplementary YouTube explanations. Without that extra effort, you are often left unsure of what is happening or why. The absence of quest markers adds to the sense of freedom, but it also makes it very easy to lock quests, miss key items, or unknowingly cut yourself off from certain endings.

In terms of difficulty, I never found the game overwhelming. The only encounter that felt significantly demanding was Messmer in the DLC. The game allows you to farm levels freely and exploit a variety of strategies that make many bosses manageable. I am a dexterity-focused player and used one katana (Nagakiba) for most of the game. I parried Malenia on my first attempt, which is why I find it amusing that some content creators dramatize dozens or hundreds of attempts using mage builds.

The build system is another point of friction. While the number of options is impressive, it can be stressful to navigate such a wide range of possibilities. A more intuitive structure would have made experimentation less overwhelming.

Graphically, the game is solid, but it is not exceptional. Older titles like God of War (2018) still surpass it visually, especially on PC.

Despite its flaws, Elden Ring is absolutely worth playing. It offers a unique sense of discovery and scale that few games achieve. Just avoid turning it into your entire identity. Step away, get some perspective, and enjoy it alongside other great titles.

I received 12 surgeries and possibly will have another soon, and have been bed ridden for over two years. Thank you Fromsoft and thank you to the community for unknowingly walking this road with me with a ton of support, tips, secrets, etc... I will always remember those moments.. I couldn't put into words how much these developers helped me escape and never come back, I will always support this company and community

Elden Ring felt like it’s the culmination of all FromSoftware games that came before it. It’s everything they learned from them and more. If you’ve played other FromSoftware games, you’ll stumble upon a lot of familiar things, scenarios, locations, enemies, bullshit, and they took all that and put it in a huge open world map.

The map itself is vague. If you like the “zero hands holding” approach, this is your game. Not only do you not know what to do next, but things are hard as they are in your average souls experience, you wander into the wrong neighborhood, and there goes all your runes.

This is the most polished experience from the series. It’s visually beautiful and beautifully crafted, the world has much variety, some copy pasted landmarks but also lots of unique places with good interiors and architecture. I know some people complain that some enemies repeat, but even with that, there are tons of variety in this aspect as well.

Unlocked new fear of insects, centipedes, ants, fingers? They replaced spiders with fingers, and I don't know which is worse now... 

I have mixed feelings about the gameplay. For most people, they nailed the combat in this one, and it's true, but there are some annoying things. 

Unlike DS2, you can attack and dodge quite a lot before running out of stamina, which promotes faster gameplay, and that's usually what people seek and enjoy. To balance that, bosses also unleash a fury of successive fast attacks, and sometimes the window during which you can attack without being punished is really small, so the fight ends up with more downtime (defense time) than attacking, and that can be boring. 

I'm not talking about op builds and cheeses, those exist, but I'm speaking of a normal first playthrough experience. 

It feels like mobs don't have a stamina bar as u do. That was a nice feature from Nioh, being able to see the enemy's stamina bar. 

Another issue is how huge bosses are, now it's not new, but man, it's becoming ridiculous. I know people loove to fight big bosses, but I use M&K because I like complete camera control, and even then, I don't even see all the boss. Some fights I don't see the hit because it's impossible to have all the boss within the camera frame, neither by locking the view nor by unlocking it. 

Other than that, I absolutely love the animations, the weapon variety, the spell effects, the class variety, and mix and matching, all the new features are fun to play with. 

On a more personal note, even though this game has everything, even things from previous souls games, more features, more work into it, I still think that experiencing similar features was more iconic in previous titles. If you're new to the genre, this game is a fantastic place to start. It has everything, and it's modern, but for me, I still find DS1 to be the most iconic and the most beautiful journey, but maybe cause I played it first, we will never know.

When I first played this game I sat down on my balls and broke my chair. I can't beat the Soldier of Godrick, I can't find any "Elden Rings," and I can't romance any female NPC's. Why are they even in the game? This game requires an incomprehensible amount of button inputs to play, LESS IS MORE. I think I shattered my hand trying to roll when I was BUSHWACKED by some bandits. My character can't seem to talk?

As my first game of the genre, it is memorable and I took my time, mostly exploring the gorgeous world.  I am glad to have used a guide for some parts and I did save scum endings (I'm a working adult ain't nobody got time for that) they were nice, albeit mostly short. 

I would recommend anyone who has the time to delve into the game and enjoy its mechanics play, regardless of the "git gud" sentiment. How one spends their free time is up to them because we all have free agency :) 

Despite how big the game is though, certain mechanics like madness spells are lore relevant and important, but fizzle out too quickly. The entire plotline and mechanics surrounding it are cool, and supposed to be powerful, but at the end of the day are not.  It's also frustrating to say that my favorite boss (Radahn) lore wise is INCREDIBLY powerful, but his boss fight is so weak. There is a disconnect because mechanics that are hyped up to be strong, yet fall short by miles. When you engage with the world and create expectations based on what characters are saying, only for them to be dashed it does take away from the game.

I will say the second half of the game is primarily a boss rush and that took away from the hundred+ hours of exploration, as I was just fighting the same boss on repeat. For the genre of the game, it makes sense, but I think it takes away from the overall experience. 

I spent many hours dying and running around looking at how in-depth the world and its zone were. From the empty fields of Limgrave, toxic pools of Caelid, ruined lakes of Liurnia, desolate volcano of Altus, shining brillance turned ashen capital Leyndell, supernatural underground zones, freezing storms of Snowfield, and crumbling ancient architecture of Farum Azula, there is character. So much character it feels awful getting into the second half of the game that has much smaller zones that feel like just large dungeons. 

In a world of happy endings, Elden Ring rarely has a quest end positively. It does help build the world as a dark and depressive environment, where people are forced to make the best with what little they have. My first quest ever involved a blind girl at a cart asking me to find her father in a castle and the result made me sad. The writing is there, but you can tell what George influenced. He has the capacity for a great fantasy setting, but likes to write some morally messed up story lines, especially with Marika/Radagon. 

The DLC will be played another day, but as someone who tried to do everything, it is a lot and was a great journey. My attacks had "oomph" and the possibilities to spec your build into something unholy is always an attractive option. Enjoy the freedom of the system and what the game has to offer yourself.

This game is great but the constant freezing issue on modern hardware and the multiplayer being unnecessarily clunky makes me give it a negative review. Other than that if they can fix the freezing then this game is a great single player game.

If your goal is to have a good time and mess around with friends - the purchase of the game is a nobrainer.
if your goal is to explore and do 100% of the shit, this game will probably suit you.
If your goal is to solo it, do quest, learn the lore etc - this game is not for you. 

Sadly, the latter is the exact reason why I picked this one, and after 60h in on the second attempt at a playthrough, I got bored as fuck (got bored the 1st time, too) of running around killing mobs, looting garbage, grinding, and getting none the wiser about the world, lore, quests (had to install a mod to keep track, srsly?).

All in all, the open (but dull and essentially empty) world, supposedly brilliant writing (that is hardly present in the game), repetitiveness, 99% garbage loot, and grind eventually took it out of me.

The graphics are nice and the game world is well-designed, this much I'll admit, but if you want a good souls-like that will not bore you to hell, do yourself a favor and get LOTF2.

Pretty good ngl, easiest for those trying to get into the souls series since it is my first souls (I've played all the others too and this is easily my favorite with 1000+ hours on console). The first playthrough should be blind or partially blind in case you get lost, other than that I recommend that you go for one type of build instead of spreading your stats across the board (Health > Stamina > Str/Dex/fai/Int). For the best experience (after your first run) imo is to run a basic straightsword or greatsword with nice shield and then try and learn all the bosses. It is extremely hard ofc but its honestly my favorite way to play since winning feels better than any other achievement in life. Just you, your sword, and your shield against this unfair world of monsters. Remember this if you feel like the worst player to touch a game... no human is able to beat these monsters in real life, that is the point, you are not human for you are the tarnished, chosen to defy death and come back to life and retry the bosses all over again, don't get greedy as the bosses never become slower, they never change their movesets or counters. Die.Learn.Destroy.

The first part of the game until you get past the capital is incredible. The game stumbles a bit after, with over-tuned and overused enemies. You can clearly tell fromsoft put a lot of time and effort into the game leading up to the capital, and the rest afterwards was a bit more rushed and less methodical. 
The late-game one-shot potential of ordinary enemies, especially ones that are reused is my main critique. For me at least, I just end up avoiding a lot of fights in the late game vs feeling a meaningful and enjoyable increase in difficulty. The late game bosses are a bit over-tuned I felt as well, with some feeling like sekiro enemies, while you are stuck with ER mechanics. 
On another note, the game is in dire need of a quest log or something of the sort. Trying to navigate some storylines is near impossible without a guide. You should just have the ER wiki ready to go when you load up the game and accept using it. 

Overall, 9/10. The game is utterly beautiful and chopped full of content, but definitely has its weak points.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐ A Masterpiece in Every Sense — Elden Ring Sets a New Standard

Elden Ring isn’t just a game. It’s an experience that sticks with you long after you turn it off. From the moment you step into the Lands Between, you realize you’re playing something truly special. The world is massive, mysterious, beautiful, and terrifying all at once — and none of it feels empty. Every corner hides a secret, every horizon pulls you in, and every enemy demands respect.

The combat is brutal but fair, and the boss fights are some of the most unforgettable encounters I’ve ever had in any game. The sense of achievement after overcoming a tough challenge is unmatched. The game never holds your hand, but it constantly rewards curiosity, patience, and skill.

The atmosphere, music, lore, characters… everything comes together perfectly. It’s dark, epic, emotional, and full of moments that feel legendary. I genuinely felt like I was carving my own story.

Elden Ring isn’t just my favorite FromSoftware game — it’s one of the greatest games ever made. If you’re hesitating, don’t. Just dive in and let the world consume you.

10/10 — A modern classic.
absolute unit of a game only bitches will regret buying

Feels unreal that this game exists.
It blew all expectations I had out of the water.
Its world, so compelling and enormous. Its art direction, ubelievable.
It has impossible variety and depth in weapons, playstyles, enemies, attack patterns, ashes of war and more.

The open world feels like such a natural and organic evolution seeing how well it is used.
Level design, more complex and surprising than ever. The exploration you will naturally do helps showcase that constantly.
Exploring the Lands Between is an incredible experience and the first time you do is the most special, so just go in blind and get lost, don't spoil anything for yourself.

The story, the world, the fantasy, its characters, bosses and their story, all equally opaque, majestic and grandiose at the same time.

It all feels like leaps forward and upward from previous games and I think it will be hard to go back.

Besides all the gushing praise, it sadly didn't run great. Maybe a 5000 series GPU problem, but the fact remains that the fps rarely felt like 60, it was fluctuating and there was microstuttering probably contributing to that. Some areas didn't exhibit this problem however.

It plays fine on keyboard and mouse which is what I used, but requires some rebinding, the defaults won't be comfortable for anyone.

On the whole, it's a remarkable game, one very hard to be repeated or replicated.

Honestly i wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. As a big Castlevania fan, the bosses are simply not hard enough. Most of your deaths are going to be from random enemies who the devs decided they can one shot you for some reason. And then you fall on some clunky ledge and you lose all your runes.

There's so much great about this game, and so much terrible!  The great:[list]
[*]Combat is great!  It's got depth, it's challenging, and mostly it's fair.  There's a big variety of enemies (though they still get a little repetitive thanks to the sheer size of the game) and a huge variety of weapons to kill them with.
[*]Exploration is about as good as it gets.  Any cliff could have a ledge below it you might jump down to.  A large tree could be hiding a door into a cave.  Illusionary walls seemed a bit cheap at first, but there are often 'tells' like sounds coming from the other side of them.  Entire maps can be hidden away where many players can miss them!  Note that the online option can spoil this badly, though.  It's hardly a secret door when there are half a dozen messages around it telling you it's there.
[*]Art direction is great, too.  Technically, the graphics don't seem to be using the most advanced technology, but the artists did very well with what they had.
[*]Boss fights are well done.  When you beat a boss, it typically won't take even five minutes.  Of course, many of them will require some experimentation, which does mean dying and starting again a few times, but there will also be some you're particularly well suited for that will finish on your first try.  Battles against dragons can take longer, but they're also incredibly good fights with the dragons flying off a short distance and breathing fire (or whatever) at you.
[/list]

On the not-so-good side:[list]
[*]Quests.  Yeeesh!  I guess the fun of the quests came in the early days when the game was released, and the community was working together to figure them out.  If you want to follow them yourself, you'll NEED to look up guides because the NPCs have a habit of moving around a lot - and I don't mean just from one side of town to another.  The rewards, if there are any, can be pretty weak or really strong... unless it doesn't fit your build, which it often will not.
[*]Story.  There IS a story in this game, but you have to dig it out by reading item descriptions and thinking about what you're seeing.  If you're an investigative reporter or historian, you'll like sifting it out.  For everyone else... lots of hassle for very little reward.
[*]You know how those old JRPGs before, oh, 2005 or so would always make you keep talking to an NPC over and over until their dialog repeats to find out everything they want to say?  FromSoft still thinks it's a good idea.
[*]There's zero lip syncing, too.  NPCs jaws just flap away until they finish.
[*]Tone is incredibly bleak.  Could somebody please be happy!?  Preferably not because you ripped off some poor sod's skin.
[*]Every time you gain a level you get to add one point to one statistic.  You'll likely gain a good 130+ levels over the course of the game so you will definitely advance in power, but every step is tiny.  For me, at least, that takes away some of the fun.  I like to be able to see a difference after gaining a level - maybe not a big one, but something I can at least notice.
[/list]

The game's difficulty isn't quite what I thought.  If you die, you drop all your runes.  Runes are money in this game, but keep in mind that gaining levels costs runes.  They will stay roughly where you died and, as long as you come back and pick them up before dying again, there's no penalty except for the time it took you to get from the last save point to that location.  So, when you see a challenge ahead, you're going to very much want to put it off until just after you buy a level or otherwise deplete your rune count.

The game is a one-save-only style game.  As such, you'll want to back up your save just in case something goes wrong.  I never heard of any game bugs corrupting a save, but computers can do weird things, and it only takes a few seconds.  The game saves itself very often quitting the game will save in that spot.  I wouldn't try doing it in the middle of a boss fight, but those fights almost always end inside of five minutes.  The game won't do well if you need to quit at any second, but if you can get 5 minutes notice, you should be fine.

All in all, I very much enjoyed the game.  I [b]really[/b] loved the exploration.  (If you're an explorer type gamer, don't worry too much about the difficulty - you'll spend so much time exploring everything that you'll be over-levelled soon enough.)  People that love deep action combat should try the game, too.  If you're more into the stories that RPGs can tell, though, this isn't your game.

I never could get a grasp on souls-likes before Elden Ring. They always frustrated me because you couldn't do anything except bang your head against the same wall (boss) until you defeat it and hit the next wall, or stop playing. 

This is the first souls-like I completed. The #1 thing that let me stick it out was the fact that there is always something else to do if you find a boss you can't deal with at the moment. The #2 thing that really made me fall in love was the fact you can be a true tank despite the purists poo-pooing that playstyle. 

There's also nothing wrong with throwing in an mod making you very overpowered, because experiencing the sense of wonder the game provides is plenty worth it. I got my friend to play with me in the co-op mod, and even with his absolute hatred towards souls-likes he proceeded to fall in love just as I did. 

It still has classic, chunky, weighty combat that takes a bit of getting used to. But once I got a hang of it, it allowed me to transition to other souls games and have a much better time understanding the language of the game (even if I haven't beaten most of them. The linear nature of the other ones still drives me nuts).

No vote in order to bring it closer to what I think it should be. Game is maybe 7/10, especially for a souls game. The trouble with it is that's extremely bloated and far overstays its welcome by drawing things out. It's an enormous kiddie pool with a lot of empty space and not a lot of depth. What you end up with is an experience where you spend most of your time traveling without a lot of action, hit up the necessary bosses and encounters, and make a few pit stops along the way for the things you need while ignoring the roughly 80% of the bland, recycled, and obnoxious filler. There's some 400 weapons and of those weapons maybe 10-20% ever get used. Bosses get repeated often and minor locations are very dull and uninteresting. 

The pacing is also incredibly bi-polar. The first few locations are a breeze, Things pick up a little bit at a time getting into the middle of the game, around the point where you're getting through the capitol. After that things dive off a cliff. Bosses start becoming extremely unforgiving with 9 hit wombo combos, massively inflated damage, and speed and mobility that make them a miserable chore to fight. Regular enemies too gain a jump in health, damage, and poise making them suck considerably more. I've completed this game several times now and every time I want to do a run through I hit a wall right after the capitol where my motivation to continue drops because I remember how unpleasant the last chunk is. There are some exceptions but largely the last third feels rushed and poorly tuned.

This was my first FromSoft game, and probably one of my top ten games in general. Super fun once you get the hang of it, and I really really love delving into the lore of it all. Certainly a good start if you're looking to try a Souls game or soulslike, but don't know where to start. The open world aspect means you can leave and come back later if you feel stuck on a boss or area, so you aren't forced to fight something if you aren't having a great time. Of course, that doesn't mean it's easy; it's still a hard game, no matter where you go, but the option to go wherever you want (for the most part) makes it a fun experience. Also very fun to read messages from other people, and leave some of your own. Dog ahead :)

A World That Pulls You In...
Hours Played: 21.4 hrs (at time of review)
Recommended? 👍 Yes

After 21.4 hours, I can confidently say Elden Ring is one of the most immersive experiences I’ve had in gaming. The world feels alive — every corner hides something worth discovering, whether it’s a new boss, a hidden dungeon, or just breathtaking scenery. The combat is punishing but fair, and every victory feels earned.
What really stands out is the freedom: you’re never forced down a single path. I’ve spent hours just exploring, finding my own way, and still feel like I’ve only scratched the surface. The sense of scale and mystery keeps me hooked, and I’m loving every moment.
If you enjoy challenging combat, deep lore, and a world that rewards curiosity, Elden Ring is absolutely worth it.

I'm gonna start a review chain on how much I've played the game. For context I haven't played a single Dark Souls game, but I have played A LOT of hard games (most notably both Hollow Knights and 700 hours of Terraria Infernum, which are all hard games with you having to learn the attacks of enemies and bosses). Spoiler warning and I hope I have a long, infuriating and rewarding adventure so I can make this chain giant :).

0 hours - I started a knight build, because I don't know anything about the game and want some gear to help me get a good start. It will probably be super fun to replay the game with different builds like classes in Terraria.

6 hours - I am still in the very early game, since I cannot really beat the first boss, Margit. I have decided after looking for some beginner advice to explore other areas and get stronger that way. For now I have a sword (I forgor the name) that has spinning slash as a strong attack and have upgraded it with two smithing upgrades from some swordsmith in a grace world that Melina took me to. I then found some portal-ish thing that brought me to a fight with Bloodhound Darriwil. Super fun fight to learn, took me like 15 minutes to kill and dropped a very good sword... which I can't equip because it requires a bigger strength and dexterity level :(.

Definetly a 10/10 game, no doubt.
One of the most fleshed out and awesome combat systems in the history of gaming. And it's not as difficult as people say. There are lots of ways to make your game easier, like summons. And if you're stuck on a boss for too long, you can also ask for help from other players. (But don't do that, that'll ruin your experience).
The graphics have become drastically better, than ones of its predeccessors. It's not dark and depressing anymore, don't trust the trailers. Although, that is a two-edged sword, as the game isn't optimized really well. It's pretty CPU and RAM heavy so you'll pretty might not be able to play while having many other programs open depending on your device (or just will have to close everything except the game like me).
Many try to say it's worse than dark souls, which in my opinion is just OGs coping. Dark souls is a wonderful series, although it's over a decade old, with the latest release being like a decade old too now. Elden Ring expands on Dark Soul's mechanics, adding stuff like jumping or making magic fun for once (even tho i was a dex build).
People, who dislike the open world are genuinely weird to me. The beauty of soulslikes is exploration. And imo this genre fits the game.
The voice actors did a great job, with me still not being able to forget some of them.
The game hyped so much that many try to roast it hard. And that ain't fair. The game is wonderful.
The cons are:
- The optimization is honestly meh.
- Even though the narrative and quests are awesome, the endings feel lackluster. Most of them just show a different tree in the end cutscene, that's how they're different. And you will get rolled back to the state of the game before you got the ending after. And these lackluster endings are one ending per playthrough. That's no big deal, but that's just stupid, because you can't get another ending. Let's take hollow knight. There you can get every ending per playthrough, so the rollbacks make sense. P.S. I just want my platinum, why do I need 2 extra playthroughs for it?

The dungeons, castles and many level designs are fantastic with depth to them and various obstacles to resolve and conquer. Many secret areas to find and places to explore.

I enjoyed a lot of the combat and the game offers you a variety of ways to dispatch your enemies from many hand to hand combat weapons, to magic or distance attacks. The game lets you get creative.

A lot of people complain the game "freezes" or stutters.  Here is the solution: The game runs at 60fps... Ensure your monitor is set to 60Hz refresh, change all nvidia settings in your panel for performance and also cap the fps at 60. Ensure all Vsync/Gsync settings are set within nvidia and on your actual display. Works flawlessly.

The game isn't perfect but it is a great game.

Masterpiece of a Game ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

I’ve poured 252 hours into Elden Ring and can proudly say I’ve defeated every single boss, including the secret optional one. This isn’t just a game—it’s an experience, a sprawling RPG that perfectly balances challenge, freedom, and storytelling.

From the hauntingly beautiful world design to the sheer depth of combat, every corner of the Lands Between feels purposeful. Exploration is endlessly rewarding, whether you’re uncovering hidden dungeons, secret NPC quests, or massive optional bosses that test your skills to the limit.

The gameplay is tight, responsive, and endlessly versatile—you can experiment with builds, weapons, and magic to tackle challenges in countless ways. The lore is rich and cryptic, encouraging curiosity and rewarding those who pay attention to every detail.

In my opinion, Elden Ring sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. It’s punishing, yes, but every victory feels earned and every discovery feels magical. Few games leave such a lasting impression, and this one will stay with me for years to come.

Pros

Very good customization 
Very good Graphics and atmosphere.
The lore is very good.
Good characters that you can meet around the map.
Combat is fun and challenging.
Extremely good map with lots of places to explore, monsters, bosses and etc.

Cons

The side quests don't tell you where you need to go to complete it.
The bosses can get really spammy.

If you like the base game for Elden Ring I recommend trying out the DLC Shadow Of The Erdtree. 
Overall phenomenal game 10/10 for me.
